The '''6521 Project,''' sometimes called the "6521 Group," was the moniker given to a nationwide operation initiated by the [[Communist Party of China]] in 2009 to ensure “social stability” by cracking down on potential dissidents during anniversaries of political significance. The digits in the campaign’s name are a reference to the 60th anniversary of the founding of the [[People’s Republic of China]], the 50th anniversary of the [[1959 Tibetan uprising]], the 20th anniversary of the [[Tiananmen Square protests of 1989|Tiananmen Square protests]], and the 10th anniversary of the [[persecution of Falun Gong]].<ref>Michael Wines. [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/11/world/asia/11china.html "Anniversaries for Tibet and Tiananmen Square Have China on Edge"]. The New York Times, 10 March 2009.</ref>
The 6521 Project was initiated as a top-level committee by the Communist Party, and was reportedly headed by [[Xi Jinping]], current [[General Secretary of the Communist Party of China]].<ref>Michael Wines. [https://www.nytimes.com/2009/03/10/world/asia/10china.html 'China's Leaders See a Calendar Full of Anniversaries, and Trouble']. The New York Times, 9 March 2009.</ref>
Under the campaign, all provinces and municipalities were required to establish temporary 6521 taskforces under the local Communist Party and Public Security leadership. Authorities at the township and county levels were also required to implement the 6521 project, reporting on their progress to municipal or provincial taskforces above them.<ref>Cary Huang, ‘‘Taskforces Set Up To Keep Lid on Protests,’’ South China Morning Post, 28 February 2009</ref><ref>Congressional Executive Commission on China. [http://www.cecc.gov/pages/annualRpt/annualRpt09/CECCannRpt2009.pdf "2009 Annual Report"] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091103235417/http://www.cecc.gov/pages/annualRpt/annualRpt09/CECCannRpt2009.pdf |date=2009-11-03 }}, 10 Oct 2009.</ref>
In parallel to the 6521 Project, a top-level coordinating body was created under the direction of [[Zhou Yongkang]], called the "Central Committee for Comprehensive Management of Social Order." The committee identified a series of potential threats to social order, and prescribed measures to suppress them. The threats named included ethnic separatism in Tibet, Falun Gong, protests triggered by unemployment, land grabs, tainted products and labor disputes, crime, and the illicit installation of satellite receivers and illegal publishing. The Committee set out 33 measures to ensure social stability. It also revived a network of volunteer informants in schools and neighborhoods, and established a joint responsibility system that holds heads of households, work units, and local governments accountable in the event of protests or other destabilizing events.<ref>Ching Cheong. [http://www.hkej.com/template/blog/php/blog_details.php?blog_posts_id=2277 "China Acts to Defuse 'Crisis Year'"]. Singapore Straits Times. 3 March 2009</ref>
==See also== *[[Human rights in the People's Republic of China]] *[[List of campaigns of the Communist Party of China]] *[[Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox Officeholder | name = Ajai Malhotra | image = Dmitry_Medvedev_with_ambassadors_14_July_2011-8.jpeg | imagesize = | caption = | birth_date = 21 November 1953 | birth_place = [[India]] |nationality = Indian |office = Indian Ambassador to the Russian Federation |term_start = 16 May 2011 |predecessor = |office1 = |term1 = |predecessor1 = [[Prabhat Prakash Shukla]] |successor1 = [[P. S. Raghavan]] |occupation = Diplomat |awards = [[Doctor of Letters]] |spouse = Ira Malhotra }} '''Ajai Malhotra''' is a former [[Indian Foreign Service|Indian career diplomat]] who served as Ambassador of India to the [[Russian Federation]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Indian Ambassadors To Russia |url=http://indianembassy.ru/index.php/en/embassy/indian-ambassadors-to-russia |accessdate=7 August 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130802113750/http://www.indianembassy.ru/index.php/en/embassy/indian-ambassadors-to-russia |archivedate=2 August 2013 }}</ref> == Background and education == Malhotra is the son of [[General|Gen.]] [[Om Prakash Malhotra]], former [[Chief of the Army Staff (India)|Chief of the Army Staff]]. During his childhood, his father was posted at various locations across India and abroad, and therefore Malhotra attended several different Army Schools. He completed his schooling from [[St. Xavier's School, Delhi]]. He earned his B.A. (Hons.) in Economics from [[Hindu College, University of Delhi]] and his M.A. in economics from the [[Delhi School of Economics]]. Malhotra speaks English, Hindi, Russian, German and [[Swahili language|Kiswahili]].
== Diplomatic career == He joined the [[Indian Foreign Service]] in 1977. From 1979–1982 he served at the High Commission in Nairobi, handling political work relating to [[Kenya]] and India's relations with [[Seychelles]]. From 1982–1985 he was Second Secretary (Pol.)/First Secretary (Pol.) at the Indian Embassy in Moscow.
From 1985, he served as First Secretary (Pol.) at the Permanent Mission of India to the UN in [[Geneva]], where he handled work related to the [[WHO]], [[WIPO]], [[ILO]] and other UN agencies, represented India on the ILO Committee on Freedom of Association and also participated in annual meetings of the [[UN Human Rights Commission]]. He returned to the [[Ministry of External Affairs (India)|Ministry of External Affairs]], New Delhi in 1989, as a Deputy Secretary handling human rights and international environmental issues, and later Director handling all multilateral issues except disarmament. As regards human rights, this included guiding processes leading to the ratification by India of the UN [[Convention on the Rights of the Child]] in 1992, UN [[Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination Against Women]] in 1993, and the establishment of the [[National Human Rights Commission of India]].<ref>http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/HRBodies/HRCouncil/AdvisoryCom/A_HRC_36_17_EN.docx</ref>
His association with global environmental issues has included participation in the UNEP Session of a Special Character: Ten Years after Stockholm (Nairobi; 1982); contribution to the drafting of the 1990 London Amendments to the [[Montreal Protocol]] on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer, [[Convention on Biological Diversity]], [[UN Framework Convention on Climate Change]], [[Rio Declaration on Environment and Development]], Statement of Principles on Forests, and [[Agenda 21]]; and participation in the [[UN Conference on Environment and Development]] (Rio de Janeiro; 1992).<ref>Mukund Govind Rajan, Global Environmental Politics: India and the North-South Politics of Global Environmental Issues, Oxford University Press, 1997, pgs 24,71-72</ref><ref>http://www.teriin.org/index.php?option=com_aboutus&id=3228&p=emp&view=profile&Itemid=181</ref> He was a member of the UNEP group of legal experts to examine the concept of "Common Concern of Mankind" in relation to global environmental issues.<ref>https://revistas-colaboracion.juridicas.unam.mx/index.php/rev-instituto-interamericano-dh/article/viewFile/7787/7024</ref>
He was Counsellor (Information) at the Indian Embassy, Moscow, from 1993–1996, returning to the Ministry of External Affairs, New Delhi, as Director/Joint Secretary and guided India's foreign relations with 22 Central and Eastern European countries, including Russia. In 1999, he was assigned as Minister (Commerce) at the Embassy of India, Washington, D.C. where he served till 2003. He was also Vice Chairman (2000–2001), First Vice Chairman (2001–2002) and then Chairman (2002–2003) of the [[International Cotton Advisory Committee]].<ref>https://www.icac.org/psap/documents/psap_public/misc/psap_reception_may03.pdf</ref>
Ajai Malhotra's served as Ambassador of India to [[Romania]] (with concurrent accreditation to [[Moldova]] and [[Albania]]) from 2003 to 2005.<ref>http://www.mea.gov.in/press-releases.htm?dtl/9157/Appointment+of+Shri+Ajai+Malhotra+as+the+next+Ambassador+of+India+to+Romania</ref><ref>http://www.mea.gov.in/press-releases.htm?dtl/8723/Appointment+of+Shri+Ajai+Malhotra+as+the+next+Ambassador+of+India+to+the+Republic+of+Moldova</ref><ref>http://www.mea.gov.in/press-releases.htm?dtl/7928/Appointment+of+Shri+Ajai+Malhotra+as+the+next+Ambassador+of+India+to+Republic+of+Albania</ref>
From 2005–2009, he was Ambassador and Deputy Permanent Representative of India to the UN, New York. Based on leaked American diplomatic cables, published by [[WikiLeaks]], it was reported that Ajai Malhotra was posted to the UN Mission, New York to balance the anti-US decisions taken by [[Nirupam Sen]], then Permanent Representative of India, to the UN.<ref name="06USUNNEWYORK1033_a">{{cite journal| last =D.Wolff| first =Alejandro| authorlink =| author2 =| title =INDIAN DPR PLEDGES TO COOPERATE WITH USG ON NEPAL, UN BUDGET, AND SYG SELECTION| id={{WikiLeaks cable|06USUNNEWYORK1033_a}} |work =| publisher =[[WikiLeaks]]| date =19 May 2006| url =https://wikileaks.org/plusd/cables/06USUNNEWYORK1033_a.html | doi =| accessdate =10 August 2013|archiveurl= |archivedate= |deadurl=no }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Sreenivasan|first1=TP|title=WikiLeaks: Indian diplomats emerge unscathed|url=http://www.rediff.com/news/column/indian-diplomats-america-wikileaks/20110325.htm|accessdate=24 June 2013|publisher=Rediff.com|date=March 25, 2011}}</ref> He participated in the negotiations leading to the setting up of the [[UN Democracy Fund]], the [[UN Peacebuilding Commission]] and the [[UN Human Rights Council]].<ref>https://www.pminewyork.org/adminpart/uploadpdf/53261ind1206.pdf</ref><ref>http://www.ohchr.org/Documents/HRBodies/HRCouncil/AdvisoryCom/A_HRC_36_17_EN.docx</ref> His pivotal role in the development of the [[United Nations Democracy Fund]] was cited by the awards committee of the Palmer Prize for Advancing Democracy, awarded by the [[Council for a Community of Democracies]].<ref>Bob R. LaGamma. "Palmer Prize honors diplomats for Advancing Democracy" (PDF). Council for Community of Democracies. Archived from the original (PDF) on 1 July 2011. Retrieved 10 August 2013.</ref>
He was Ambassador of India to [[Kuwait]] from 2009–2011.<ref>{{cite news|title=H.H. the Amir receives credential of foreign diplomats|url=http://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=1985335&language=en|accessdate=10 August 2013|date=24 March 2009|agency=KUNA – Kuwait News Agency|location=Kuwait}}</ref><ref name=atam>{{cite news|title=Indian Envoy Leaving Kuwait – End of Successful Tenure|url=http://www.arabtimesonline.com/NewsDetails/tabid/96/smid/414/ArticleID/167609/reftab/67/t/Indian-envoy-leaving-Kuwait/Default.aspx|accessdate=10 August 2013|newspaper=Arab Times|date=5 April 2011|location=Kuwait}}</ref> He was responsible for expanding the protection of Indian workers in Kuwai and set up a safe house, especially for domestic workers in distress.<ref>{{cite news|title=Kuwait's Indian embassy sets model to help workers in distress|url=http://www.sify.com/news/kuwait-s-indian-embassy-sets-model-to-help-workers-in-distress-news-international-lc1qufcgidd.html|accessdate=10 August 2013|newspaper=Sify|date=27 February 2011|agency=IANS}}</ref> His tenure was also highlighted by high level visits from India to Kuwait, including by the Vice-President of India, [[Mohammad Hamid Ansari|Hamid Ansari]]<ref name=atam /> and [[S. M. Krishna]],<ref>{{cite news|title=Krishna to seek closer ties with Kuwait|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/international/krishna-to-seek-closer-ties-with-kuwait/article100370.ece|accessdate=10 August 2013|newspaper=The Hindu|date=4 February 2010}}</ref> former External Affairs Minister.
He was the Ambassador of India to Russia from 16 May 2011 – 30 November 2013.<ref>https://www.rbth.com/arts/2013/08/08/p_s_raghavan_to_be_indias_next_ambassador_in_russia_28167</ref> His tenure saw the visit of Indian Prime Minister, [[Manmohan Singh]] in mid-December 2011 to Russia, and Russian President [[Dmitry Medvedev]] to India in March 2012 for the [[BRICS]] summit in New Delhi. It also saw visits to India in December 2012 by Russian President [[Vladimir Putin]] and to Russia by Indian Prime Minister Manmohan Singh in September 2013 for the G20 Summit in St. Petersburg and in November 2013 to Moscow for the annual India-Russia Bilateral Summit. The 65th anniversary of bilateral Indo-Russian diplomatic relations was marked with year-long celebrations during his tenure.<ref>{{cite news|title=65th anniversary of bilateral diplomatic relations will be celebrated throughout the year – Ambassador Malhotra|url=http://indrus.in/articles/2012/03/15/bilateral_agreements_are_not_usually_signed_during_a_visit_for_a_mul_15150.html|accessdate=10 August 2013|newspaper=Russia & India report|date=15 March 2012|agency=Interfax}}</ref> It also saw the induction of three [[Talwar-class frigate]]s into the [[Indian Navy]] fleet, [[INS Teg (F45)|INS Teg]], [[INS Tarkash (F50)|INS Tarkash]], and [[INS Trikand (F51)|INS Trikand]],<ref>[http://articles.economictimes.indiatimes.com/2013-06-29/news/40271741_1_indian-navy-close-in-weapon-system-ins-trikand India Inducts New Power-Packed Stealth Frigates]. ''The Economic Times.'' Retrieved 16 August 2013</ref> as well as India's nuclear powered submarine [[INS Chakra (2011)]]<ref>{{cite news|title=INS Chakra commissioned to Indian Navy|url=http://www.sunday-guardian.com/news/ins-chakra-commissioned-to-indian-navy|publisher=The Sunday Guardian|date=23 January 2012}}</ref> and aircraft carrier [[INS Vikramaditya]].<ref>{{cite news|title=Aircraft carrier Vikramaditya inducted into Indian Navy|url=http://www.deccanchronicle.com/131116/news-current-affairs/article/aircraft-carrier-vikramaditya-inducted-indian-navy|agency=Press Trust of India|publisher=Deccan Chronicle|date=17 November 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Speech by H.E. Mr. Ajai Malhotra, Ambassador of India to Russia, at the commissioning of INS Vikramaditya into the Indian Navy; Severodvinsk, 16 November 2013.|url=http://indianembassy.ru/index.php/media-news/press-releases/984-speech-by-h-e-mr-ajai-malhotra-ambassador-of-india-to-russia-at-the-commissioning-of-ins-vikramaditya-into-the-indian-navy-severodvin|website=Embassy of India, Moscow}}</ref> [[INS Trikand (F51)|INS Trikand]] was launched by his wife, Mrs. Ira Malhotra.<ref name=trikand>{{cite web|title=Speech by H.E. Mr. Ajai Malhotra, Ambassador of India to the Russian Federation, at the Commissioning Ceremony of INS Trikand at Kaliningrad, June 29, 2013|url=http://www.indianembassy.ru/index.php/en/media-news/press-releases/932-speech-by-h-e-mr-ajai-malhotra-ambassador-of-india-to-the-russian-federation-at-the-commissioning-ceremony-of-ins-trikand-at-kaliningrad-june-29-2013|publisher=Indian Embassy, Russia|accessdate=10 August 2013}}</ref> He retired on 30 November 2013.<ref>{{cite news|title=P S Raghavan to be India's next ambassador in Russia|url=http://indrus.in/arts/2013/08/08/p_s_raghavan_to_be_indias_next_ambassador_in_russia_28167.html|accessdate=10 August 2013|newspaper=Russia & India report|date=8 August 2013|author=Rajeev Sharma}}</ref>
==Later roles== Since February 2014, Malhotra is the Chairman and Managing Trustee of Chikitsa<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://chikitsatrust.org/board-of-trustees/|title=» Board of Trustees|website=chikitsatrust.org|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-23}}</ref> which provides free primary health care in underserved communities and [[Shiksha (NGO)|Shiksha]]<ref>{{cite web|title=Board of Trustees|url=http://shikshatrust.org/board-of-trustees/|website=Shiksha}}</ref> which provides free education and vocational training to underprivileged children and youth.
Since April 2014 he is a Distinguished Fellow & Senior Adviser (Climate Change) at [[The Energy and Resources Institute]], New Delhi.<ref>{{cite web|title=TERI – Profile|url=http://www.teriin.org/index.php?option=com_aboutus&id=3228&p=emp&view=profile&Itemid=181|website=The Energy Resources Institute}}</ref> Since 2015 he is Chairman of the Managing Committee of the NAB Centre for Blind Women & Disability Studies<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.nabcentreforwomen.org/the-managing-comittee/|title=Managing Committee|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}}</ref> and a member of the Editorial Board of the [[World Economy and International Relations]] Journal at the [[Institute of World Economy and International Relations]], Moscow.<ref>https://www.imemo.ru/en/jour/meimo/index.php?page_id=687&id=55</ref>
In 2015, he was elected Chairman of the Nehru Trust for the Indian Collections at the [[Victoria & Albert Museum]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Ambassador Ajai Malhotra IFS (Retd) becomes Chairman of the NTICVA|url=http://www.nehrutrustvam.org/ambassador-ajai-malhotra-ifs-retd-becomes-chairman-nticva-0|website=Nehru Trust for the Indian Collections at the Victoria & Albert Museum}}</ref>
On November 20, 2015, he was appointed an Independent Director of [[Oil and Natural Gas Corporation]] (ONGC).<ref>{{cite web|title=TERI – Profile|url=http://www.ongcindia.com/wps/wcm/connect/ongcindia/Home/Company/Board_of_Directors/Independent_Director/Ajai+Malhotra/|website=ONGC }}</ref>
On January 16, 2017, he was appointed an Independent Director of ONGC Videsh Limited.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ongcvidesh.com/company/board-of-directors/|title=Board of Directors {{!}} ONGC Videsh Ltd.|website=www.ongcvidesh.com|language=en-US|access-date=2017-04-23}}</ref>
On September 29, 2017, he was elected by [[secret ballot]] to the Advisory Committee of the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]], Geneva.<ref>https://www.unog.ch/80256EDD006B9C2E/(httpNewsByYear_en)/B55FBFBCC7F9BF61C12581AA0067DFA9?OpenDocument</ref>
== Recognition ==
In 2004, he was awarded a Doctorate ([[Honoris causa|Honoris Causa]]) by the [[Vasile Goldiş Western University of Arad]], Romania, in recognition of his work in support of environmental causes and sustainable development.<ref>{{Cite web |url=http://dir.uvvg.ro/dhc.html |title=Archived copy |access-date=1 October 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131213155945/http://dir.uvvg.ro/dhc.html |archive-date=13 December 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}</ref>
In 2011, he was cited by the awards committee of the Palmer Prize for Advancing Democracy, awarded by the [[Council for a Community of Democracies]] for his pivotal role in supporting democratic development and development of the [[United Nations Democracy Fund]] (UNDEF), and for being a forceful advocate of channelling UNDEF funds to civil society.<ref>{{cite web|title=Palmer Prize honors diplomats for Advancing Democracy |url=http://ccd21.org/pdf/vilnius_palmer_prize_press_release.pdf |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110701010101/http://ccd21.org/pdf/vilnius_palmer_prize_press_release.pdf|publisher=Council for Community of Democracies |accessdate=10 August 2013 |author=Bob R. LaGamma |dead-url=yes |archivedate=1 July 2011 }}</ref>
In 2015, he was conferred a 'Lifetime Achievement Award' by [[Hindu College, University of Delhi]] at its 13th Distinguished Alumni Awards in New Delhi.<ref> https://news.webindia123.com/news/articles/india/20150418/2574744.html</ref>
== Personal life ==
Ajai Malhotra is married to Ira Malhotra,<ref>{{cite web|title=Expanded cultural links benefit "both our peoples"- Ira Malhotra|url=http://indrus.in/arts/2013/05/27/expanded_cultural_links_benefit_both_our_peoples-_ira_malhotra_25415.html|publisher=Russia & India report|accessdate=10 August 2013}}</ref> who is a teacher and was the founding editor of 'Parenting' magazine in India.<ref>{{cite web|title=Mrs Ira Malhotra: Our first lady of the Indian Embassy in Kuwait, a crusader for the cause of education|url=http://www.indiansinkuwait.com/ShowArticle.aspx?ID=5003&SECTION=0|publisher=Indians in Kuwait|accessdate=11 August 2013}}</ref> She launched the warship, the [[INS Trikand (F51)|INS Trikand]], which was delivered to India from Russia during his tenure.<ref name=trikand /> He has a son and a daughter. He is the son of [[General OP Malhotra]].
==Bibliography== * {{cite book|last1=Malhotra|first1=Ajai|title=Future Generations and International Law: Earthscan Law and Sustainable Development|year=1997|isbn=1-317-97178-7}} * {{cite book|last1=Malhotra|first1=Ajai|title=India-Russia-China: Is There a Case for Strategic Partnership?|year=2015|isbn=9789384464653}} * {{Cite journal|last=Malhotra|first=Ajai|title=Climate Change: Tackling the Challenge Confronting India|url=http://www.associationdiplomats.org/Publications/ifaj/Vol11/11.2/11.2-F-ARTICLE%201.pdf|journal=Indian Foreign Affairs Journal|volume=11|date=April–June 2016|pages=124–138}}

{{Infobox political party | name = The Alliance | logo = Alliansen.svg | logo_size = 150 | colorcode = darkorange | leader1_title = [[Moderate Party|Moderate]] | leader1_name = [[Ulf Kristersson]] | leader2_title = [[Centre Party (Sweden)|Centre]] | leader2_name = [[Annie Lööf]] | leader3_title = [[Christian Democrats (Sweden)|Christian Democrats]] | leader3_name = [[Ebba Busch Thor]] | leader4_title = [[Liberals (Sweden)|Liberals]] | leader4_name = [[Jan Björklund]] | foundation = 31 August 2004 | headquarters = | international = | website = {{URL|http://www.alliansen.se/}} | country = Sweden | native_name = Alliansen | dissolution = | predecessor = | newspaper = | membership_year = | membership = | ideology = [[Liberalism]]
[[Liberal conservatism]]
[[Christian democracy]] | position = [[Centre-right politics|Centre-right]] | european = | europarl = | colors = {{Color box|#F5891C|border=darkgray}} [[Orange (color)|Orange]] {{Color box|#1E5FE0|border=darkgray}} [[Blue]] | seats1_title = [[Parliament of Sweden|Parliament]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|143|349|hex=#F5891C}} }} {{Politics of Sweden}} '''The Alliance''' ({{lang-sv|Alliansen}}), formerly the '''Alliance for Sweden''' (''Allians för Sverige''), is a [[Centre-right politics|centre-right]] [[liberal conservative]] [[political alliance]] in [[Sweden]]. The Alliance consists of the four centre-right [[list of political parties in Sweden|political parties]] in the [[Riksdag]]. The Alliance was formed while in [[opposition (parliamentary)|opposition]], and later achieved a majority government in the [[Swedish general election, 2006|2006 general election]] and a minority government in the [[Swedish general election, 2010|2010 general election]], governing Sweden from 2006 to 2014 with [[Fredrik Reinfeldt]] of the [[Moderate Party]] serving as [[Prime Minister of Sweden]] until the [[Swedish general election, 2014|2014 general election]]. The Alliance is co-chaired by every component party's individual leaders. After [[Swedish general election, 2014|defeat in 2014]], the [[Moderate Party]]'s [[parliamentary group leader]] [[Anna Kinberg Batra]] announced to the [[Riksdag]] that the [[political alliance]] now "will operate in opposition". As a result of the [[Swedish general election, 2018|2018 general election]], the future of the Alliance is uncertain. In November, the Centre Party and the Liberals opposed Ulf Kristersson's proposed government coalition composed of the Moderates and the Christian Democrats. Kristersson was supported by three parties; his own Moderate Party, the Christian Democrats and the Sweden Democrats. The Centre Party and Liberals opposed the idea of such a coalition, as they are against any government that depends on the Sweden Democrats.{{Cite news|url=https://www.dn.se/nyheter/politik/kristersson-en-tung-dag-for-alliansen/|title=Kristersson: ”En tung dag för Alliansen”|last=Mannheimer|first=Edgar|date=13 November 2018|work=Dagens Nyheter|access-date=}} == Members of the Alliance == [[File:Kommundagarna 2018 (41924664142).jpg|thumb|Four leaders together]] The Alliance consists of the four centre-right ({{lang-sv|borgerlig}}, lit. "[[bourgeois]]") parties in the Riksdag (Sweden's [[parliament]]). The members are: *The '''[[Moderate Party]]''' led by [[Ulf Kristersson]] since 2017, a [[Liberal conservatism|liberal conservative]] party currently with 70 of 349 seats (19.84%) in the Riksdag. *The '''[[Centre Party (Sweden)|Centre Party]]''' led by [[Annie Lööf]] since 2011, a [[Liberalism|liberal]], former [[Nordic agrarian parties|agrarian]] party currently with 31 of 349 seats (8.61%) in the Riksdag. *The '''[[Christian Democrats (Sweden)|Christian Democrats]]''' led by [[Ebba Busch Thor]] since 2015, a [[Christian democracy|Christian democratic]] party currently with 22 of 349 seats (6.32%) in the Riksdag. *The '''[[Liberals (Sweden)|Liberals]]''' (formerly the '''Liberal People's Party''') led by [[Jan Björklund]] since 2007, a [[Liberalism|liberal]] party currently with 20 of 349 seats (5.49%) in the Riksdag. ==== Other ==== *The '''[[Health Care Party]] of Dalarna''' led by [[Ingvar Niilimaa]], a [[Single-issue politics|single-issue party]] which only active in [[Dalarna County]] where it become part of a DSP-Alliance-MP government since 2018.{{cite news|title=Historiskt maktskifte i Dalarna – Alliansen tar över efter 92 år|url=https://www.svt.se/nyheter/lokalt/dalarna/historiskt-maktskifte-i-dalarna-alliansen-tar-over-efter-92-ar|newspaper=SVT Nyheter|date=2018-10-11|accessdate=2018-10-26|language=sv}}{{cite news|title=Nya namnet: Dalasamverkan|url=https://www.svt.se/nyheter/lokalt/dalarna/nya-namnet-dalasamverkan|newspaper=SVT Nyheter|date=2018-10-11|accessdate=2018-10-26|language=sv}} *The '''[[New Democracy (Sweden)|New Democracy]]''' led by [[Ian Wachtmeister]] and [[Bert Karlsson]], a [[Right-wing populism|right-wing populist party]] which support the centre-right government 1991 to 1994. The party dissolved 2000. == History of the Alliance == [[Politics of Sweden|Swedish politics]] had been dominated by the [[Swedish Social Democratic Party|Social Democratic Party]] for over 70 years. They had been in [[government]] for all but nine years (summer of 1936, 1976–1982, 1991–1994) since 1932. The opposition parties decided that this was partly because they did not present a clear and viable alternative government. At a meeting held in the Centre Party leader Maud Olofsson's home in the village of [[Högfors (village)|Högfors]], the four party leaders decided to form an alliance. The meeting ended on 31 August 2004 with the presentation of a joint declaration outlining the principles under which the four parties intended to fight the election.{{cite web |title=Allians för Sverige |publisher=Allians för Sverige |date=31 August 2004 |url=http://www.alliansforsverige.se/wp-content/uploads/2007/09/hogfors.pdf |language=Swedish |accessdate=19 September 2010}} A year later a similar meeting was held at Christian Democrat leader Göran Hägglund's home in [[Bankeryd]], resulting in the affirmation of the alliance and another declaration.{{cite web |title=Program för arbete |publisher=Allians för Sverige |date=31 August 2005 |url=http://www.alliansforsverige.se/wp-content/uploads/2007/09/bankeryd1.pdf |language=Swedish |accessdate=19 September 2010}} == Aims and policies of the Alliance == [[File:Allians för Sverige.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Alliance for Sweden's press conference in [[Sundsvall]] during the bus tour of 6–7 March 2006. From left to right: Reinfeldt, Olofsson, Hägglund and Leijonborg.]] [[File:Alliansen 2010.JPG|thumb|300px|right|The Alliance the day before the 2010 election. From left to right: Hägglund, Björklund, Olofsson and Reinfeldt]] The Centre-right Alliance for Sweden aimed to win a [[majority]] of seats in the [[Swedish general election, 2006|2006 Riksdag elections]] and form a [[coalition government]]. In order to do this, the member parties decided to issue common [[policy]] statements and to have a joint election manifesto. Each individual party still had its own manifesto and policies, but these will build up from common proposals in the Alliance's joint proposals. The Alliance has policy working groups for six areas: [[economic policy]], [[education policy]], [[foreign policy]], the [[welfare state]], [[employment]] and [[business]] policy, and [[policing]]. These were not set according to party size, but with one senior politician (often MP) and one staff per party, and following the idea that "everybody contributes and everybody gains".{{cite web|title=Ännu fler ministrar|url=http://www.aftonbladet.se/nyheter/valet2010/article12554110.ab|website=Aftonbladet|accessdate=1 May 2017}} An example of this policy cooperation was the [[budget]] proposal that the Alliance parties put forward on 2 October 2005. The core proposal was a tax cut of 49 billion [[Swedish kronor]], which is 1.9% of [[GDP]] and 3.3% of the total income of the [[public sector]] in 2005.{{cite news |title=En tunn agenda för reformer |newspaper=[[Dagens Nyheter]] |date=4 October 2005 |url=http://www.dn.se/ledare/huvudledare/en-tunn-agenda-for-reformer-1.394779 |language=Swedish |accessdate=19 September 2010}} Each individual party also proposed its own policies in addition. For example, the Liberals want to spend 1bn kronor extra on tertiary education and the Christian Democrats want to have more benefits and tax deductions for families. On 14 June 2006 Alliance for Sweden agreed on a common energy policy. It will apply over the next parliamentary term (2006–2010), and includes a promise not to shut down any more [[nuclear reactor]]s during that period ([[Barsebäck nuclear power plant|Barsebäck 2]] was shut down in 2005). The proposal is that no more reactors are to be built, that the nuclear phase-out law will be repealed and that all forms of energy research will be legal and able to receive state grants (research on [[nuclear power]] is currently forbidden in Sweden). An Alliance government would also grant any applications to increase the output of the existing plants, provided that it would be safe to do so.{{cite news |title=Alliance agrees to keep nuclear |first=Adam |last=Ewing |newspaper=[[The Local]] |date=14 June 2006 |url=http://www.thelocal.se/article.php?ID=4068&date=20060614 |accessdate=19 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605043735/http://www.thelocal.se/article.php?ID=4068&date=20060614 |archivedate=5 June 2011 |df= }} This has been hailed as a historic step, as disagreement over nuclear power has long plagued the centre-right in Sweden: the Centre Party opposes nuclear power, the Moderates and Christian Democrats support its continuing operation while the Liberals want to build more reactors. Some doubts have been raised about the long-term survival of this compromise, as neither the Centre Party nor the Liberals have changed their fundamental positions on nuclear power. On 5 July 2006, during the politics week at [[Almedalen]] on [[Gotland]], the Alliance parties announced a plan to abolish [[property tax]]. Their agreement promises to freeze taxable values at the current level (so that the revaluation that is being carried out will not apply), and to reduce the rate of tax on apartments from 0.5% to 0.4% of their taxable value.{{cite news |title=Alliance to abolish property tax |first=Adam |last=Ewing |newspaper=[[The Local]] |date=4 July 2006 |url=http://www.thelocal.se/article.php?ID=4249&date=20060704 |accessdate=19 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605044009/http://www.thelocal.se/article.php?ID=4249&date=20060704 |archivedate=5 June 2011 |df= }} A ceiling of 5000 [[Swedish kronor|kronor]] will also be imposed on the taxation of the value of a house's plot. The parties are also agreed on the abolition of the tax and its replacement with a municipal charge independent of the value of the property; this reform is planned to be carried out in 2008. Property tax is estimated to bring in 28.1 billion kronor in 2006, rising to 30.2bn in 2007 and 32.2bn in 2008 (as taxable values rise). The first stage of the Alliance's plan (freezing property values, capping the tax on land value and reducing the rate for apartments) is estimated to cost around 4-5 billion kronor. The financing of this is to be revealed in the Alliance's [[manifesto]] in August 2006. Alliance for Sweden released its election manifesto,{{cite web |title=Fler i arbete – mer att dela på |publisher=Allians för Sverige |date=23 August 2006 |url=http://www.alliansforsverige.se/wp-content/uploads/2007/09/valmanifest2006.pdf |language=Swedish |accessdate=19 September 2010| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090411091041/http://www.alliansforsverige.se/wp-content/uploads/2007/09/Valmanifest2006.pdf| archivedate=April 11, 2009| deadurl= no}} entitled ''More people at work - more to share'' ({{lang-sv|Fler i arbete - mer att dela på}}), on 23 August 2006. The result of the election was clear enough on election night for [[Moderate Party]] leader [[Fredrik Reinfeldt]] to declare himself the victor and for [[Göran Persson]] to announce his resignation as [[Prime Minister of Sweden|Prime Minister]] and as leader of the [[Swedish Social Democratic Party|Social Democratic Party]]. The four [[centre-right]] parties of Alliance for Sweden formed a government with Fredrik Reinfeldt as Prime Minister, which was presented to the [[Parliament of Sweden|Riksdag]] on 6 October. == The Alliance government (2006-2014) == {{See also|Cabinet of Fredrik Reinfeldt|Government of Sweden}} [[Minister for Finance (Sweden)|Minister for Finance]] [[Anders Borg]] presented the government's first budget{{cite web |title=Autumn Budget Bill: Putting Sweden to work - a good deal for all |publisher=[[Ministry of Finance (Sweden)|Ministry of Finance]] |date=16 October 2006 |url=http://www.sweden.gov.se/sb/d/7341/a/71054;jsessionid=aXEoxDjfj4h- |accessdate=19 September 2010}} on 16 October 2006. The budget contains many of the proposals that were prominent in the Alliance's election campaign: both the job deduction in the income tax, which will also be larger for old people to encourage them to remain in the labour market, and the "fresh start jobs" with reduced payroll tax for companies employing people who have been unemployed for more than a year will come into effect from 1 January 2007. Tax reductions for companies hiring young people and for domestic services are to come into effect on 1 July. The tax reductions announced in the budget total 42 billion [[Swedish kronor]],{{cite news |title=Swedish tax slashed by 42 billion kronor |first=Paul |last=O'Mahony |newspaper=[[The Local]] |agency=[[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå]] |date=16 October 2006 |url=http://www.thelocal.se/article.php?ID=5229&date=20061016 |accessdate=19 September 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110605054251/http://www.thelocal.se/article.php?ID=5229&date=20061016 |archivedate=5 June 2011 |df= }} of which the income tax deduction is 38.7 billion. Other changes include the ending of employers' co-financing of sickness benefit after the second week, reduction of unemployment benefits and considerably raised fees to unemployment funds, resulting in a substantial decline in union density and density of unemployment funds.Anders Kjellberg (2011) [http://portal.research.lu.se/portal/files/3462138/2064087.pdf "The Decline in Swedish Union Density since 2007"] ''Nordic Journal of Working Life Studies'' (NJWLS) Vol. 1. No 1 (August 2011), pp. 67-93Anders Kjellberg and Christian Lyhne Ibsen (2016) [https://lup.lub.lu.se/search/ws/files/21682547/Kjellberg_og_Ibsen_2016_ur_Due_og_Madsen.pdf "Attacks on union organizing: Reversible and irreversible changes to the Ghent-systems in Sweden and Denmark"] in Trine Pernille Larsen and Anna Ilsøe (eds.)(2016) ''Den Danske Model set udefra (The Danish Model Inside Out) - komparative perspektiver på dansk arbejdsmarkedsregulering'', Copenhagen: Jurist- og Økonomforbundets Forlag (pp.279-302) Unemployment benefit would remain 80% of previous pay for 200 days then drop to 70%. Benefit would be payable for a maximum of 300 days, or 450 if the recipient has children. ==List of Leaders of The Alliance== {| class="wikitable" style="font-size:95%;" ! Year ! Moderate Party ! '''[[Moderate Party|Leader]]''' 1 October 2017 – present |- | 2018 |} ==Electoral history== [[File:Kommundagarna 2018 (41968939921).jpg|thumb|Four leaders in February 2018.]] [[File:Kommundagarna 2018 (41924670372).jpg|thumb|Four leaders in February 2018.]] In 1991, the Alliance was called the Centre-Right Parties. They formed the centre-right minority coalition government in 1991 with the support of right-wing populist party After the coalition had been lost in 1994, the Centre-Right Parties was dissolved but the centre-right opposition parties continued to work together. In 2004, the four parties Moderate Party, Centre Party, Liberal People's Party and the Christian Democrats wanted to collaborate again. So they started the Alliance. [[Lago Agrio oil field]]. | birth_name = | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1970}} <!-- {{Birth date and age|1970|MM|DD}} or {{Birth-date and age|Month DD, 1970}} --> | birth_place = [[Pennsylvania]] | death_date = <!-- {{Death date and age|YYYY|MM|DD|YYYY|MM|DD}} or {{Death-date and age|Month DD, YYYY|Month DD, YYYY}} (death date then birth date) --> | death_place = | nationality = [[United States|American]] | other_names = | occupation = [[Energy analyst]], [[author]], [[journalist]] and [[activist]] | known_for = [[Oil industry]] investigations | website = http://www.antoniajuhasz.net/ }}
'''Antonia Juhasz''' (born 1970) is an American oil and energy analyst, author, journalist and activist.<ref name=wsj290910>{{Cite news | url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703882404575520202919898096 |title=Activist Faces Charges in Chevron Meeting Outburst | first = John | last = Letzing | newspaper= [[The Wall Street Journal]] | date=29 September 2010 | accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=ens140411>{{Cite news | url=http://www.ens-newswire.com/ens/apr2011/2011-04-14-01.html |title= Protesters Disrupt BP's First Shareholder Meeting Since Oil Spill | work = Environment News Service |date= 14 April 2011 |accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=alameda040108>{{Cite news | url=http://alamedasun.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2585&Itemid=10 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131113230311/http://alamedasun.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2585&Itemid=10 | dead-url=yes | archive-date=13 November 2013 |title= 'Big Oil' Topic of Public Affairs Forum Meeting | newspaper = Alameda Sun |date= 4 January 2008 |accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=npr071008>{{Cite news | url= https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=95465269 |title= Antonia Juhasz: 'Tyranny of Oil' Is A Grave Threat | work = [[NPR]] |date= 7 October 2008 |accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref> She has authored three books: ''The Bush Agenda'' (2006), ''The Tyranny of Oil'' (2008), and ''Black Tide'' (2011).
==Education== Juhasz earned her [[undergraduate education|undergraduate]] degree in [[Public Policy]] at [[Brown University]].<ref name="education">[http://www.tyrannyofoil.org/article.php?id=43 Education] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120301070726/http://www.tyrannyofoil.org/article.php?id=43 |date=March 1, 2012 }}</ref> She then earned her [[Master of Arts|M.A.]] degree in Public Policy from [[Georgetown University]].<ref name="education"/>
==Career== Juhasz received grants in 2014-2015 and 2013-2014 from the Max & Anna Levinson Foundation <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.levinsonfoundation.org/?Recent_Grants/ |title=investigative journalism |publisher=Max & Anna Levinson Foundation |date= |accessdate=2015-05-05}}</ref> to support her ongoing work in investigative journalism in the oil and energy sectors with Media Alliance and the Investigative Reporting Program, respectively. Juhasz was a 2012-2013 Investigative Journalism Fellow at the Investigative Reporting Program,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://investigativereportingprogram.com/ |title=Investigative Reporting Program |publisher=Investigative Reporting Program |date= |accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref> a working news room at the Graduate School of Journalism at the [[University of California, Berkeley]]. She investigated the role of oil and natural gas in the [[Afghanistan]] war.
Juhasz is a contributing writer to ''[[Rolling Stone]]''<ref>[https://www.rollingstone.com/contributor/antonia-juhasz ''Rolling Stone'' profile]</ref> and ''[[Harper's Magazine|Harper's]]''<ref>[http://harpers.org/author/antoniajuhasz/ ''Harper's'' profile]</ref> magazines, among other outlets.
Juhasz is also a reporter with the Investigative Fund of The Nation Institute.<ref name="theinvestigativefund1">{{cite web|url=http://www.theinvestigativefund.org/reporters/antoniajuhasz/ |title=Antonia Juhasz |publisher=The Investigative Fund |date= |accessdate=2016-02-20}}</ref>
According to information at her website, Juhasz has taught at the [[New College of California]] in the Activism and Social Change Masters Program and as a guest lecturer on U.S. Foreign Policy at the [[McMaster University]] Labour Studies Program in a unique educational program with the Canadian Automobile Workers Union.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://antoniajuhasz.net/article.php?id=43 |title=The Bush Agenda : Biographical Information |publisher=Antonia Juhasz |date=2007-07-30 |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
As project director of the [[International Forum on Globalization]],<ref name="positions"/> in 1999 Juhasz worked to inform the public about the [[World Trade Organization]], an effort which helped build activism culminating in the [[1999 Seattle WTO protests]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ifg.org/news/cancun/st910.htm |accessdate=May 26, 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130606160843/http://www.ifg.org/news/cancun/st910.htm |archivedate=June 6, 2013 }}</ref>
Juhasz worked as a legislative assistant in Washington, DC, for two U.S. members of Congress: [[John Conyers, Jr.]] (D-MI) and [[Elijah E. Cummings]] (D-MD).<ref name="positions"/>
;Other positions {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * Founder and former Director of the Energy Program at [[Global Exchange]]<ref name="positions">[http://www.tyrannyofoil.org/article.php?id=43 Current or Past Positions Held by Juhasz] {{Primary source inline|date=June 2013}} {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110115035402/http://www.tyrannyofoil.org/article.php?id=43 |date=January 15, 2011 }}</ref> * National Advisory Board Member, [[Iraq Veterans Against the War]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ivaw.org/about/advisory-committee |title=Advisory Committee | Iraq Veterans Against the War |publisher=Ivaw.org |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * Board Member, GI Voice/ [[Coffee Strong]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.coffeestrong.org/about/ |title=About |publisher=Coffee Strong |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref> * Senior Policy Analyst, [[Foreign Policy in Focus]]<ref name="positions"/> * Associate Fellow, [[Institute for Policy Studies]]<ref name="positions"/> * Fellow, Oil Change International<ref name="positions"/> * Director, International Trade Program, American Lands Alliance<ref name="positions"/> {{div col end}}
== Writing ==
===Books=== Juhasz is the author of three books. She wrote ''The Bush Agenda: Invading the World One Economy at a Time'' in 2006. ''[[The Georgia Straight]]'' of Canada said it was "One of the crispest, most insightful books yet to expose the Bush regime."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.straight.com/life/buh-agenda |author=Straight.com |title=The Bu$h Agenda | Georgia Straight, Vancouver's News & Entertainment Weekly |date=August 3, 2006 |accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref>
Juhasz's ''The Tyranny of Oil: the World's Most Powerful Industry and What We Must Do To Stop It'' ([[HarperCollins]] 2008) received the 2009 San Francisco Library Laureate Award. ''[[USA Today]]'' wrote, Juhasz "reminds us that those who don't learn the lessons of history are fated to repeat its mistakes."<ref>{{cite news| url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/money/books/reviews/2009-01-04-book-tyranny-of-oil_N.htm | work=[[USA Today]] | first=Russ | last=Juskalian | title=Timing of oil price collapse dulls 'Tyranny's' point | date=21 January 2009}}</ref> ''[[Kirkus Reviews]]'' finds it a "timely, blistering critique... white-hot... Explosive fuel for the raging debate on oil prices."<ref>{{cite web|last=Coyne |first=Amanda |url=https://www.kirkusreviews.com/book-reviews/antonia-juhasz/the-tyranny-of-oil/ |title=THE TYRANNY OF OIL by Antonia Juhasz | Kirkus |publisher=Kirkusreviews.com |date=2008-10-07 |accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref>
Her 2011 book, ''Black Tide: the Devastating Impact of the Gulf Oil Spill'' examined the human impact of the [[Deepwater Horizon oil spill]]. It was praised by ''[[Ms. (magazine)|Ms.]]'', which called it "masterfully reported,"<ref>{{cite web|last=Shank |first=Megan |date=April 20, 2011|url=http://msmagazine.com/blog/2011/04/20/black-tide-women-and-the-gulf-oil-spill-one-year-later/ |title=Women and the Gulf Oil Spill, One Year Later |publisher=Msmagazine.com |accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref> and ''[[Mother Jones (magazine)|Mother Jones]]'', which said the writing was "both engaging and informative."<ref>{{cite web|last=Sheppard |first=Kate |url=https://www.motherjones.com/blue-marble/2011/04/deepwater-horizon-disaster-book-form |title=The Deepwater Horizon Disaster in Book Form |publisher=Mother Jones |date= April 22, 2011|accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref>
===Book Chapters=== Juhasz wrote the essay, "Oil and Water," for the book, ''Unfathomable City: A New Orleans Atlas'', Rebecca Solnit and Rebecca Snedeker, editors (University of California Press, November 2013).
Juhasz wrote the essay, "Roasted Corn Broth with Chunky Pea Guacamole," in the book, ''Ingredients for Peace: Cooking with Global Peacemakers'', Nobel Peace Prize Laureate Jody Williams and Emily Goose, editors (Lulu.com Publishers, February 2010).
Juhasz wrote Chapter 12 "Global Uprising: The Web of Resistance," in the book, A ''Game As Old As Empire: The Secret World of Economic Hit Men and the Web of Global Corruption'', Steven Hiatt, editor (Berrett-Koehler Publishers, February 2007).
Juhasz wrote the essay, "Global Water Wars," in the book, ''Paradigm Wars: Indigenous Peoples' Resistance to Globalization'', Jerry Mander and Victoria Tauli-Corpuz, editors (Sierra Club Books, 2006).
Juhasz is a contributing author to the book ''Alternatives to Economic Globalization: A Better World is Possible'', Jerry Mander and John Cavanagh, editors (Berrett-Koehler Publishers, October 2004).
=== Reports === Juhasz is the lead author and editor of ''The True Cost of Chevron: An Alternative Annual Report'', for which she received a 2010 Project Censored Award.<ref name=censored>{{cite web|url=http://www.projectcensored.org/top-stories/articles/the-true-cost-of-chevron/ |title=18. The True Cost of Chevron – Top 25 of 2011 |publisher=Projectcensored.org |date= |accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref>
===Journalism===
Publications carrying her work have included ''[[The New York Times]]'', ''[[The Washington Post]]'', the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'',<ref>[http://www.latimes.com/news/opinion/la-oe-juhasz8dec08,0,4717508.story?coll=la-opinion-rightrail "It's Still about Oil"]</ref> [[Democracy Now!]],<ref>[http://www.democracynow.org/article.pl?sid=07/02/20/1523250 Democracy Now]</ref> [[National Public Radio|NPR]], and ''Cambridge University International Relations Journal''.<ref>[http://www.thebushagenda.net/article.php?id=43 TheBushAgenda.net]</ref> She was the object of a [[Terry Gross]] interview<ref>[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=95465269 Interview] on [[Fresh Air]], Oct. 7, 2008]</ref> about ''The Tyranny of Oil''.<ref>[http://www.harpercollins.com/authors/30015/Antonia_Juhasz/index.aspx HarperCollins profile]</ref><ref>[http://www.fpif.org/ Foreign Policy in Focus]</ref><ref>[http://www.thetyrannyofoil.org/ ''The Tyranny of Oil'']</ref><ref>[https://archive.org/details/sglTheTyrannyofOil Link to recording of Antonia Juhasz] talking about ''The Tyranny of Oil'' at Davis, CA</ref><ref>[http://video.google.com/videoplay?docid=7168833640158365477&hl=en VIDEO: The Tyranny of Oil], talk by Antonia Juhasz at Powell's Books in Portland, Oregon, on October 27, 2008, from her recent book tour.</ref>
According to her [[Linkedin]] report, other publications in which Juhasz's work has appeared include the ''[[International Herald Tribune]]'', ''[[Rolling Stone]]'', ''[[The Atlantic]]'', ''[[Harper's Magazine]]'', ''[[The Nation]]'', ''[[Miami Herald]]'', [[CNN.com]], ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'', ''[[Petroleum Review]]'' magazine, ''[[In These Times]]'', ''Cambridge University Review of International Relations Journal'', ''[[Roll Call]]'', ''The Daily Mirror'' (Zimbabwe), ''[[The Star (South Africa)|The Star]]'' (Johannesburg), ''[[Multinational Monitor]]'', ''[[Tikkun (magazine)|Tikkun]]'', ''LeftTurn'', [[AlterNet]], ''[[The Huffington Post]]'', and [[TomPaine.com]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.linkedin.com/pub/antonia-juhasz/8/639/21a |title=Antonia Juhasz |publisher=LinkedIn |date= |accessdate=2014-06-04}}</ref>
Juhasz regularly provides media commentary. She was featured in the [[CNBC]] documentary ''The Hunt for Black Gold'', and has appeared in shows including [[MSNBC]], BBC TV and radio, ''Kudlow & Company'', ''The Business Hour with [[Neil P. Cavuto]]'', ''[[Hannity & Colmes]]'', [[C-Span]]'s ''[[Book TV]]'' and ''[[Washington Journal]]'', ''[[The Diane Rehm Show]]'', ''[[Talk of the Nation]]'', ''[[To the Point]]'', ''Marketplace'', ''[[Bloomberg Radio News]]'', [[Air America (radio network)|Air America]], and [[Pacifica radio]], among many others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.projectcensored.org/lectures/lecture121108/ |title=Lecture #10 |publisher=Projectcensored.org |date=2009-03-13 |accessdate=2014-05-28}}</ref>
==Activism==
Juhasz provided testimony at the [[Iraq Veterans Against the War]]—[[Winter Soldier: Iraq & Afghanistan]] in [[Silver Spring, Maryland]] in March 2008; at the Citizens Hearing on the Legality of U.S. Actions in Iraq in support of Lt. [[Ehren Watada]] in [[Tacoma, Washington]], in January 2007; and to the New York Session of the [[World Tribunal on Iraq]] in May 2004.
On 26 May 2010, Antonia Juhasz was removed from the [[Chevron Corporation]] shareholders' meeting in [[Houston]] and then arrested outside the meeting venue.<ref name=wsj290910/><ref name=democracynow280510>{{Cite news | url= http://www.democracynow.org/2010/5/28/chevron_has_5_activists_arrested_and |title= Chevron Has 5 Activists Arrested and Bars Entry to Global Victims of Its Practices at Annual Shareholders' Meeting | work = [[Democracy Now!]] | date=28 May 2010 | accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=huffington280910>{{Cite web | url= http://www.huffingtonpost.com/antonia-juhasz/chevron-throws-book-at-sh_b_742488.html | first = Antonia | last = Juhasz |title= Chevron Throws Book at Shareholder Activist (Me) | work = [[Huffington Post]] | date=28 September 2010 | accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref><ref name=marketwatch280910>{{Cite news | url= http://www.marketwatch.com/story/chevron-throws-book-at-shareholder-2010-09-28 | first = John | last = Letzing |title= Chevron shareholder activist faces jail time | work = [[MarketWatch]] | date=28 September 2010 | accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref> According to people at the meeting, this happened after Juhasz blasted Chevron's environmental record and then together with a few other activists, for several minutes chanted "Chevron lies".<ref name=marketwatch280910/><ref name=reuters280910>{{Cite news | url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/2010/05/26/uk-oil-rig-chevron-idUKTRE64P5K120100526 | first = Braden | last = Reddall |title= Chevron CEO says industry to learn from BP leak | work = [[Reuters]] | date=26 May 2010 | accessdate=9 June 2013}}</ref> According to Juhasz, she was charged with criminal trespass and disrupting a meeting, and was incarcerated for a twenty-four-hour period.<ref name=democracynow280510/>
Project Censored awarded Juhasz Top 25 in 2005 for "Ambitions of Empire: The Radical Reconstruction of Iraq's Economy".<ref>[http://www.projectcensored.org/top-stories/articles/17-us-government-represses-labor-unions-in-iraq-in-quest-for-business/ Project Censored Award],</ref> In 2007 [[Peace Action]] placed Juhasz on their Women Peacemakers Honor Roll, "For women who have made a unique and lasting contribution to work for peace and justice in the world."{{Citation needed|date=August 2015}}

revision.text:
{{Conservatism US}} {{Lead missing|date=April 2018}} ==Voting trends== From the 1940s to the 1990s most Asian Americans were anti-communist refugees who had fled mainland China, North Korea or Vietnam, and were strongly anti-Communist. Many had ties to conservative organizations.William Wei, ''The Asian American movement'' (1993) pp 16, 226, 274 In recent years, more liberal Asian-American groups such as newer Chinese and Indian immigrants have greatly changed the Asian-American political demographics, as well as a larger proportion of younger Asian Americans, many of whom have completed college degrees.William Wei, ''The Asian American movement'' (1993) pp 170, 274 During the 1990s and 2000s, Asian American voting behavior shifted from moderate support for the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] to stronger support for the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]].{{Cite news|url=http://prospect.org/article/how-asian-americans-became-democrats-0|title=How Asian Americans Became Democrats|newspaper=The American Prospect|access-date=2016-10-22}} In the [[1992 United States Presidential Election|1992 presidential election]] Republican [[George H. W. Bush]] received 55% of the Asian-American vote compared to 31% for Democrat [[Bill Clinton]]. Asian Americans voted Republican and were the only racial group more conservative than whites in the 1990s, according to surveys.Jeffrey D. Schultz, ed., ''Encyclopedia of Minorities in American Politics'' (2000) Volume 1 pp 261-62 By the [[United States presidential election, 2004|2004 election]], Democrat [[John Kerry]] won 56% of the Asian American vote, with Chinese and Indian Americans tending to support Kerry, and Vietnamese and Filipino Americans tending to support [[George W. Bush|George Bush]].Jim Lobe, [http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Front_Page/FI16Aa01.html Asian-Americans lean toward Kerry] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20080919024923/http://www.atimes.com/atimes/Front_Page/FI16Aa01.html |date=19 September 2008 }}, Asia Times. September 16, 2004. Japanese-Americans leaned towards Kerry, while Korean-Americans leaned towards Bush. Democrat [[Barack Obama]] won 62% of the Asian American vote in the [[2008 U.S. Presidential Election|2008 presidential election]],''[http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2004/pages/results/states/US/P/00/epolls.0.html Election results, America Votes 2004]'', CNN;
^ ''[http://www.cnn.com/ELECTION/2008/results/polls/#USP00p1 Exit Polls]'', CNN. with the margin increasing during the [[United States presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]], where Asian Americans voted to re-elect Obama by 73%.{{cite web|url=http://www.voanews.com/content/exit-polls-show-asian-americans-backed-obama-by-wide-margin/1540974.html|title=Exit Polls Show Asian Americans Backed Obama by Wide Margin|publisher=[[Voice of America]]|author=Hilburn, Matthew|date=2012-11-07|accessdate=2012-11-10}} In the [[United States elections, 2014|2014 midterm elections]], based on exit polls, 50% of Asian Americans voted Republican, while 49% voted Democrat; this swing towards voting for Republicans was a shift from the strong Democratic vote in 2012, and had not reached 50% since 1996.{{cite news |last=McLaughlin |first=Seth |date=9 November 2014 |title=GOP makes big inroads with Asian voters in midterms |url=http://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2014/nov/9/asian-vote-breaks-for-republicans-in-midterms/?page=all |newspaper=Washington Times |access-date=13 March 2015 }} The 2016 [[National Asian American Survey]], conducted before the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 presidential election]], found that 55% of Asian American registered voters supported Democratic candidate [[Hillary Clinton]] and only 14% supported Republican candidate [[Donald Trump]].{{Cite web|url=http://naasurvey.com/wp-content/uploads/2016/10/NAAS2016-Oct5-report.pdf|title=Report on Registered Voters in the Fall 2016 National Asian American Survey|last=Ramakrishnan|first=Karthick|last2=Wong|first2=Janelle|date=2016-10-05|website=|publisher=National Asian American Survey|access-date=2016-10-05|last3=Lee|first3=Taeku|last4=Lee|first4=Jennifer}} Despite their growing trend of voting for Democrats in national elections, Asian Americans have tended to identify as independents and have not developed strong ties to political parties as a group.{{Cite web|url=http://press.princeton.edu/titles/9468.html|title=Hajnal, Z.L. and Lee, T.: Why Americans Don't Join the Party: Race, Immigration, and the Failure (of Political Parties) to Engage the Electorate. (eBook and Paperback)|website=press.princeton.edu|access-date=2016-10-22}} Due to the smaller size of the groups population, in comparison to the population as a whole, it has been difficult to get an adequate sampling to forecast voter outcomes for Asian Americans.{{cite web |last=Lee |first=Taeku |title=Asian Americans and the Electorate |url=http://www.apsanet.org/content_5154.cfm |work= |publisher=American Political Science Association |accessdate=23 August 2009}} In 2008, polls indicated that 35% considered themselves [[non-partisan]], 32% Democrats, 19% [[Independent (politician)#United States|independents]], and 14% Republicans.{{cite news|first=Rex |last=Feng |authorlink= |title=Who Is The Asian American Voter? |url=http://www.asianweek.com/2008/10/24/who-is-the-asian-american-voter/ |work= |publisher=AsianWeek |date=24 October 2008 |accessdate=23 August 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090209220954/http://www.asianweek.com/2008/10/24/who-is-the-asian-american-voter/ |archivedate=9 February 2009 |df= }} The 2012 [[National Asian American Survey]] found that 51% considered themselves non-partisan, 33% Democrats, 14% Republicans, and 2% [[Third party (United States)|Other]];{{cite news|title=Asian-American voters a force in November election |author=Jerry Large |url=http://seattletimes.com/html/jerrylarge/2019270993_jdl27.html |newspaper=Seattle Times |date=26 September 2012 |accessdate=19 November 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130116204829/http://seattletimes.com/html/jerrylarge/2019270993_jdl27.html |archivedate=16 January 2013 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://naasurvey.com/resources/Home/NAAS12-sep25-election.pdf |title=Public Opinion Of a Growing Electorate: Asian Americans and Pacific Islanders in 2012 |author=Karthick Ramakrishnan |author2=Taeku Lee |date=8 October 2012 |publisher=The National Asian American Survey |accessdate=19 November 2012}} [[Hmong American|Hmong]], Indian, and Korean Americans strongly identified as Democrats, and Filipino and Vietnamese Americans most strongly identified as Republicans. In 2013, according to the [[Asian American Legal Defense and Education Fund]], Chinese Americans were the least likely Asian American ethnicity to have a party affiliation, with only one third belonging to a party.{{cite news |title=Asian-American Vote Reveals Nuances |author=Matthew Hilburn |url=http://www.voanews.com/content/polling-asian-americans-nuanced/1586148.html |newspaper=Voice of America |date=17 January 2013 |accessdate=25 January 2013 |quote=Chinese-Americans were the least likely to affiliate with a party. Magpantay suggested that only one third of Chinese-Americans belong to a party, compared with 71 percent among all Asian-Americans, because of the negative association of the word party with the Communist Party in China. }} The 2016 National Asian American Survey found that 41% of Asian Americans identified as non-partisan, 41% as Democrats (a modest increase from 2008 and 2012), and 16% as Republicans. Neither the Republican nor Democratic parties have financed significant efforts to the registration of Asian Americans, however much more attention has been focused on contributions from Asian Americans,{{cite book |title=Encyclopedia of Asian American Issues Today, Volume 1 |last=Chen |first=Edith Wen-Chu |authorlink= |editor=Grace J. Yoo |year=2010 |publisher=ABC-CLIO |location= |isbn=978-0-313-34751-1 |page=722 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R_t3yQiWKQEC&lpg=PR3&ots=sPdK23bgeW&dq=%22filipino%20american%22%20voting%20republican&lr&pg=PA722#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate=19 March 2011}} having once been referred to as potential "Republican Jews".{{cite journal|last1=Cho |first1=Wendy K. Tam |last2= |first2= |year=2002 |title=Tapping Motives and Dynamics behind Campaign Contributions: Insights from the Asian American Case |journal=American Politics Research |volume=30 |issue=4 |pages=347–383 |publisher=SAGE Publications |doi=10.1177/1532673X02030004001 |url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/scholar?q=cache:JvwL7bLyXg8J:scholar.google.com/&hl=en&as_sdt=0,5 |accessdate=19 March 2011 }}{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} As recently as 2006, the outreach efforts of America's two major political parties have been unbalanced, with the Democratic Party devoting more resources in attracting Asian Americans.{{cite web|url=http://www.imdiversity.com/villages/asian/politics_law/ikeda_asian_republicans_1006.asp |title=Has the GOP Given Up on Asian Americans? |author=Stewart David Ikeda |work= |publisher=IMDiversity Inc. |accessdate=22 February 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101227073828/http://imdiversity.com/Villages/Asian/politics_law/ikeda_asian_republicans_1006.asp |archivedate=27 December 2010 |df= }} In 2016, a majority of Asian-Americans possessed the same political views on racial profiling, education, social security, and immigration reform as the Democratic Party; the efforts to attract Asian-Americans has produced a proportionally significant growth in Democratic affiliation by Asian-Americans from 2012 to 2016 by 12 percent.{{Cite web|url=http://www.apiavote.org/sites/apiavote/files/Inclusion-2016-AAVS-final.pdf|title=Inclusion, Not Exclusion|last=|first=|date=May 22, 2016|website=apiavote.org|publisher=Asian-American Voter Survey(AAVS)|access-date=September 29, 2016}} Political affiliation aside, Asian Americans have trended to become more politically active as a whole, with 2008 seeing an increase of voter participation by 4% to a 49% voting rate.{{cite news |first=Tom |last=Edwards |authorlink= |title=Voter Turnout Increases by 5 Million in 2008 Presidential Election |url=https://www.census.gov/newsroom/releases/archives/voting/cb09-110.html |work=U.S. Census Bureau News |publisher=U.S. Department of Commerce |date=20 July 2009 |accessdate=2010-07-26 |archiveurl=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20101020013217/http%3A//www%2Ecensus%2Egov/newsroom/releases/archives/voting/cb09%2D110%2Ehtml# |archivedate=2010-10-20 |deadurl=yes |df= }} ==Timeline of events== This is a timeline of significant events in Asian history which have shaped the conservative movement in the United States. ; 1900's * 1903 - [[Jonah Kūhiō Kalanianaʻole]] elected as Delegate to the [[United States House of Representatives|U.S. House of Representatives]] from [[Hawaii Territory]]'s [[Hawaii Territory's at-large congressional district|At-large district]] ; 1920s * 1927 - [[Victor S. The '''Automated System for Customs Data''' (ASYCUDA) is a [[compute]]rized system designed by the [[United Nations Conference on Trade and Development]] (UNCTAD) to administer a country's customs. In 2004 there were more than 50 operational projects with expenditures exceeding US$7 million. It is the largest [[technical cooperation]] programme of the UNCTAD, covering over 80 countries and 4 regional projects.
There are three generations of ASYCUDA in use: ASYCUDA version 2.7, ASYCUDA++ <ref>[https://asycuda.org/pdf%20docs/sffunct.pdf Asycuda ++]</ref> and ASYCUDA World. They were built using different paradigms and [[solution]]s available at conception.{{what|date=May 2014}} ASYCUDA World is the most recent version. [[Cape Verde]] adopted use of ASYCUDA World in January 2016.<ref>[http://www.asycuda.org/wnfiles/CAPVERT-Article-GB.pdf Official ASYCUDA World Launch ceremony in Cap Verde], 12 January 2016, accessed 1 February 2017</ref>
UNCTAD's aim was to build a computer system to assist customs authorities (or their local equivalents) all over the world to automate and control their core processes and obtain timely, accurate and valuable information to support government projections and planning.
==References== {{reflist}}

'''Benjamin Franklin's phonetic alphabet''' was [[Benjamin Franklin]]'s proposal for a [[English spelling reform|spelling reform]] of the [[English language]]. The alphabet was based on the [[Latin alphabet]] used in English. Franklin modified the standard English alphabet by omitting the letters c, j, q, w, x, and y, and adding new letters to explicitly represent the open-mid back [[Open-mid back rounded vowel|rounded]] and [[Open-mid back unrounded vowel|unrounded]] vowels, and the consonants sh, ng, voiced th, and voiceless th. It was one of the earlier proposed spelling reforms to the English language. The alphabet consisted of 26 letters in the following order:Franklin, Benjamin. [https://archive.org/stream/politicalmiscell00franrich#page/466/mode/2up A Reformed Mode of Spelling]. In [https://archive.org/stream/politicalmiscell00franrich#page/n5/mode/2up Political, Miscellaneous, and Philosophical Pieces], pages 467-478. ''{{serif|m}}'' |- ! style="text-align:left" | Letter name | ''b || ''pi || ''em |- ! style="text-align:left" | Pronunciation ([[Help:IPA/Latin|IPA]]) | {{IPA|/b/}} || {{IPA|/p/}} || {{IPA|/m/}} |} Other English phonemes are represented as follows: *{{IPAc-en|hw}} is represented as ''hu'' (as in ''huɥi'' for ''why''). *{{IPAc-en|aɪ}} is represented as ''ɥi'' (as in ''ɥiz'' for ''eyes''). *{{IPAc-en|aʊ}} is represented ''cɩu'' (as in ''hcɩus'' for ''house''). *{{IPAc-en|dʒ}} is represented ''dի'' (as in ''edի'' for ''age''). *{{IPAc-en|eɪ}}, at the time more probably {{IPA|[eː~ɛː]}}, is represented as ''ee'' or ''e'' (as in ''leet'' for ''late'' or ''kes'' for ''case''). *{{IPAc-en|ɛər}} is represented as ''eer'' (as in ''keer'' for ''care'' or ''᷄ⱨeer'' for ''their''). *{{IPAc-en|ɜr}} and {{IPAc-en|ər}} are represented as ''ɥr'' (as ''lɥrn'' for ''learn''). *{{IPAc-en|iː}} is represented as ''ii'' or ''i'' (as in ''ſtriim'' for ''stream''). *{{IPAc-en|ɔɪ}} is represented ''cɩɥi'' (as in ''distrcɩɥi'' for ''destroy''). *{{IPAc-en|ɔr}} is represented ''cɩr'' (as in ''fcɩrget'' for ''forget''). **{{IPAc-en|oʊ|r}}, at the time [[horse-hoarse merger|separate]], is represented ''or'' (as in ''kors'' for ''course''). *{{IPAc-en|tʃ}} is represented ''tի'' (as in ''tիit'' for ''cheat''). *{{IPAc-en|ʒ}} is represented ''zի'' (as in ''mezիɥr'' for ''measure''). *Unstressed vowels are generally represented by the letters used to represent their stressed equivalents. What today is considered a [[schwa]] is mostly represented with ''ɥ'', although whenever spelled in standard English with ''a'', Franklin maintains the symbol ''a''. [[File:Franklin's extra letters.jpg|thumb|400px|{{large|{{IPAc-en|ɔː}}.....{{IPAc-en|ʌ}}.....{{IPAc-en|ŋ}}.....{{IPAc-en|ð}}.....{{IPAc-en|θ}}.....{{IPAc-en|ʃ}}}}; The phonemes immediately above provide the sounds in IPA of the extra symbols (above them) which Franklin devised for his phonetic alphabet.]] [[File:Benjamin Franklin's alphabet - sample letter.png|thumb|340px|Sample text in Franklin's phonetic alphabet from a letter to Franklin.]] ==Vowels== Franklin's proposed alphabet included seven letters to represent vowels. This set consisted of two new letters, in addition to five letters from the existing English alphabet: a, e, i, o, u. The first new letter was a formed as a ligature of the letters o and a, and used to represent the sound {{IPAblink|ɔ}} (as written in [[International Phonetic Alphabet|IPA]]). The second, ɥ, was used for {{IPAblink|ʌ}}. Franklin proposed the use of doubled letters to represent what he called long vowels, represented by modern phonemes thus: {{IPAc-en|ɔː}} as the long-vowel variant for {{IPAc-en|ɒ}} (or, in his notation, ''cɩcɩ'' versus ''cɩ''), {{IPAc-en|eɪ}} for {{IPAc-en|ɛ}} (''ee'' versus ''e''), and {{IPAc-en|iː}} for {{IPAc-en|ɪ}} (''ii'' versus ''i''). However, these distinctions appear not perfectly identical to the distinctions today; for example, the only word shown to use ''cɩcɩ'' is the word ''all'', but not other words that in modern notation would use {{IPA|/ɔː/}}. This discrepancy may reflect Franklin's own inconsistencies, but, even more likely, it reflects legitimate differences in the English phonology of his particular time and place. In his examples of writing in the proposed alphabet, Franklin contrasts long and short uses of his letter e, with the words "mend" and "remain," respectively spelled in Franklin's system as "mend" and "remeen." In this system, the doubled "ee" is used to represent the {{IPA|/eɪ/}} sound in "late" and "pale." Likewise, "ii" is used to represent the {{IPA|/iː/}} sound in "degrees", "pleased", and "serene." One of Franklin's correspondences written in the new alphabet[https://archive.org/stream/politicalmiscell00franrich#page/473/mode/1up Letter from Benjamin Franklin], dated 28 Sept 1768, reprinted in Franklin, Benjamin. [https://archive.org/stream/politicalmiscell00franrich#page/466/mode/2up A Reformed Mode of Spelling]. In [https://archive.org/stream/politicalmiscell00franrich#page/n5/mode/2up Political, Miscellaneous, and Philosophical Pieces], pages 467-478. London, 1779. is inconsistent in this regard, representing the {{IPA|/eɪ/}} sound in "great" and "compared" with the accented letter "ê" instead of "ee". Franklin does not appear to make a distinction between the modern {{IPAc-en|uː}} and {{IPAc-en|ʊ}} [[phoneme]]s, which likely reveals another difference between eighteenth-century English pronunciation versus modern pronunciation. ==Consonants== Franklin's proposed alphabet included nineteen letters to represent consonants. This set consisted of four new letters, in addition to fifteen letters from the existing English alphabet: b, d, f, g, h, k, l, m, n, p, r, s, t, v, z. New letters were proposed to replace the English [[digraph (orthography)|digraph]]s ng, sh, [[Voiced dental fricative|voiced th]], and [[Voiceless dental fricative|voiceless th]]. New consonant digraphs based on these new letters were used to represent the [[affricate]] sounds of ch in cherry and j in January. The most influential of Franklin's six new characters appears to have been the letter eng, {{IPA link|ŋ|<}}, for "ng". It was later incorporated into the IPA. [[Alexander Gill the Elder]] had used this letter in 1619.The Cambridge Encyclopedia of the English Language, David Crystal ==References== ==External links== *[http://www.omniglot.com/writing/franklin.htm Article on Omniglot] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20060220083609/http://www.historycarper.com/resources/twobf3/phonetic.htm Franklin writing about his alphabet] *[http://stbride.org/friends/conference/temporarytype/sixnewletters Six New Letters for a Renovated Alphabet], Nicola Twilley and [[Geoff Manaugh]], a talk given at the Friends of St Bride conference, Temporary Type, London, 10–12 October 2005 *[http://blogs.smithsonianmag.com/design/2013/05/benjamin-franklins-phonetic-alphabet/ Benjamin Franklin’s Phonetic Alphabet] at Smithsonian.com, 10 May 2013 {{DEFAULTSORT:Benjamin Franklin's Phonetic Alphabet}} [[Category:Benjamin Franklin]] [[Category:English spelling reform]] [[Category:Phonetic alphabets]]

The British '''Atomic Scientists Association''' ('''ASA''' or '''BASA'''), was founded by [[Joseph Rotblat]] in 1946.
It was a politically neutral group, composed of eminent physicists and other scientists and was concerned with matters of British public policy regarding applications and dangers of nuclear physics (including [[nuclear weapons]] and [[nuclear power]]).
In so doing it also sought to inform fellow scientists and the public of the essential facts, usually via published papers and other documents.
== Members == The vice-president (VP) was the executive head while the president (P) was the honorary position.
* [[Kathleen Lonsdale]] (VP, P 1967) * [[Harrie Massey]] * [[Nevill Mott]] * Joseph Rotblat (VP 1946) * [[Basil Schonland]]
