[[Delaware]], [[United States|U.S.]] | location = [[San Francisco]], [[California]], U.S. | homepage = {{URL|change.org}} }} '''Change.org''' is a [[online petition|petition]] website operated by for-profit Change.org, Inc., an American [[B Corporation (certification)|certified B corporation]]{{cite web|url=http://www.bcorporation.net/change.org |title=Change.org |publisher=B Corporation |date= |accessdate=2016-11-13}} which claims to have over 240 million users{{cite web|url=http://www.thenonprofittimes.com/news-articles/change-org-gets-30-million-infusion/|title=Change.Org Gets 30 Million Infusion|last=|first=|date=|website=The Non Profit Times|publisher=thenonprofittimes.com|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=23 June 2015}} and hosts sponsored campaigns for organizations. The company is headquartered in San Francisco, California.{{Cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/living/article/Ben-Rattray-and-Change-org-3781962.php|title=Ben Rattray and Change.org|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} The website serves to facilitate petitions by the general public.{{Cite web|url=http://money.cnn.com/2014/12/09/technology/change-org-25-million-investors/|title=Change.org gets $25 million from big names|last=|first=|date=|website=|access-date=}} Previously corporations including [[Virgin America]],{{cite web|url=http://storage.pardot.com/37772/47364/Change.org_Virgin_America.pdf|title=Virgin America found brand advocates to enter a new market}} and organizations such as [[Amnesty International]] and the [[Humane Society of the United States|Humane Society]], paid the site to host and promote their petitions.{{cite news|last=Alter|first=Jonathan|title=For Change.org, a Better World Is Clicks Away|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2012-03-09/for-change-org-better-world-is-clicks-away-commentary-by-jonathan-alter.html|publisher=Bloomberg}} Change.org's stated mission is to "empower people everywhere to create the change they want to see."{{cite news|last=Farr|first=Christina|title=Change.org CEO shows how coral should get her tits out change the face of health care (Q&A)|url=https://venturebeat.com/2013/05/17/change-org-health-petitions/|accessdate=7 October 2013|newspaper=VentureBeat|date=17 May 2013}} Popular topics of Change.org petitions are economic and criminal [[justice]], [[human rights]], [[education]], [[environmental protection]], [[animals rights]], [[health]], and [[Sustainability|sustainable food]]. ==History== Change.org was launched on May 28, 2002,{{cite web|url = https://techcrunch.com/2007/02/07/social-networking-for-change/|title = Social Networking For Change(.org)|author = Gonzalez, Nick|publisher = [[TechCrunch]]|date = February 7, 2007}} by current chief executive [[Ben Rattray]], with the support of founding [[chief technology officer]] Mark Dimas, Darren Haas,{{cite news|url=https://techcrunch.com/2007/02/07/social-networking-for-change/|title=Social Networking For Change(.org)|first=Vince|last=Veneziani|publisher=[[TechCrunch]]|date= February 7, 2007|accessdate= December 10, 2011}} and [[Adam Cheyer]]. As of February 2012, the site had 100 employees with offices on four continents. By the end of 2012, Rattray stated "he plans to have offices in 20 countries and to operate in several more languages, including Arabic and Chinese."{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/05/opinion/sunday/kristof-after-recess-change-the-world.html?_r=1|title = 'After Recess - Change the World'|author = [[Nicholas Kristof|Kristof, Nicholas]]| work = [[The New York Times]]|date = February 4, 2012}} In May 2013, the company announced a $15 million round of investment led by Omidyar Network and said it has 170 staff members in 18 countries.{{cite news|last=Empson|first=Rick|title=With $15M From Omidyar And 35M+ Users, Change.org Wants To Prove Socially-Minded Startups Can Attract Big Numbers|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/05/21/with-15m-from-omidyar-and-35m-users-change-org-wants-to-prove-socially-minded-business-can-attract-big-numbers/|accessdate=1 July 2013|newspaper=TechCrunch|date=21 May 2013}} In 2011, Change.org claimed it was the subject of a [[distributed denial of service]] attack by "Chinese hackers",{{cite news|last=Branigan|first=Tania|title=Ai Weiwei campaign website 'victim of Chinese hackers'|url=https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/2011/apr/20/ai-weiwei-campaign-website-chinese-hackers|work = [[The Guardian]] |date=April 20, 2011|location=London}} and that the alleged attack was apparently related to its petition to the [[government of China|Chinese government]] to release artist [[Ai Weiwei]].{{cite web|last=Joffe-Walt|first=Benjamin|title=Chinese Hackers Attack Change.org Platform in Reaction to Ai Weiwei Campaign|url=http://blog.change.org/2011/04/chinese-hackers-attack-change-org-platform-in-reaction-to-ai-weiwei-campaign/|publisher=Change.org}} In 2011, there was a proposal to merge the Spanish-speaking counterpart website ''Actuable'' into ''Change.org''. It took place in 2012 when they approved the voluntary union of ''Actuable'' users into the ''Change.org'' platform.{{cite web |url=http://www.publico.es/ciencias/397493/actuable-se-fusiona-con-change-org-y-crean-la-mayor-plataforma-de-ciberactivismo-online |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-24 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120228184822/http://www.publico.es/ciencias/397493/actuable-se-fusiona-con-change-org-y-crean-la-mayor-plataforma-de-ciberactivismo-online |archivedate=2012-02-28 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://tecnologia.elpais.com/tecnologia/2011/09/20/actualidad/1316509269_850215.html |title=Change.org adquiere la española Actuable | Tecnología | EL PAÍS |publisher=Tecnologia.elpais.com |date=2011-09-20 |accessdate=2016-11-13}} In 2012, [[Arizona State University]] decided to block access to Change.org in response to a petition created by student Eric Haywood protesting "rising tuition costs at the school". University officials claimed that "Change.org is a spam site" and the blocking was conducted "to protect the use of our limited and valuable network resources for legitimate academic, research, and administrative uses".{{cite news|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/josh-levy/arizona-state-censors-cha_b_1253155.html|title = Arizona State Censors Change.org|author = Levy, Josh | work = [[The Huffington Post]] |date = February 3, 2012}} It was reported on April 5, 2012, that Change.org hit 10 million members, and was the fastest-growing social action platform on the web. At that time, they were receiving 500 new petitions per day.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/04/05/change-org-hits-10-million-members-now-the-fastest-growing-social-action-platform-on-the-web |title=Change.org Hits 10 Million Members, Now The "Fastest-Growing Social Action Platform On The Web" |publisher=TechCrunch |date=2012-04-05 |accessdate=2016-11-13}} On May 13, 2012, ''[[The Guardian]]'', [[BBC News]] and other sources reported that Change.org would launch a UK-specific platform for petitions, placing Change.org in competition with [[38 Degrees]],{{cite news|url = https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2012/may/14/trayvon-epetition-website-changeorg-launches-uk|title = Trayvon Martin petition site Change.org comes to UK| work = [[The Guardian]]|author = Topping, Alexandra |date = May 13, 2012|location=London}}{{cite news|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-18033968|title = Change.org petition site targets UK campaigners|author = Kelion, Leo|date = May 14, 2012|publisher = BBC News}} a British not-for-profit political-activism organization. An August 2013 ''[[Fast Company (magazine)|Fast Company]]'s'' article reported that Change.org would soon begin featuring petition recipients, saying, "For the first time, companies will be able to post a public response to any given petition (currently, they can only respond to the person who started the campaign). They will also be able to create their own Decision Maker page, which will show all petitions against them, the number of signatures gathered, and their statuses." {{cite news|last=Bluestein|first=Adam|title=HOW BEN RATTRAY'S CHANGE.ORG BECAME A VIRAL CONSUMER WATCHDOG|url=http://www.fastcompany.com/3014809/change-org-petitions-ben-rattray|accessdate=7 October 2013|newspaper=Fast Company|date=5 August 2013}} In summer 2017, a petition on change.org called for [[/r/incels]] (incel named after an abbreviation for "[[inceldom|involuntary celibate]]") to be banned for inciting violence against women.{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/11/09/technology/incels-reddit-banned.html|title=Reddit Bans 'Incel' Group for Inciting Violence Against Women|last=Hauser|first=Christine|date=2017-11-09|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-11-12|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}} ==Notable petitions== ===In Brazil=== On November 12th, 2018, a petition entitled “Contra o aumento de salário aos ministros do STF” exceed the record of signatures with 2,6 million. Much more than "Aprovem o Pedido de Impeachment da Presidente Dilma" with 2,23 million. ===In the United States=== On March 8, 2012, a petition entitled "Prosecute the killer of our son, 17-year-old [[Shooting of Trayvon Martin|Trayvon Martin]]" was posted on Change.org. The petition received over 2.2 million signatures – at that time the largest number of signatures for any campaign in Change.org's history.{{cite web|url = http://www.change.org/petitions/prosecute-the-killer-of-our-son-17-year-old-trayvon-martin|title = Prosecute the killer of our son, 17-year-old Trayvon Martin|publisher = Change.org}} The petition called for the prosecution of [[George Zimmerman]], a neighborhood watch volunteer, who, on February 26, 2012, shot and killed Trayvon Martin in [[Sanford, Florida|Sanford]], [[Florida]], a suburb of [[Orlando, Florida|Orlando]]. Zimmerman said he was acting in self-defense, and was set free without being charged. On April 11, 2012, Zimmerman was arrested and charged with second-degree murder. He stood trial in the months of June and July and was acquitted of all charges on July 13, 2013. On October 1, 2011, Molly Katchpole, a "22 year old nanny with two jobs" in [[Washington D.C.]], started a petition on Change.org "asking [[Bank of America]] and their CEO Bryan Moynihan to drop its unexpected new $5/month banking fee" for debit card customers. Less than one month later, 300,000 signatures were collected. The petition was widely cited as a contributing cause for the bank formally announcing to drop the new banking fee. [[President of the United States|U.S. President]] [[Barack Obama]] signed the petition; [[United States Senate|U.S. Senator]] [[Dick Durbin]], the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] [[senator from Illinois]], responded to Bank of America and the petition on [[Twitter]]. It may have contributed to the [[United States Congress|U.S. Congress]] deciding to "look at legislation for out-of-control banking fees".{{cite web|url = http://www.change.org/petitions/tell-bank-of-america-no-5-debit-card-fees|title = Tell Bank of America: No $5 Debit Card Fees|publisher = Change.org}} In December 2011, a fourth-grade class in [[Brookline, Massachusetts|Brookline]], [[Massachusetts]], launched the "Lorax Petition Project" through Change.org requesting [[Universal Studios]] to include more of an environmental message on its website and trailer for its upcoming film, ''[[The Lorax (film)|The Lorax]]'', a classic [[Dr. Seuss]] children's story. The website and trailer lacked the important message from the book, "to help the environment".{{cite web|url = http://www.change.org/petitions/z-let-the-lorax-speak-for-the-trees|title = 'Universal Pictures: Let the Lorax Speak for the Trees!'|publisher = Change.org}} The petition collected over 57,000 signatures, and on January 26, 2012, the studio updated the website "with the environmental message the kids had requested".{{cite news|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/05/opinion/sunday/kristof-after-recess-change-the-world.html?_r=1|title = After Recess - Change the World|author = [[Nicholas Kristof|Kristof, Nicholas]] | work = [[The New York Times]]|date = February 4, 2012}} On the morning of February 2, 2012, Stef Gray, a 23-year-old graduate in New York, held a news conference at the Washington offices of Sallie Mae where she presented the results of her Change.org, [[Sallie Mae]], the "nation's largest private student-loan provider" petition, which had received about 77,000 signers. That afternoon the company changed its forbearance fee policy.{{cite news|author= Lewin, Tamar|url = https://www.nytimes.com/2012/02/03/education/sallie-mae-to-change-forbearance-fee-policy.html?_r=3|title = Sallie Mae to Change Forebearance Fee Policy | work = [[The New York Times]]|date = February 2, 2012}} In November 2013, someone calling himself "[[John Doe]]" of [[Arlington, Texas]] launched a petition against changes made to the [[YouTube]] commenting system by [[Google]]. The changes force YouTube users to create an account on [[Google+]] and also removes the "reply" mechanism on comments unless they were posted on Google+. This petition received over 100,000 signatures in less than a week, and over 200,000 within two weeks.{{cite web|url=https://www.reddit.com/r/youtube/comments/1q92rm/google_change_the_youtube_comment_section_back_to/|publisher=Reddit|title=Change the Youtube comment section back to its original form|year=2013|accessdate=2015-09-30}} The petition garnered more than 241,000 signatures, but failed to change Google's stance on the matter. However, the changes to YouTube did not have the intended effect – namely, increasing spam instead of curbing it – and in mid-2015, the commenting system was altered to allow users to post comments without signing into Google+.{{cite news |url =https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/technology-33687110 |title =Google unlinking Google+ from YouTube|work =BBC News |location=London |date =July 28, 2015 |accessdate=July 29, 2015}} In November 2013, Aaron Thompson from [[Tuscaloosa, Alabama]] started a petition, directed at Seth MacFarlane to bring back Brian Griffin on the TV series ''[[Family Guy]]'', after he was briefly killed off in the Season 12 episode "[[Life of Brian (Family Guy)|Life Of Brian]]". Thompson's petition gained 30,000 signatures within 36 hours.{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/11/26/irate-family-guy-fans-strike-up-online-petition-to-bring-major-character-back-to-life-4202038/|title=Irate Family Guy fans strike up online petition to bring major character back to life|publisher=[[Metro.co.uk]]|last=Westbrook|first=Caroline|date=2013-11-26}}{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/11/27/disgruntled-family-guy-fans-petition-to-bring-major-character-back-to-life-tops-80000-signatures-4203996/|title=Disgruntled Family Guy fans' petition to bring major character back to life tops 80,000 signatures|publisher=Metro.co.uk|last=Duncan|first=Amy|date=2013-11-27}} The character was brought back to the show a few episodes later.{{cite web|url=http://metro.co.uk/2013/12/16/brian-griffin-back-from-the-dead-on-family-guy-after-stewie-comes-to-the-rescue-4232138/|title=Brian Griffin back from the dead on Family Guy after Stewie comes to the rescue|publisher=Metro.co.uk|last=Lee|first=Ann|date=2013-12-16}} In September 2014, Karol Wilcox of [[Hayti, Missouri]] started a petition against the planned execution of Beau, a two-and-a-half-year-old dog in [[Dyersburg, Tennessee]], for allegedly killing a duck on his owner's property. By November, this petition had gained over 540,000 signatures. The petition worked and the dog was spared.{{cite web|url=http://wreg.com/2015/01/30/beau-his-owner-could-be-reunited-this-afternoon/|title=Beau the dog and owner reunited|first1=Ashley|last1=Crockett|first2=Mike|last2=Suriani|publisher=WREG|date=2015-01-30|accessdate=2015-09-30}} After the [[United States presidential election, 2016|2016 United States presidential election]], in which [[Donald Trump]] was declared [[President-elect of the United States]], there were [[Protests against Donald Trump|mass protests]]. As part of these protests, one California man started a change.org petition on November 10, 2016, which called for electors in states that Trump won to become [[faithless elector]]s and cast their vote for [[Hillary Clinton]] instead at state [[Electoral College (United States)|Electoral College]] meetings. The petition acquired over 4 million signatures by November 14, 2016, only 4 days after it started.{{cite news|last1=Gore|first1=Leada|title=Popular vote totals for presidential race 2016: Clinton leading as last-ditch Electoral College efforts continue|url=http://www.al.com/news/index.ssf/2016/11/popular_vote_totals_for_presid_1.html|accessdate=November 14, 2016|work=AL.com|date=November 14, 2016}} By November 23, 2016, it had gotten 4.5 million signatures.{{cite news|last1=Chambers|first1=Fracesca|title=Petition with 4.5 MILLION signatures begs Electoral College voters to abandon Trump as Hillary's supporters make last-ditch effort to win her the presidency|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-3965060/Petition-begs-Electoral-College-voters-vote-Hillary-instead-Trump.html|accessdate=28 November 2016|agency=Daily Mail|date=23 November 2016}} The petition ultimately failed as, on December 19, 2016, Trump officially gained the presidency with 304 electors.{{cite web|title=Vote of Presidential Electors: December 19, 2016|url=http://www.270towin.com/live-2016-presidential-election-vote-of-electors/|website=270ToWin}} The petition closed with 4.9 million signatures,{{cite web | last=Mele | first=Christopher | title=Online Petitions Take Citizen Participation to New Levels. But Do They Work? | website=The New York Times | date=2016-12-28 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2016/12/28/us/online-petitions-activism.html | accessdate=2016-12-29}} the highest in change.org history to date.{{cite tweet|user=Change |number=804830023156953088|title=Our biggest. petition. ever. 4.6 million ask the electoral college to elect @HillaryClinton as president on Dec 19. |date=2 December 2016}} On November 3, 2017, following [[sexual assault]] claims made against actor [[Kevin Spacey]], [[Netflix]] fired the actor from, and stalled the production of, the sixth and final season of the television series in which Spacey had starred in on the network, ''[[House of Cards (U.S. TV series)|House of Cards]]''.{{cite web |url= http://www.hollywoodreporter.com/live-feed/netflix-officially-severs-ties-kevin-spacey-1054981 |title= Netflix Severs Ties With Kevin Spacey |first=Kate |last= Stanhope |work= Hollywood Reporter |date= November 3, 2017 |accessdate= November 4, 2017}}{{Cite web |url= http://www.latimes.com/business/hollywood/la-fi-ct-netflix-kevin-spacey-20171104-story.html |title= Netflix has a mess on its hands with the collapse of 'House of Cards' |work= Los Angeles Times |date= November 4, 2017 |author= David Ng, Meg James |accessdate= November 4, 2017}} Following Spacey's dismissal, a petition created on November 2, 2017, calling for Spacey to be replaced by actor [[Kevin James]] as a post-plastic surgery Frank Underwood began gaining a rapid number of supporters; this petition has gained media notability since its inception, gaining 50,000 supporters within eight days.{{cite web|url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/features/baltimore-insider-blog/bs-fe-cards-james-20171108-story.html|title=Paul Blart for president? Petition suggests replacing Kevin Spacey with Kevin James on 'House of Cards'|first=Chris|last=Kaltenbach|publisher=The Baltimore Sun|date=2017-11-08|accessdate=2018-04-15}}{{cite web|url=https://www.vice.com/en_us/article/wjg48m/more-than-30000-people-want-kevin-james-to-replace-spacey-on-house-of-cards-vgtrn|title=More Than 30,000 People Want Kevin James to Replace Spacey on 'House of Cards'|first=River|last=Donaghey|publisher=Vice|date=2017-11-07|accessdate=2018-04-15}}{{cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/entertainment/television/2017/11/08/kevin-james-should-replace-kevin-spacey-in-house-of-cards-petition-says.html|title=Kevin James should replace Kevin Spacey in House of Cards, petition says|first=Frank|last=Lovece|publisher=The Toronto Star|date=2017-11-08|accessdate=2018-04-15}} In wake of the [[Logan Paul suicide video controversy]], user "... - .- -.-- .- .-.. .. ...- ." ("stayalive" in [[Morse code]]) created a petition entitled “Delete Logan Paul’s YouTube Channel", having received more than 520,000 signatures as of 15 January 2018. While numerous other petitions have been created for the same purpose, none have received as much attention.{{cite web|title=Logan Paul 'Dead Body' Video Spurs Thousands To Petition To Get Him Off YouTube|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/logan-paul-dead-body-petition_us_5a4f97bee4b089e14dba6cd7|website=Huffington Post|accessdate=01/05/2018}} ===In the United Kingdom=== On 10 March 2015, the political blogger Guido Fawkes, whose real name is [[Paul Staines]], started a petition{{cite news|url=http://www.cnn.com/2015/03/20/world/uk-bbc-jeremy-clarkson/|title=Fan hands BBC petition urging 'Top Gear' host's reinstatement|first1=Larua|last1=Smith-Spark|first2=Rosie|last2=Tomkins|publisher=CNN|date=2015-03-22|accessdate=2015-09-30}} to reinstate [[Jeremy Clarkson]], [[BBC]] co-host of TV series ''[[Top Gear (2002 TV series)|Top Gear]]''. This followed the BBC's decision to suspend him over a "fracas" involving a producer on the show.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}} The petition gained over 500,000 signatures within 24 hours, making it the fastest growing petition to date for the site, while having the servers at Change.org in the UK regularly become unresponsive due to the high demand.{{cite news |last=Dearden |first=Lizzie |title=Jeremy Clarkson petition 'BBC Bring Back Clarkson' is now officially the fastest-growing Change.org campaign in history|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/news/jeremy-clarkson-suspended-more-people-support-top-gear-petition-than-campaigns-to-end-fgm-and-page-3-10100908.html |accessdate=11 March 2015 |work=The Independent |location=London |date=11 March 2015}} It had gained over 1,000,000 signatures by 20 March 2015 and it was delivered to the BBC.{{cite news |title=Petition backing Jeremy Clarkson hits one million signatures |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/bbc/11485289/The-Stig-delivers-Jeremy-Clarkson-petition-to-BBC.html |accessdate=21 March 2015 |work=The Daily Telegraph |location=London |date=20 March 2015}} ===In Canada=== In August 2014, Erica Perry from [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia|BC]], started a petition asking [[Centerplate]], a large food and beverage corporation serving entertainment venues in North America and the UK, to fire its then-CEO Desmond "Des" Hague after the public release of security camera footage allegedly showing Hague abusing a young [[Doberman Pinscher]] in an elevator.{{cite news|author= Hanson, Hilary|url = http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/27/des-hague-centerplate-ceo-kicking-puppy_n_5724772.html|title = Des Hague, Multimillionaire CEO, Caught On Tape Kicking Puppy | work = [[The Huffington Post]]|date = August 27, 2014}} In response to Centerplate not taking action after the incident other than releasing a statement of apology from Hague, and an agreement by Hague to commit to perform certain charitable acts, the petition called for Centerplate to fire Hague. On September 2, 2014, after the petition had received over 190,000 signatures, Hague resigned from his position as CEO of Centerplate.{{cite news|author= Talmazan, Yuliya|url = http://globalnews.ca/news/1528859/centerplate-ceo-des-hague-resigns-over-dog-abuse-video|title = Centerplate CEO Des Hague resigns over dog abuse video | work = [[Global News]]|date = September 2, 2014}} ===In France=== In February 2016, 50 petitions have exceeded 100,000 signatories.{{cite news|author= de Comarmond, Leila|url = http://www.lesechos.fr/economie-france/social/021725031549-la-petition-anti-loi-travail-bat-des-records-1202980.php|title = La pétition anti-loi travail bat des records| work = [[Les Échos (newspaper)|Les Échos]]|date = February 25, 2016}} A petition against the "[[El Khomri law|Loi El Khomri]]", a labor law project by the French Labor Minister [[Myriam El Khomri]] has over 1 million signatures,{{cite web|author=Économie |url=http://www.lepoint.fr/societe/la-petition-decroche-1-million-de-signatures-contre-la-loi-el-khomri-04-03-2016-2023120_23.php |title=1,1 million de signatures pour la pétition contre la loi El Khomri - Le Point |publisher=Lepoint.fr |date=2016-03-07 |accessdate=2016-11-13}} a record for change.org in France. ===In Germany=== In 2012, Philip Matesanz, a 21-year-old German university student, started a petition to allow third-party recording tools for [[YouTube]]. The petition garnered more than 4.3 million signatures.{{cite web|url = https://www.change.org/petitions/youtube-googlede-allow-third-party-recording-tools-for-youtube-freedomonyoutube|title = @Youtube & @GoogleDE : Allow third party recording tools for YouTube #FreedomOnYoutube|publisher = change.org}} This was the largest number of signatures in the history of Change.org until the record was beaten in November 2016. ===In Spain=== In February 2013, over one million people, around two percent of the total population of Spain, had signed the petition calling for the entire [[government of Spain|Spanish government]] to resign.{{Citation needed|date=November 2016}} The call was motivated by an unprecedented corruption scandal involving the majority of key leaders of the [[People's Party (Spain)|People's Party]].{{Citation needed|date=January 2014}} ===In the Philippines=== The petition to have death row convict [[Mary Jane Veloso]] released was the fastest ever growing petition from the [[Philippines]] with over 250,000 signatories from over 125 countries.{{cite web|url=https://www.change.org/p/indonesian-pres-joko-widodo-jokowi-do2-save-the-life-of-human-trafficking-victim-mary-jane-veloso?utm_source=action_alert&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=295296&alert_id=lkcTYuUGdD_ewOj0qmymwRzwJXnbmO3Q0nGH%2FUr2pNfnRf%2FwRKLxP0%3D |title=Petition · Indonesian Pres. Joko Widodo @jokowi_do2 : Save the Life of human trafficking victim Mary Jane Veloso ·|publisher=Change.org |date= |accessdate=2016-11-13}}{{cite web|url=http://www.rappler.com/move-ph/91333-save-mary-jane-top-10-signed-change-org-petitions|title=#SaveMaryJane among most signed Change.org petitions|work=Rappler}} ===In India=== The petition of "Affordable internet for all" was started by an Indian blogger, YouTuber Amit Bhavani. To raise the voice against increasing prices of internet. The petition reached 75,000+ sign ups within 48 hours. The petition of "Justice for Asifa: 8yr old girl raped and murdered in Kathua, J&K " got 2 million supporters with over 1.5 million signatures. The petition of Kumar Ajitabh's kidnapping case has got 7K supporters (#FindAjitabh) The petition of banning, TV show, [[Pehredaar Piya Ki]] received support in the form of 1 lakh people due to promoting child marriage. ===In Australia=== The petition against ''Australian Citizenship Eligibility Changes April 2017'' is ongoing with over 75,000 signatures. In 2018 an anonymous creator of a Facebook community built on hatred for people riding bikes started a change.org anti-cycling petition that has grown in a short time to reach over 100,000 signatures. Allegedly, there is evidence many of the names on the petition are fake.{{cite news |title=Massive anti-cycling petition full of false names, claims Bicycle Queensland CEO |url=https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/massive-anticycling-petition-full-of-false-names-claims-bicycle-queensland-ceo/news-story/fdf3e0dd06aa3343948dce1020df03b1}} Change.org advised they were not able to provide any information to substantiate any such claims of fake names being used. After [[Snapchat]] released their new update in February 2018, Nic Rumsey from Australia created a petition to remove this update after a huge number of people provided feedback to the effect that they were not enjoying the update. The petition has over 1,100,000 signatures as of February 16, 2018. A petition commenced in October 2018, gaining over 300,000 signatures, to prevent a proposal to use the Sydney Opera House as a promotional billboard. Racing NSW proposed using the sails of the Sydney Opera House to promote the Everest horse race at Sydney's Royal Randwick on 13 October 2018. ===In Mexico=== After two earthquakes hit Central Mexico on [[2017 Chiapas earthquake|September 7th]] and [[2017 Central Mexico earthquake|September 19th]], 2017, there were different petitions to force the "[[Instituto Nacional Electoral]]" (''National Electoral Institute''), the [[Mexican Senate]], and President [[Enrique Peña Nieto]] to donate most or all of the money destined for the upcoming [[Mexican general election, 2018|2018 general elections]] be redirected to victims of the natural disaster in Mexico City and neighbor states of [[Morelos]], [[Chiapas]], [[Oaxaca]], and [[Puebla]]. All petitions together sum the number of more than 3 million signatures.{{cite news |author=Redacción GQ |title=México rompe récord en Change.Org, ahora solo falta que lo escuchen |url=https://www.gq.com.mx/actualidad/articulos/mexico-rompe-record-de-firmas-en-change-org/8935 |location=Mexico |date=22 September 2017 |access-date=22 September 2017 |language=Spanish}} The petition of Alfredo Aguirre from Monterrey,Mèxico reached 1,000,000+ sign ups within 24 hours. It was a new world record of Changeorg's history. ==Business model== Change.org makes revenue through a subscription membership model, people promoting petitions on the site, and crowdfunding.{{Cite web|url=https://www.smh.com.au/business/companies/why-change-org-s-army-of-davids-is-neutering-more-global-goliaths-20180228-p4z24h.html|title=Why Change.org's Army of Davids is Neutering More Global Goliaths|last=Bryant|first=Nick|date=3 March 2018|website=smh.com.au|language=en|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-08-21}} Change.org members contribute monthly to sustain the technology and the small teams of campaigners who coach and support petition starters. The majority of the company's revenue is advertising - individuals and organisations who start or sign petitions then chip in to promote those petitions to other site visitors. To date, Change.org has raised $50 million to fuel its growth from mission-aligned investors in business, technology and the media. In 2017 an investment round driven by [[Reid Hoffman]]{{Cite news|url=http://fortune.com/2017/05/26/reid-hoffman-change-org/|title=LinkedIn Founder Reid Hoffman Invests Big Change In Change.org|work=Fortune|access-date=2018-08-21|language=en}} helped drive the shift to the current business model. The website previously made revenue by running advertisements called sponsored campaigns for advocacy organizations such as [[Amnesty International]]{{cite news|last=Mui|first=Ylan M|title=Change.org Emerges as Influential Advocate on Issues from Bullying to Bank Fees|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/economy/changeorg-emerges-as-influential-advocate/2012/01/09/gIQAoCJHLQ_story.html| work = [[The Washington Post]]|date=January 24, 2012}} and list-building services to partner organizations.{{cite news|author=Martin, Courtney E. |url=http://www.thenation.com/article/164338/you-are-now-now-future-online-feminism|title= 'You Are the NOW of Now!' The Future of (Online) Feminism| work =[[The Nation]]|date= November 2, 2011}} In May 2013 the website started "crowd-promoted petitions" that allowed a signatory to promote the petition by paying $5 to $1000 at the final stage of petition signing. ==Criticism== ===Fake Signatures=== Massive Australian based anti-cycling petition is full of false names, claims Bicycle Queensland CEO. Anne Savage said the body had received information that many of the names were created by electronic “bots”. “We have evidence that the majority of names on that petition are false names,” she said.https://www.couriermail.com.au/news/queensland/massive-anticycling-petition-full-of-false-names-claims-bicycle-queensland-ceo/news-story/fdf3e0dd06aa3343948dce1020df03b1 ===Visibility of personal information=== Under certain conditions,{{cite web|title=Privacy Policy {{!}} Change.org|url=http://www.change.org/about/privacy|publisher=Change.org|accessdate= March 19, 2012}}{{vague|date=January 2015}} signatures and other private information including email addresses can be found by search engines. Change.org operates a system for signature hiding, which works only if the user has an account on Change.org.{{cite web|title=I want my name off of this petition immediately! : The Change.org Help Desk|url=http://helpdesk.change.org/entries/20272227-i-want-my-name-off-of-this-petition-immediately|publisher=Change.org|accessdate= March 19, 2012}} Conversely, the platform has been criticized for not providing enough information on who has signed a petition; for instance a means of verifying that a petition protesting a politician has been signed by his or her constituents or that the signatures are genuine at all.{{cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2015-05-29/change-org-is-amplifying-the-power-of-a-signature|title=Change.org Is Amplifying the Power of a Signature|first=Sarah|last=Issenberg|publisher=Bloomberg|date=2015-05-29|accessdate=2018-04-15}} ===Corporate structure=== There has been debate and criticism{{cite web|title=Is Change.org about Real Change or Just Pocket Change? |url=http://chieforganizer.org/2012/06/20/is-change-org-about-real-change-or-just-pocket-change/ |publisher=Chief Organizer Blog|author=Rathke, Wade |date= June 20, 2012|accessdate= July 10, 2012}}{{cite web|title=Change Dot Biz|url=http://www.informationdiet.com/blog/read/change-dot-biz|publisher=The Information Diet|date= February 28, 2012|accessdate= July 6, 2012}} around the fact that Change.org is a for-profit business despite using the [[.org]] domain suffix rather than the commercial [[.com]]. The site has been accused of fooling its users and hiding the fact that it is "a for-profit entity that has an economic incentive to get people to sign petitions". {{quote|text=Change.org is being deliberately deceitful through the use of the change.org name. I'd suspect that the average change.org user does not know that Change.org is a for-profit corporation, and that the corporation plans on using the contact information being provided to them to earn revenue.|sign=[[Clay Johnson (technologist)|Clay Johnson]]}} Change.org spokesperson Charlotte Hill countered this criticism in a September 2013 article in ''[[Wired Magazine|Wired]]'', saying, "We are a mission-driven social enterprise, and while we bring in revenue, we reinvest 100% of that revenue back into our mission of empowering ordinary people. It's not just that we're not yet making a profit – it's that we are decidedly not for-profit." {{cite news|last=Klint|first=Finley|title=Meet Change.org, the Google of Modern Politics|url=https://www.wired.com/wiredenterprise/2013/09/change-org/|accessdate=7 October 2013|newspaper=Wired Magazine|date=26 September 2013}} ===Advertising policy=== In 2012, the site dropped most of the restrictions it previously placed on paid content. Internal documents began referring to "clients" and "partners" as "advertisers" and stated that "only advertisers strictly identified as 'hate groups' are to be barred."{{cite web|url=http://www.dailykos.com/story/2012/10/23/1149092/-Change-org-sells-out-progressive-movement|title=Change.org sells out progressive movement|first=Raven|last=Brooks|publisher=Daily Kos|date=2012-10-23|accessdate=2015-09-30}}{{cite web|url=http://crooksandliars.com/karoli/why-i-will-not-sign-another-changeorg-petit|title=Why I Will Not Sign Another Change.org Petition Ever|publisher=[[Crooks and Liars]]|date=2012-10-24|accessdate=2015-09-30}} As a result, Change.org was accused of encouraging [[astroturfing]] and abandoning the progressive user base from which it initially gained traction. Additional controversy arose when the employee who initially leaked the documents was fired. Of the users who lost interest in the site after this change, a number of them expressed difficulty in being removed from Change.org mailing lists. ===Selling of personal data=== Change.org has also been accused of selling the personal data provided by the users to third-party companies that hire its services, gaining money at the expense of the users. ===Use for trending topics=== Topics for Change.org petitions have grown to include disagreement with the [[Academy Awards]] and removing milk from certain types of coffee.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/food/dailydish/la-dd-starbucks-vegan-pumpkin-spice-latte-20130912-story.html|first=Jenn|last=Harris|title=First world problem: Vegans want Starbucks Pumpkin Spice Lattes too|publisher=[[LA Times]]|date=2013-09-12|accessdate=2014-12-04}}{{cite web|url=http://blog.tradical360.com/7-dumbest-change-org-petitions-ever-created/ |first=Becky |last=Radolf |title=The 7 Dumbest Change.org Petitions Ever Created |publisher=Tradical |date=2014-03-07 |accessdate=2014-12-04 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141217055129/http://blog.tradical360.com/7-dumbest-change-org-petitions-ever-created/ |archivedate=2014-12-17 |df= }} The authors of these petitions have been criticized for focusing on [[first world problems]].{{cite web|url=http://www.dallasobserver.com/news/apartment-tenants-start-changeorg-petition-over-package-delivery-really-7428094|title=Apartment tenants start Change.org petition over package delivery. Really|first=Amy|last=Martyn|publisher=Dallas Observer|date=2015-07-24|accessdate=2016-11-19}} Further debate over the content of petitions came in November 2014 when [[Martin Daubney]] called some of them "bizarre" and stated that the site was being used to promote censorship.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/thinking-man/11229136/Is-Change.org-just-a-weapon-of-censorship.html|first=Martin|last=Daubney|title=Is Change.org just a weapon of censorship?|publisher=[[The Daily Telegraph|The Telegraph]]|date=2014-11-14|accessdate=2014-12-04}} In response, the Change.org communication director John Coventry defended the wide range of petitions, saying that "people make an informed choice in what they want to support."{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/men/thinking-man/11230684/Its-wrong-to-accuse-Change.org-of-promoting-censorship.html|first=John|last=Coventry|title=It's wrong to accuse Change.org of promoting censorship|publisher=The Telegraph|date=2014-11-14|accessdate=2014-12-04}} The following week saw criticism alleging that petitions about the media receive more attention than petitions about "saving 'actual' lives."{{cite web|url=http://things-that-matter.net/2014/11/20/how-can-a-petition-to-get-a-misogamist-pick-up-artist-refused-entry-to-the-uk-get-158000-signatures-and-our-petition-to-stop-the-home-office-just-leaving-people-to-drown-gets-3000-go-figure/|first=Ewan|last=Nicholson|title=How can a petition to get a misogynistic pick-up artist refused entry to the UK get 158,000 signatures and our petition to stop the Home Office just leaving people to drown gets 3000? Go figure.|publisher=Things That Matter|date=2014-11-20|accessdate=2014-12-04}} ==See also== {{portal|Internet}} * [[Avaaz]] * [[Activism 2.0]] * [[Care2]] * [[GetUp!]] * [[Slacktivism]] * [[SumOfUs]] * [[We the People (petitioning system)|We the People]] – Whitehouse.gov petition website ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Change.org}} * {{official website}} [[Category:2007 establishments in the United States]] [[Category:American political blogs]] [[Category:Internet-based activism]] [[Category:Internet properties established in 2007]] [[Category:Online petitions]] [[Category:Politics and technology]] [[Category:Technology in society]] [[Category:Benefit corporations]] [[Category:Social networks for social change]]

<!-- Needs factual sources. Most of the sources are (or all) are vague, or opinion-based articles with little to no supporting facts. -->{{Political corruption sidebar|image=[[File:Flag of Italy.svg|150px]]}}
'''Corruption in Italy''' is a major problem. In [[Transparency International]]'s annual surveys, Italy has consistently been regarded as one of the most corrupt countries in the Eurozone.<ref name=forbes>{{cite web| last =Webb| first =Jonathan | title =Corruption In Italy Is Getting Worse, Says Supreme Court Judge| work =Forbes| date =Apr 25, 2016| url =https://www.forbes.com/sites/jwebb/2016/04/25/corruption-in-italy-is-getting-worse-says-supreme-court-judge/#4f2bfc957970}}</ref> Transparency International's 2017 Corruption Perception Index ranks the country 54th place out of 180 countries.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.transparency.org/news/feature/corruption_perceptions_index_2017|title=Corruption Perception Index 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Corruption costs [[Italy]] a reported €60 billion a year, which amount to four percent of its GDP. On the 2016 [[Corruption Perceptions Index]], Italy took 61st place out of 174 countries, scoring on a par with [[Senegal]], [[Montenegro]], and [[South Africa]].<ref name=local>{{cite web| title =Italy is (still) one of Europe's most corrupt countries| work =The Local| date =Jan 27, 2016| url =http://www.thelocal.it/20160127/italy-is-still-one-of-europes-most-corrupt-countries}}</ref> Political corruption remains a major problem particularly in [[Southern Italy]] including [[Calabria]], parts of [[Campania]] and [[Sicily]] where corruption perception is at a high level.<ref>{{cite web|title=Freedom in the World|url=http://www.freedomhouse.org/report/freedom-world/2013/italy|publisher=Freedom House|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=EXAMINING THE LINKS BETWEEN ORGANISEDCRIME AND CORRUPTION|url=http://ec.europa.eu/dgs/home-affairs/doc_centre/crime/docs/study_on_links_between_organised_crime_and_corruption_en.pdf|publisher=Center for the Study of Democracy|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref> Political parties are ranked the most corrupt institution in Italy, closely followed by public officials and Parliament, according to Transparency International's [[Global Corruption Barometer]] 2013.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Corruption Barometer 2013|url=http://www.transparency.org/gcb2013|publisher=Transparency International|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref>
Regarding business and corruption, foreign investments and economic growth are hindered by organized crime and corruption.<ref>{{cite web|title=2013 Investment Climate Statement – Italy|url=https://www.state.gov/e/eb/rls/othr/ics/2013/204664.htm|publisher=US Department of State|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref> Business executives from [[World Economic Forum]] [[Global Competitiveness Report]] 2013–2014 consider corruption one of the problems for doing business in Italy.<ref>{{cite web|title=Global Competitiveness Report 2013-2014|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GlobalCompetitivenessReport_2013-14.pdf|publisher=World Economic Forum|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref> Procurement process, mainly in water, roads and railway projects, in Italy is affected by corruption.<ref>{{cite web|title=Snapshot of the Italy Country Profile|url=http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/europe-central-asia/italy/snapshot.aspx|publisher=Business Anti-Corruption Portal|accessdate=6 December 2013}}</ref>
According to Transparency International's Global Corruption Barometer 2013, 89% of surveyed households consider political parties to be corrupt or extremely corrupt—ranking as the most corrupt institution in Italy. Furthermore, 64% of the surveyed households believe that the level of corruption has increased and 61% of surveyed households find government efforts in the fight against corruption to be ineffective<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.transparency.org/gcb2013/country/?country=italy|title=Italy 2013 - World's largest opinion survey on corruption - Transparency International|last=e.V.|first=Transparency International|website=www.transparency.org|access-date=2017-06-22}}</ref>
Italian culture has been described as being characterized by “an ambiguous attitude to graft.”<ref name="indep">{{cite web| last =Day| first =Michael| title =Corruption in Italy 'worse than ever' as minister quits over links with gang accused of bribery| work =The Independent | date =Mar 20, 2015| url =https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/corruption-in-italy-worse-than-ever-as-minister-quits-over-links-with-gang-accused-of-bribery-10124024.html}}</ref> A 2015 ''[[Al Jazeera]]'' report noted that clientelism and graft have long been cornerstones of the country's political establishment,<ref name="aljaz">{{cite web| last =Mammone | first =Andrea | title =Eternal Corruption in the Eternal City?| work =Al Jazeera| date =Sep 10, 2015| url =http://america.aljazeera.com/opinions/2015/9/eternal-corruption-in-the-eternal-city.html}}</ref> and a ''[[Forbes]]'' contributor wrote in 2016 about “the deep-seated nature of unsavoury elements in both private and public sectors” in Italy.<ref name="forbes" /> “Many Italians,” maintained a 2010 report, have accepted corruption and poor governance as part of their lives.<ref name="insider">{{cite web| last =Scaglia| first =Paul| title =Comment: Quake underlines Italy’s sad legacy of corruption| work =Italian Insider| date =Apr 9, 2010| url =http://www.italianinsider.it/?q=node/119}}</ref> However, a 2015 report challenged this generally accepted view, arguing that “corruption in Italy does not seem to be a cultural issue” and that Italians consistently believe corrupt practices are less acceptable than other European nations.<ref name="open">{{cite web| last =Capussela| first =Andrea| title =Corruption in Italy: a resilient equilibrium| work =Open Democracy | date =May 9, 2015| url =https://www.opendemocracy.net/can-europe-make-it/andrea-capussela-vito-intini/corruption-in-italy-resilient-equilibrium}}</ref>
[[The Mafia]] plays a key role in both public and private corruption. Arising “out of business deals,” as ''Forbes'' put it, the Mafia historically “acted as a guarantor for contracts, when the judiciary was viewed as weak. Until relatively recent history, almost every deal in the country was enforced by a ‘man of honor.’”<ref name=forbes/>
One source has described the web of corruption involving politics, business, and the Mafia as “an unholy triangle,” adding that it could alternatively be seen as a rectangle, with the [[Roman Catholic Church]] being a fourth major participant in the web of corruption, owing to links between the Mafia and [[Vatican Bank]] and to “complex money laundering systems” involving banks that manage church funds.<ref name=bizins>{{cite web| last =Roe| first =Alex| title =Why Nothing's Changed Since The Huge Corruption Scandal That Hit Italy 20 Years Ago| work =Business Insider| date =Feb 21, 2012| url =http://www.businessinsider.com/why-nothings-changed-since-the-huge-corruption-scandal-that-hit-italy-20-years-ago-2012-2?IR=T&IR=T}}</ref>
==Recent history== ===L'Aquila earthquake=== {{Main|2009 L'Aquila earthquake}} After a 1968 earthquake in [[Sicily]], most of the funds appropriated to replace housing went to “needless construction projects,” a fact that underscored the scale of Italian corruption and the influence of the Mafia. Similarly, the 2009 L'Aquila earthquake, in which over 300 people died, was described as a “stark reminder to Italians of the risks they take by tolerating a corrupt political system.” Franco Barberi, head of an Italian committee assessing earthquake risks, alleged that anywhere where corruption had not undermined safety measures, a similar earthquake would have resulted in no fatalities.<ref name=insider/>
===Tangentopoli=== A 1992–94 corruption scandal called Tangentopoli (Bribe City), uncovered by the so-called [[Mani pulite]] (Clean Hands) investigation, “rocked Italy to its core” and brought down the First Republic. But the probes “fizzled out” and afterwards the bribery just got worse.<ref name=indep/><ref name=bizins/>{{Main|Mani pulite}}
The political impact of Mani Pulite remains the worst scandal of all modern Italy. The public outrage over the corruption led to “the sudden extinction" of five different political factions that had controlled Italy's government since 1946.<ref name=open/> A new political establishment took their place, but corruption resumed.<ref name=open/>
One target of the 1992 through 1994 corruption probes was [[Gianstefano Frigerio]], then a [[Christian Democracy (Italy)|Christian Democrat]] MP. During 1992–94, he was the defendant in four trials; one case fell afoul of the statute of limitations, but in the remaining three cases he was found guilty. He managed to have his six-year prison sentence reduced, then turned into a community service sentence, wherein his public service in the Parliament had been deemed acceptable community service.<ref name=open/> He was then re-elected to parliament in 2001, and arrested again in 2014 for participation in the massive corruption scheme surrounding the Expo in Milan.<ref name=open/>
It is widely believed that two judges, Paolo Borsellino and Giovanni Falcone, were murdered in 1992 because of their efforts to punish corrupt ties between Mafia and politicians.<ref name=bizins/>
{{See also|Paolo Borsellino|Via D'Amelio bombing|Giovanni Falcone}}
==Perceptions== In 2012, 65% of Italians told Transparency International (TI) that they thought corruption had intensified during the previous three years.<ref name=guard>{{cite web| last =Davies| first =Lizzy| title = The six things wrong with Italy – and how to solve them| work =The Guardian| date =Feb 20, 2013| url =https://www.theguardian.com/world/2013/feb/20/six-things-wrong-with-italy}}</ref> In April 2016, Italian Supreme Court judge Piercamillo Davigo, who had prosecuted widespread political corruption in the 1990s, also expressed the view that corruption had grown worse since then. “The politicians haven’t stopped stealing, they’ve stopped being ashamed of it,” he said. “Now they blatantly claim a right to do what they used to do secretly.”<ref name=forbes/>
Nicola Gratteri, an anti-mafia prosecutor, shared Davigo's view that the level of political corruption had heightened. Gratteri noted that twenty years prior, it was common practice for mob bosses to ask politicians for favors, but in recent years the politicians have sought the aid of mob bosses in return for public contracts.<ref>{{cite web| last =Jones| first =Gavin| title =Italy judge's warning on political corruption triggers furor| work =Reuters| date =Apr 23, 2016| url =https://www.reuters.com/article/us-italy-politics-justice-idUSKCN0XK0ER}}</ref>
A 2013 report in ''The Guardian'' identified “Organised crime and corruption” as one of six problems currently facing Italy. The Mafia, once confined largely to the south, now operated nationwide, and had spread beyond [[drug trafficking]] and [[prostitution]] to [[transportation|transport]], [[healthcare|public health]], and other industries.<ref name=guard/>'
Since 2000, Italy has experienced perceived corruption levels on par with Post-Soviet, Eastern European [[Transition economy|transition nations]].<ref name=open/>
==Government== Italian public officials routinely have close ties to organized crime and to businesses.<ref name=anti>{{cite web| title =Italy Corruption Report| work =Business Anti-Corruption Portal| url =http://www.business-anti-corruption.com/country-profiles/europe-central-asia/italy/show-all.aspx}}</ref> Italian citizens consider political parties and parliament itself to be the nation's two most corrupt institutions.<ref name=local/>
Corruption is common in Italy's public services sector. Doing business in Italy is complicated by inefficient government bureaucracies and burdensome rules, and almost half of Italians believe that the issuance of business permits involves bribes and abuse of power.<ref name=anti/> Because of corruption, it takes almost six years to complete a major public-works project in Italy, and such projects cost four times as much as elsewhere in Europe.<ref name=insider/>
In 2002, Berlusconi’s government “virtually abolished the crime of false accounting,” a move that caused a growth in corruption and Mafia crime.<ref name=indep/>
As of 2012, [[Filippo Penati]], a PD politician, was being investigated for corruption, specifically bribery. So was PdL party member [[Marco Milanese]], whose fellow party members in parliament managed to prevent his arrest.<ref name=bizins/>
Industry Minister [[Federica Guidi]] resigned in March 2016 when evidence emerged that she sought to help her boyfriend's business by helping to pass a certain budget amendment. Her boyfriend, Gianluca Gemelli, faced charges of corruption and influence peddling in the so-called Basilicata case.<ref name=occrp>{{cite web| title =Italy: Official Investigated In Growing Oil Corruption Scandal| work =OCCRP| date =Apr 14, 2016| url =https://www.occrp.org/en/daily/5132-italy-official-investigated-in-growing-oil-corruption-scandal}}</ref>
===Silvio Berlusconi=== [[File:Silvio Berlusconi (2010) cropped.jpg|thumb|160px|right|Silvio Berlusconi]] {{Main|Controversies surrounding Silvio Berlusconi}}
[[Silvio Berlusconi]], billionaire, media mogul, and prime minister of Italy for three periods (1994-5, 2001–6, and 2008–11), was frequently accused of corruption. His firms have been charged with such crimes as bribery and false invoicing, and Berlusconi himself has widely been rumored to have Mafia ties. In 2011, the [[U.S. State Department]] named Berlusconi as participating in the “commercial sexual exploitation of a Moroccan child.” Convicted of tax fraud in 2012, he was removed from the Italian Senate after the Supreme Court confirmed the verdict the next year, but not imprisoned. In June 2013 he was found guilty of paying a teenage girl for sex, and of abusing his political power, but the verdict was overturned in 2014.<ref>{{cite web| title = Silvio Berlusconi: Italy's once-untouchable prime minister| work =BBC| date =Jun 14, 2016| url =https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-11981754}}</ref>
===Public procurement=== The government procurement system is characterized by a high level of corruption. This is particularly true where infrastructure contracts are concerned. In such cases, the Mafia is very likely to be involved and favoritism will almost inevitably play a part in the awarding of contracts. In recent years, most of the high-profile corruption cases in Italy have involved government procurement. In 2015, one in three public contracts involved irregularities.<ref name=anti/>
Contracts for Expo 2015, a fair in [[Milan]], became the subject of a major anti-corruption investigation in which seven officials were arrested as of April 2015. [[Venice]]'s mayor and over 30 other public officials were arrested in 2015 for accepting bribes in exchange for building contracts.<ref name=anti/> In the same year, several businessmen were taken into custody on charges of belonging to “a gang involved in kickbacks and dodgy contracts” for high-speed rail lines, Expo 2015, a flood barrier in Venice, and other large-scale projects. Among those who had received kickbacks was Infrastructure and Transport Minister [[Maurizio Lupi]], who was forced to resign.<ref name=indep/>
===Judiciary=== The [[Judiciary of Italy|Italian courts]] are slow and inefficient. Almost half of citizens surveyed view the system as corrupt, and many think that bribes and abuse of power are common.<ref name=anti/>
===Police=== Experts view the [[Italian police]] as being relatively free of corruption and respectful of the law. About a third of Italians, however, consider the police to be corrupt.<ref name=anti/>
===Land administration=== There is a degree of corruption in Italian land administration. Over half of citizens think that officials issuing building permits commit bribery and abuse of power.<ref name=anti/>
===Tax system=== The tax system lacks transparency and involves considerable bribery. Most firms view the tax rates as problematic.<ref name=anti/>
===Customs service=== There is a degree of corruption in the customs system.<ref name=anti/>
==Financial sector== {{Main|Bancopoli}} The Bancopoli scandal of 2005–6 involved stock manipulation and insider trading. [[Antonio Fazio]], head of Italy's central bank, gave unfair advantage to [[Banca Popolare Italiana]] (BPI) in its struggle against the Dutch bank [[ABN AMRO]] for control of [[Banca Antonveneta]]. Fazio and other figures in the banking community were ultimately forced to resign, while the managing director of BPI was arrested and the bank's entire board of directors came under investigation.<ref>{{cite web|title=Procura: deposizione del premier irrilevante|url=http://www.corriere.it/Primo_Piano/Politica/2006/01_Gennaio/25/unipol.shtml|work=Corriere della Sera|publisher=RCS Pubblicità SpA|accessdate=24 June 2012|language=Italian}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Unipol, procura chiede archiviazione per le dichiarazioni di Berlusconi|url=http://www.repubblica.it/2006/a/sezioni/politica/affaripol3/archidic/archidic.html|work=La Repubblica.it|publisher=La Repubblica|accessdate=24 June 2012|language=Italian|date=25 January 2006}}</ref>
==Sports== {{Main|2006 Italian football scandal}} In 2006, police investigators revealed that the managers of major Italian [[soccer]] teams had been colluding with friendly referees to rig games.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.ft.com/cms/s/6129251e-0de3-11db-a385-0000779e2340.html | title=Azzurri’s quest consoles nation rocked by scandals | publisher=Financial Times | author=Simon Kuper | date=2006-07-07 | accessdate=2006-07-30 | archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20060715141908/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/6129251e-0de3-11db-a385-0000779e2340.html| archivedate= 15 July 2006 <!--DASHBot-->| deadurl= no}}</ref>
==Rome== [[File:Roma-palazzo dei senatori01.jpg|thumb|180px|right|The Senate Palace in Rome]] Beginning in December 2014, ties between [[Rome|Roman]] politicians and the Mafia were made public by the municipal judiciary, which provided evidence of the widespread siphoning of public funds from projects involving “the managing of green areas, recycling, social housing and refugee reception centers.” Leading officials were shown to have received bribes in exchange for government contracts; former mayor [[Gianni Alemanno]] was among those investigated.<ref name=aljaz/>
In what has come to be called the [[Mafia Capitale investigation]], officials were accused of rigging contracts for the management of migrant centers in Rome. The scheme involved stealing millions of euros from the civic coffers. The city has continued to suffer because of this crime.<ref name=anti/> In mid 2015, several leading government and business figures were arrested in connection with the scandal.<ref name=anti/>
A June 2016 report in ''The Guardian'' noted that Rome mayoral candidate [[Virginia Raggi]] of the [[Five Star Movement]] (M5S) was doing well in polls because of her focus on “the corruption and cronyism of Italy’s mainstream parties.” In Rome, noted the newspaper, “establishment politicians and officials” were currently “on trial alongside alleged mobsters, charged with conspiring to pocket millions of euros from rigged public contracts.” Raggi has accused the political elite of creating “a pit of waste” and of “robb[ing] Rome” with their corruption.<ref>{{cite web| last =Scammell| first =Rosie| title =Rubbish on the streets, corruption in the air: Rome looks for a clean-up candidate| work =The Guardian| date =Jun 11, 2016| url =https://www.theguardian.com/world/2016/jun/11/rome-mayoral-elections-raggi-corruption-five-star-movement}}</ref>
“The level of corruption we are witnessing in Rome,” wrote one observer in 2015, “suggests that Italy needs a major change in mentality, a cultural revolution.”<ref name=aljaz/>
==Positive view of Italian corruption== In 2001, British author and physician [[Theodore Dalrymple]] argued that corruption is actually the “one saving grace” of Italian public administration. Dalrymple explained his view that Italy's government was overburdened with an inefficient [[bureaucracy]] that slows down any progress but that corruption and bribery to bypass roadblocks allows for some progress to be made.<ref name=dalry>{{cite web| last =Dalrymple| first =Theodore| title =The Uses of Corruption| work =The City Journal| url =http://www.city-journal.org/html/uses-corruption-12180.html}}</ref>
Dalrymple further maintained that the open display of corruption on the part of government officials causes Italian citizens to view the government as the 'enemy', an attitude that Dalrymple considered sensible and healthy, as compared with the misguided British belief that the state is purely good. This belief, Dalrymple charged, “has completely eroded the proud and sturdy independence of the British population.”<ref name=dalry/>
==Anti-corruption efforts== In a May 2015 article for [[Open Democracy]], Andrea Capussela and Vito Intini noted that Italy's anti-corruption efforts are inadequate and are not pursued with any enthusiasm. Since 1994, they explained, Italy has seen a series of laws passed that weakened the government's ability to combat corruption. For example, the statute of limitations was cut in half, procedural rules were made more complicated, and some corruption-related acts were decriminalized. A new anti-corruption law passed in 2012 did not reverse these laws, and is widely considered weak. Capussela and Intini asked explicitly: “why were such laws adopted and never reversed and how could the political élite get away with it?” This state of affairs was especially puzzling, they pointed out, since the struggle against corruption had often been high on the agenda of any rising politician for two decades.<ref name=open/>
The Italian Anti-Corruption Law of 2012 expanded the definition of corruption and enhanced transparency and disclosure requirements for public-sector workers. It also introduced “white lists” of suppliers, service providers, and construction firms that comply with anti-Mafia laws. In addition, it established the National Anti-Corruption Authority, which has the power to investigate corruption cases, and the National Anti-Corruption Plan.<ref>{{cite web| last =Cova| first =Bruno| title =How Italy has toughened its anti-corruption laws| work =Ethic Intelligence| url =http://www.ethic-intelligence.com/experts/351-how-italy-has-toughened-its-anti-corruption-laws-and-what-this-means-for-companies/}}</ref> The law banned persons convicted of corruption from running for public office, increased prison sentences for officials convicted of abuse of office or demanding bribes, increased penalties for private-sector corruption, and called for the institution of local anti-corruption plans and for greater transparency in hiring and budgets.<ref>{{cite web| title =Italy: Anti-Corruption Law Adopted| work =Library of Congress| url =https://www.loc.gov/law/foreign-news/article/italy-anti-corruption-law-adopted/}}</ref> The law criminalized influence-trading in both the public and private sectors, protected whistleblowers, and prohibited corrupt officials from holding certain administrative positions. But proper enforcement of the law continues to be complicated by a slow, overburdened judiciary.<ref name=anti/>
There are effective means of investigating police abuse and corruption, but the process is hampered by slow courts. The Code of Conduct of Public Officials includes detailed prescriptions involving transparency, conflicts of interest, and gifts. There are also Rules on Protocol Gifts that forbid gifts to public officials, who are required to report their assets.<ref name=anti/>
Italy is a signatory to the [[Council of Europe]]’s Civil and Criminal Law Conventions against Corruption , the [[United Nations Convention Against Corruption|UNCAC]], and the [[OECD]]'s Anti-Bribery Convention.<ref name=anti/>
[[Mario Monti]], prime minister from 2011 to 2013, sponsored a 2012 anti-corruption law that was described by TI as an insufficient “first step.”<ref name=guard/> In 2012, 64% of Italians described government anti-corruption efforts as ineffective.<ref name=guard/> Only 19 percent think such efforts are effective.<ref name=local/>
The Italian National Anti-Corruption Authority (ANAC) is an independent regulatory body set up in 2009. It is empowered to inspect offices and confiscate documents. In 2016, the ANAC and the European Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) announced a partnership to fight corruption throughout the EU.<ref>{{cite web| title =OLAF and ANAC team up to tackle corruption in Italy and beyond| work =OLAF| date =Apr 20, 2016| url =https://ec.europa.eu/anti-fraud/media-corner/news/20-04-2016/olaf-and-anac-team-tackle-corruption-italy-and-beyond_en}}</ref>

[[File:Cyberstorm.mu team picture.jpg|thumb|The initial cyberstorm.mu team]] '''cyberstorm.mu''' is a group of developers from [[Mauritius]] who are focused on [[computer security]], [[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]] standards and [[Linux]] and Open Source Software adoption. They have worked on implementing [[TLS 1.3]] in [[Linux]] and [[Open-source software|Open Source Software]] during the [[Internet Engineering Task Force|IETF]] 100 [[Hackathon]] as part of the TLS Working Group <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2017/10/26/hackers_mu_tls_1_3/|title=Mauritian code-cutters to help deliver TLS 1.3|access-date=2017-11-14|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.ietf.org/blog/participating-ietf-hackathon-mauritius/|title=Participating in the IETF Hackathon from Mauritius {{!}} IETF Blog|last=|first=|date=|website=www.ietf.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2017-12-14}}</ref>. They have also prepared high school students for [[Google Code-in]] in 2016 which marked the first time that Mauritius participated <ref>{{Cite news|url=http://defimedia.info/google-code-two-mauritian-students-among-finalists|title=Google Code-in: Two Mauritian students among the finalists|date=2017-02-11|work=Defimedia|access-date=2017-12-30|language=fr}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://opensource.googleblog.com/2016/12/taking-pulse-of-google-code-in-2016.html|title=Taking the pulse of Google Code-in 2016|work=Google Open Source Blog|access-date=2017-12-30|language=en-US}}</ref>. In 2017, they trained another batch of high school students and this would lead to the first Grand Prize Winner for Mauritius <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://opensource.googleblog.com/2018/01/google-code-in-2017-winners.html|title=Announcing the Winners of Google Code-in 2017|work=Google Open Source Blog|access-date=2018-01-31|language=en-US}}</ref>. During IETF 101, cyberstorm.mu acted as TLS 1.3 champions, and continued to work on application integration support <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://trac.ietf.org/trac/ietf/meeting/wiki/101hackathon|title=101hackathon – Meeting Wiki|website=trac.ietf.org|access-date=2018-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=IETF - Internet Engineering Task Force|title=IETF Hackathon in London|date=2018-03-18|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IwuKtInfxlk&feature=youtu.be&t=4015|accessdate=2018-03-19}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/03/27/with_tls_13_signed_off_its_implementation_time/|title=Hurrah! TLS 1.3 is here. Now to implement it and put it into software|access-date=2018-03-27|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.ietfjournal.org/hacking-from-paradise/|title=Hacking from Paradise: Attending IETF Hackathon Remotely|work=IETF Journal|access-date=2018-04-10|language=en-US}}</ref> . In June 2018, cyberstorm.mu organized a hackathon with codename "Operation JASK" to fix sigspoof3 in a number of open source projects <ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2018/06/19/gnupg_popped_again_in_pass/|title=Pass gets a fail: Simple Password Store suffers GnuPG spoofing bug|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}}</ref>. In July of 2018, cyberstorm.mu participated in IETF 102 hackathon as TLS 1.3 champions to work on inter-operability and applications support and http 451 <ref>{{Citation|last=IETF - Internet Engineering Task Force|title=IETF102-HACKATHON-20180715-1400|date=2018-07-15|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u6rz4PWA_As&feature=youtu.be&t=4526|access-date=2018-07-18}}</ref>. Additionally, they have been active in authoring IETF Standards such as RFC 8270. During IETF 103, the team worked on TLS 1.3, [[HTTP 451|http451]] & [[Secure Shell|SSH]] <ref>{{Citation|last=IETF - Internet Engineering Task Force|title=IETF Hackathon Presentations|date=2018-11-04|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0XV9I-gVCB0&feature=youtu.be|access-date=2018-11-07}}</ref>.

'''Director of communications'''<ref>Public Relations Society of America http://www.prsa.org/jobcenter/commjobs.html</ref> is a position in both the private and public sectors. A director of communications is responsible for managing and directing an organization's internal and external communications. Directors of communications supervise [[public relations]] staff, create communication strategies, and may serve as the key spokesperson and media contact for the organization.
A director of communications may also be called a public relations manager,<ref>U.S. Department of Labor http://online.onetcenter.org/link/summary/11-2031.00</ref> '''communications director''', or '''[[press secretary]]'''.
The director of communications usually reports directly to a [[corporate title|CXO]], including a [[chief communications officer]] (CCO) or [[chief executive officer]] (CEO) of a company or organization.
In an organization, the director of communications directs the Communications Department, sometimes called a Public Affairs Department. The director of communications may be assisted by a deputy director, clerical staff, and communications specialists and public affairs officers.
==Communications in politics==
=== United States ===
In [[United States]] politics, a director of communications is usually a senior aide to the [[President of the United States]] ([[White House Communications Director]]), a member of the [[United States House of Representatives|House of Representatives]], a [[United States Senate|senator]], a [[judge]], a candidate for political office, a [[United States Cabinet|Cabinet secretary]], or a government department.
=== United Kingdom and Canada ===
{{Main|Director of Communications (Office of the Prime Minister)}} {{Main|Downing Street Director of Communications}}
In Canada and the [[United Kingdom]], a director of communications is a senior aide to [[Member of Parliament|members of Parliament]], members of the [[House of Lords]], the [[Prime Minister of the United Kingdom|prime minister]], Cabinet ministers, and government departments. The post of director of communications to the Prime Minister of the United Kingdom is [[Robbie Gibb]]; the director of communications to the Prime Minister of Canada is [[Jason MacDonald (politician)|Jason MacDonald]].
=== Australia === In [[Australia]], the director of communications is a senior adviser to the [[Prime Minister of Australia|Prime Minister]]. They manage the Prime Minister's communications office including Press Secretaries and [[Speechwriter|Speechwriting]] staff. The current director for the [[Turnbull Government]] is [[Mitch Fifield]].
=== Nigeria === In [[Nigeria]] the director of communications or special adviser on communications is a senior aide to the [[President of Nigeria|president]], [[Vice President of Nigeria|vice president]], and senior members of the National Assembly.
===Council of Europe=== In the [[Council of Europe]], the director of communication plays a key role in the organization, directly supporting the work of the [[Secretary General of the Council of Europe]].

The '''economy of affection''' is term introduced by [[Göran Hydén]] to describe a network of interactions, communications and support among certain [[peasant]] groups in parts of East Africa. These groups, identified in terms of their relationship to structure, are united by [[kinship]], community, religion or other affinities. The functional purposes of this economy of affection involves survival, social maintenance, and development.
The kind of personal relationships and dependencies which form the basis for a [[subsistence economy]] in [[East Africa]] have been superseded by commercial or government services in the developed world. But in such sub-Saharan African villages, as studied by Hyden, their economies have not yet been 'captured' by [[capitalism]] and their peasantry remains unproletarianised. The key issue here for Hyden is that the "[[Value system|social values]]" of the [[Market (economics)|market]] are still underdeveloped. The East African [[peasant]]ry still is able to 'choose' to operate at least partially in the traditional morality-based economy and the true market system. This then explains why a rational response to market incentives might strengthen his position in the economy of affection.<ref>[[Göran Hydén|Hyden, G.]] (1980) Beyond Ujamaa in Tanzania: underdevelopment and an uncaptured peasantry, London. {{ISBN|0435963023}}</ref><ref>Hyden, G. (1983) No Shortcut to Progress: African development in perspective, London. {{ISBN|0520039971}}</ref><ref>Waters, Tony. (1992) [https://www.jstor.org/stable/161051 A Cultural Analysis of the Economy of Affection and the Uncaptured Peasantry in Tanzania], ''The Journal of Modern African Studies'', Vol. 30, No. 1 Mar., pp. 163-175</ref>
Tony Waters believes that Hyden's model of the uncaptured peasantry can be used to describe other peasant situations such as North America's European frontier in the early 19th century, and Scotland in the 18th and 19th centuries.<ref>Waters, Tony. (2008). [https://www.amazon.com/The-Persistence-Subsistence-Agriculture-Marketplace/dp/0739128361] The Persistence of Subsistence Agriculture: Life Beneath the Level of the Marketplace. Lanham, MD: Lexington Books.</ref> The concept was popularised at China Agricultural University by Evans Tekuro Muki, Deborah Nakirijja, Victoria Harding, Tymon Mphaka and Lesego Khunuou
