{{Use mdy dates|date=July 2018}} {{short description|36th Governor of West Virginia}} {{Infobox officeholder | name = Jim Justice | image = Jim_Justice_2017_InaugurationHighlights_PB-63_(32366955776)_(cropped).jpg | office = 36th [[List of Governors of West Virginia|Governor of West Virginia]] | term_start = January 16, 2017 | term_end = | predecessor = [[Earl Ray Tomblin]] | successor = | birth_name = James Conley Justice II | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1951|4|27}} | birth_place = [[Charleston, West Virginia|Charleston]], [[West Virginia]], U.S. | death_date = | death_place = | party = [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican]] (before 2015, 2017–present) | otherparty = [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic]] (2015–2017) | occupation = Businessman | residence = [[Lewisburg, West Virginia]] (personal)
[[West Virginia Governor's Mansion]] (official) | spouse = {{marriage|Cathy Comer|1975}} | children = 2 | net_worth = {{increase}}[[United States dollar|US$]]1.6 billion (2017){{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/jim-justice-ii/|title=Jim Justice, II.|accessdate=April 5, 2018}} | education = [[University of Tennessee]]
[[Marshall University]] ([[Bachelor of Arts|BA]], [[Master of Business Administration|MBA]]) | website = {{url|governor.wv.gov|Government website}} }} '''James Conley Justice II''' (born April 27, 1951) is an American coal mining and agriculture businessman and politician serving the [[List of Governors of West Virginia|36th]] and current [[List of Governors of West Virginia|Governor of West Virginia]] since 2017. With a net worth of around $1.9 billion, he is the wealthiest person in [[West Virginia]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/jim-justice-ii/#4c5e903e7fe6|title=Jim Justice, II.|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-09-02|language=en}} He inherited a coal mining business from his father and successfully built a massive business empire with over 50 companies, including [[The Greenbrier]], a luxury resort. Justice is one of the few billionaires from the State of West Virginia.{{cite web |url=http://wvmetronews.com/2015/01/13/photo-gallery-west-virginia-coasts-to-blowout/a/|title=A West Virginia dancer performs during the first half at the WVU Coliseum.|date=January 14, 2015|website=WV MetroNews|accessdate=May 14, 2017}} In 2015, Justice switched from the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] to the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]] and announced his candidacy for Governor in the [[West Virginia gubernatorial election, 2016|2016 election]]. He ran as a Democrat and defeated the Republican nominee, [[Bill Cole (politician)|Bill Cole]]. Less than seven months after taking office, Justice switched back to the Republican Party the day after announcing his plans at a [[President of the United States|President]] [[Donald Trump|Trump]] rally in the state. ==Early life== James Conley Justice II was born in Charleston, the son of James Conley Justice and Edna Ruth (née Perry) Justice. Justice grew up in [[Raleigh County, West Virginia]]. He enrolled at the [[University of Tennessee]] on an [[athletic scholarship]] for [[golf]], but transferred to [[Marshall University]]. At Marshall, he was a two-year captain on the [[Marshall Thundering Herd|Thundering Herd]] golf team.{{cite journal|last=Houvouras|first=Jack|date=Winter 2010|title=HQ&A with Jim Justice |url=http://www.huntingtonquarterly.com/articles/issue72/hqa.php|journal=Huntington Quarterly|location=Huntington, WV|publisher=HQ Publishing|accessdate=May 1, 2016}} He earned his [[bachelor's degree]] and [[Master in Business Administration]] from Marshall.{{cite web|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/wva-billionaire-jim-justices-mission-to-restore-the-greenbrier-resort/2011/02/09/AB5NO5M_story.html|title=W.Va. billionaire Jim Justice's mission to restore the Greenbrier resort|work=[[Washington Post]]|first=Neely|last=Tucker|date=March 6, 2011|accessdate=July 4, 2015}} ==Business career== After college, Justice went into the family agriculture business. Justice founded Bluestone Farms in 1977, which now operates {{convert|50,000|acre}} of farmland, and is the leading producer of grain on the [[East Coast of the United States]]. During that time, he also developed Stoney Brook Plantation, a 15,000-acre hunting and fishing preserve in [[Monroe County, West Virginia|Monroe County]]. Justice is a seven time national corn growing champion.{{Cite web |url=http://www.wvgazettemail.com/article/20151104/GZ01/151109764/1419|title=Justice stresses big ideas over specifics in campaign |last=Gutman|first=David|website=Charleston Gazette-Mail|accessdate=January 12, 2016}} After the death of his father in 1993, Justice inherited ownership of Bluestone Industries and Bluestone Coal Corporation. In 2009, he sold some of his coal business to the Russian company [[Mechel]] for $568 million. In 2015, after a huge drop in the price of coal which led Mechel to close some of the mines, he bought the business back for just $5 million.{{Cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/features/2017-01-10/can-west-virginia-s-new-governor-save-coal-country|title=Can West Virginia's New Governor Save Coal Country?|last=Barrett|first=Paul|date=January 10, 2017|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=August 4, 2017}} Since buying back the mine from Mechel, Justice re-opened several of the mines and hired over 200 coal miners.{{Cite web|title = Justice to put 200 miners back to work|url=http://www.timeswv.com/news/justice-to-put-miners-back-to-work/article_5250c5de-13d7-11e5-8b82-fb371a724c0f.html|website=Times West Virginian|accessdate=January 12, 2016}} Justice's mining companies have a history of safety violation and unpaid taxes; in 2016, ''[[NPR]]'' called him the "top mine safety delinquent" in the United States.{{Cite web|url=https://www.npr.org/2016/10/07/496696292/billionaire-gubernatorial-candidate-owes-15-million-in-taxes-and-fines|title=Billionaire Gubernatorial Candidate Owes $15 Million In Taxes And Fines|last=Berkes |first=Howard|website=NPR.org|access-date=August 3, 2017}} Justice owes millions of dollars to the government in back taxes, and unpaid coal mining fees and fines: "His mining companies owe $15 million in six states, including property and minerals taxes, state coal severance and withholding taxes, and federal income, excise and unemployment taxes, as well as mine safety penalties, according to county, state and federal records."{{cite web |url=https://www.npr.org/2016/10/07/496696292/billionaire-gubernatorial-candidate-owes-15-million-in-taxes-and-fines|title=Billionaire Gubernatorial Candidate Owes $15 Million In Taxes And Fines|publisher=|accessdate=April 5, 2018}} Justice serves as the owner or [[chief executive officer]] of over 50 companies, including [[The Greenbrier]] in [[White Sulphur Springs, West Virginia]], which he bought for $20.5 million in 2009, preventing its [[bankruptcy]].{{cite web |url=http://www.wvgazette.com/article/20150511/GZ01/150519885?hootPostID=abd4e9a79a984c6f9e8b1befd5519cd8|title=Greenbrier owner Jim Justice enters governor's race|work=[[The Charleston Gazette]]|last=Eyre|first=Eric|date=May 11, 2015|accessdate=June 30, 2015}} When Justice first took control he immediately brought back all 650 laid-off employees. He added vacation and health benefits to their contracts and offered a 10 percent raise if the hotel regained its fifth star.{{Cite news|title=W.Va. billionaire Jim Justice's mission to restore the Greenbrier resort|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/lifestyle/magazine/wva-billionaire-jim-justices-mission-to-restore-the-greenbrier-resort/2011/02/09/AB5NO5M_story.html|newspaper=The Washington Post |date=February 9, 2011|accessdate=November 11, 2016|issn=0190-8286|first=Neely|last=Tucker}} Justice is in the process of building a new mountain top golf course with golfers [[Jack Nicklaus]], [[Gary Player]], and [[Lee Trevino]]. [[Arnold Palmer]] was involved before his 2016 death.{{Cite web|title=Justice lures golf legends to build mountaintop course near Greenbrier |url=http://www.wvgazettemail.com/article/20150621/GZ02/150629839/2003120916#sthash.elNd4DYo.dpuf |website=Charleston Gazette-Mail|accessdate=January 12, 2016}} [[Forbes]] estimates Justice's net worth at $1.6 billion, making him the richest man in [[West Virginia]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/sports/nfl/saints/2014/07/24/new-orleans-saints-training-camp-jim-justice/13134225/ |title=Billionaire Jim Justice gives Saints lavish training camp|first=Jim|last=Corbett|date=July 24, 2014|work=USA Today |accessdate=June 30, 2015}} As of 2014, he owned 70 active mines in 5 states. His charitable activities have included $25 million for the James C. Justice National Scout Camp at [[The Summit Bechtel Family National Scout Reserve]], $5 million for [[Marshall University]], and $10 million to the [[Cleveland Clinic]].{{cite news|last=Berkes|first=Howard|last2=Boiko-Weyrauch|first2=Anna|last3=Benincasa |first3=Robert|url=https://www.npr.org/2014/11/15/363024382/billionaire-spent-millions-in-charity-but-avoided-mine-fines |title=Billionaire Spent Millions In Charity, But Avoided Mine Fines|work=[[NPR]]|date=November 15, 2014|accessdate=June 30, 2015}} Justice gives away more than $1 million in Christmas gifts annually through the Dream Tree for Kids campaign.{{Cite web |title=Dream Tree for Kids distributes $1 million worth of gifts|url=http://www.register-herald.com/news/dream-tree-for-kids-distributes-million-worth-of-gifts/article_008263ab-390e-59b5-acf1-905f67c08947.html|work=Beckley Register-Herald|accessdate=January 12, 2016}} Before taking office as governor, Justice resigned from all the executive positions he held at his business. He placed his daughter Jill in charge of [[The Greenbrier]] and his son Jay in charge of his mining and agriculture businesses. He has said he will place all his assets in a [[blind trust]], but that the process will take time because of their complexity.{{Cite web |url=http://wvmetronews.com/2017/01/30/billionaire-gov-jim-justice-says-hes-pursuing-blind-trust-commerce-secretary-thrasher-files-one/|title=Billionaire Gov. Jim Justice says he's pursuing blind trust; Commerce Secretary Thrasher files one|date=January 30, 2017 |website=WV MetroNews|access-date=August 4, 2017}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.wvgazettemail.com/news-politics/20170302/some-of-justices-companies-put-in-blind-trust|title=Some of Justice's companies put in blind trust|work=Charleston Gazette-Mail|access-date=August 4, 2017|language=en-US}} ==Political career== [[File:VP Pence Visits West Virginia 03.jpg|thumb|Jim and Cathy Justice meeting Vice President [[Mike Pence]] in March 2017]] In 2015, Justice declared his candidacy for [[Governor of West Virginia]] in the [[West Virginia gubernatorial election, 2016|2016 election]] as a member of the [[Democratic Party (United States)|Democratic Party]]. He had been a registered member of the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] until changing his registration in February 2015.{{cite news |last=Maher |first=Kris |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/jim-justice-west-virginia-billionaire-launches-campaign-for-governor-1431380406 |title=Jim Justice, West Virginia Billionaire, Launches Campaign for Governor |work=[[The Wall Street Journal]] |date=May 12, 2015 |accessdate=June 30, 2015 }} This was his first time running for political office.{{cite web |url=http://wvmetronews.com/2015/05/11/jim-justice-enters-politics-announces-2016-run-for-governor/|title=WV MetroNews – Jim Justice enters politics, announces 2016 run for governor |newspaper=Wvmetronews.com |first=Jeff|last=Jenkins|accessdate=August 7, 2015}} In May 2016, Justice won the Democratic nomination for governor and ran against Republican nominee [[Bill Cole (politician)|Bill Cole]] in the general election.{{cite news|last=Raby |first=John |url=http://www.herald-dispatch.com/elections/jim-justice-wins-democratic-nomination-for-west-virginia-gov/article_4feb8f22-9ea2-5ed3-bf31-4b887b799b8c.html|title=Jim Justice wins Democratic nomination for West Virginia gov|work=[[The Herald-Dispatch]]|date=May 10, 2015 |accessdate=May 10, 2016}}{{dead link|date=April 2017|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}} On November 8, Justice won the election.{{cite web|url=http://www.wvgazettemail.com/news-politics/20161108/jim-justice-declared-winner-in-governors-race |title=Jim Justice wins WV gubernatorial race|accessdate=November 12, 2016}} Justice was endorsed by the United Mine Workers.{{Cite web|title=UMWA endorses Jim Justice for governor |url=http://wvmetronews.com/2015/11/12/umwa-endorses-jim-justice-for-governor/|website=WV MetroNews|access-date=January 12, 2016}} ===Governor of West Virginia=== [[File:Jim Justice 2017 InaugurationHighlights PB-74 (32406322245).jpg|thumb|Justice at his inauguration]] Justice took office as governor on January 16, 2017. He is known for using colorful metaphors and digs at political opponents.{{cite news|last1=Jenkins|first1=Jeff|title=From 'knuckleheads' to 'blockheads' Justice still critical of legislature over budget|url=http://wvmetronews.com/2017/03/06/from-knuckleheads-to-blockheads-justice-still-critical-of-legislature-over-budget/|accessdate=April 14, 2017|work=MetroNews|date=March 6, 2017}}{{cite news|last1=McElhinny |first1=Brad|title=Governor Justice calls himself a grizzly and Senate majority leader a poodle |url=http://wvmetronews.com/2017/02/24/governor-justice-calls-himself-a-grizzly-and-senate-majority-leader-a-poodle/|accessdate=April 14, 2017|work=MetroNews|date=February 24, 2017}} To improve West Virginia's budget situation, he has proposed raising the state's revenue by $450 million, primarily by increasing the consumer sales tax, reinstituting the [[business and occupation tax|business and occupation (B & O) tax]], and establishing a "rich man's" tax.{{cite news|url=http://wvmetronews.com/2017/04/13/justice-vetoes-budget-by-unveiling-bull-manure/ |title=Justice vetoes budget by unveiling bull manure |publisher=West Virginia MetroNews Network |first=Jeff |last=Jenkins |date=April 13, 2017 |accessdate=August 4, 2017}} He also opposed plans to cut health and education spending.{{Cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/05/01/us/jim-justice-west-virginia-governor.html|title=West Virginia's Governor, an 'Unusual Democrat,' Fights a G.O.P. Tide|last=Bidgood|first=Jess|date=May 1, 2017|work=The New York Times|access-date=August 4, 2017|issn=0362-4331}} On April 13, 2017, while vetoing a budget bill passed by the Republican-controlled [[West Virginia Legislature]], Justice said the bill was "nothing more than a bunch of political you-know-what" and showed a prop featuring bull feces on a print copy of the bill.{{cite news|last1=Stevenson|first1=Peter W.|title=The governor of West Virginia brought a plate of B.S. to the statehouse, literally|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/the-fix/wp/2017/04/14/the-governor-of-west-virginia-brought-a-plate-of-b-s-to-the-statehouse-literally/|accessdate=April 14, 2017|work=[[The Washington Post]]|date=April 14, 2017}} On August 3, 2017, Justice announced that he had rejoined the Republican Party. He made the announcement at a [[Donald Trump]] rally in [[Huntington, West Virginia|Huntington]] and also confirmed his support for the sitting [[President of the United States|President]]. Justice said that he was returning to the GOP because he could not help Trump as a Democrat. The announcement came as a surprise to his own staff.{{cite news|last=Kabler|first=Phil|date=August 3, 2017 |title=WV Gov. Justice switching political parties, returning to GOP|url=http://www.wvgazettemail.com/news-politics/20170803/wv-gov-justice-switching-political-parties-returning-to-gop |publisher=[[Charleston Gazette]] |access-date=August 4, 2017}} This also made Justice the first Republican governor of West Virginia since [[Cecil H. Underwood|Cecil Underwood]] in 2001. Even after switching to the Republican Party, Justice endorsed incumbent Democrat [[Joe Manchin]] for reelection in the [[United States Senate election in West Virginia, 2018|2018 Senate election in West Virginia]].{{cite web |url=http://wvmetronews.com/2017/09/20/governor-justice-now-republican-tells-republicans-he-supports-manchins-senate-bid/|title=WV MetroNews – Governor Justice, now Republican, tells Republicans he supports Manchin's Senate bid|website=wvmetronews.com |accessdate=April 5, 2018}}
{{cite web|url=http://www.washingtonexaminer.com/gop-gov-jim-justice-backs-democrat-joe-manchin-for-senate/article/2635089|title=GOP Gov. Jim Justice backs Democrat Joe Manchin for Senate|date=September 20, 2017|accessdate=April 5, 2018}} === Political Positions === Governor Jim Justice began his gubernatorial campaign and career as a [[conservative Democrat]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.wvgazettemail.com/news/politics/jim-justice-wins-wv-gubernatorial-race/article_51616242-0090-5608-a495-b9613d7a2b86.html|title=Jim Justice wins WV gubernatorial race|last=Brown|first=Andrew|work=Charleston Gazette-Mail|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/magazine/story/2016/09/west-virginia-2016-governor-coal-cole-justice-214268|title=Is West Virginia Holding America’s Weirdest Election?|work=POLITICO Magazine|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}} [[Time (magazine)|''Time'']] magazine identified him as a [[Moderate Democrat|moderate]] Democrat.{{Cite web|url=http://time.com/4886765/west-virginia-rally-jim-justice-republican-trump/|title=West Virginia Governor Switches Parties at Trump Rally|website=Time|language=en|access-date=2018-11-20}} However, as noted above, he switched to the [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] a few months after taking office and declared his support for President [[Donald Trump]].{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/maxjedeurpalmgren/2017/08/04/billionaire-and-wv-governor-jim-justice-switches-to-republican-at-trump-event/#59e2b096483b|title=Billionaire and WV Governor Jim Justice Switches To Republican at Trump Event|last=Jedeur-Palmgren|first=Max|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}} ==== Economic Policy ==== Justice campaigned and has governed with support for the coal industry.{{Cite news|url=https://www.politico.com/story/2017/08/03/trump-praises-west-virginia-governor-coal-241313|title=Trump: Praise for Justice and coal|work=POLITICO|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}} He does not support raising taxes, but has supported increasing teachers' salaries arguing that increased state revenue will pay for the increased budget spending.{{Cite web|url=http://wvmetronews.com/2018/01/10/new-spending-proposals-and-a-tax-cut-on-governor-justices-plate-this-year/|title=WV MetroNews – New spending proposals and a tax cut on Governor Justice’s plate this year|website=wvmetronews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-20}} In 2017, Justice said that he opposed budget cuts and supported raising sales taxes.{{Cite web|url=http://wvmetronews.com/2018/05/04/governor-justice-highlights-state-revenue/|title=WV MetroNews – Governor Justice highlights improving state revenue|website=wvmetronews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-20}} The fiscally conservative [[Cato Institute|CATO Institute]], gave Justice an 'F' grade based on their positions, but Justice voiced his disagreement with the rating.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wvgazettemail.com/news/politics/justice-dismisses-f-on-cato-institute-report-card-on-fiscal/article_5587ddce-938c-5c72-9975-a70ec661317b.html|title=Justice dismisses 'F' on Cato Institute report card on fiscal policy|last=writer|first=Phil Kabler Staff|work=Charleston Gazette-Mail|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}} ==== Social Policy ==== On abortion, Justice had said that he does not support abortion, but that the Supreme Court had decided the issue.{{Cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/Governor/Jim_Justice_Abortion.htm|title=Jim Justice on Abortion|website=www.ontheissues.org|access-date=2018-11-20}} Later, Justice attended an anti-abortion, or [[Anti-abortion movements|pro-life]], rally supporting Amendment 1, a state constitutional amendment intended to ban abortion if [[Roe v. Wade|''Roe v. Wade'']] is overturned.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wvnews.com/news/wvnews/west-virginians-to-vote-on-amendment-to-constitution-concerning-abortion/article_0bd04fd6-892c-5eac-8e0d-3d3d491af1a8.html|title=West Virginians to vote on amendment to constitution concerning abortion|work=WV News|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.wvgazettemail.com/news/politics/anti-abortion-proponents-rally-for-amendment/article_f83d36b4-7b6f-5309-9107-09d88f428797.html|title=Anti-abortion proponents rally for Amendment 1|last=writer|first=Lori Kersey Staff|work=Charleston Gazette-Mail|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}} He is considered pro-life and signed two anti-abortion bills into law.{{Cite web|url=http://wvmetronews.com/2018/01/12/pro-life-lawmakers-look-to-restrict-taxpayer-paid-for-abortions/|title=WV MetroNews – Pro-life lawmakers look to restrict taxpayer-funded abortions|website=wvmetronews.com|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-20}} Justice supports gun ownership and loosened gun laws. In 2016, Justice had a 0% rating from the [[National Rifle Association|National Rife Association]] (NRA).{{Cite web|url=https://votesmart.org/candidate/evaluations/166287/jim-justice-jr#.W_R9cuhKiUk|title=The Voter's Self Defense System|website=Vote Smart|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-20}} In 2018, however, Justice signed into a law a bill allowing gun owners to keep their guns locked in vehicles on their employers' property, and this was a bill supported by the NRA.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wsaz.com/content/news/WVa-lawmakers-approve-parked-guns-legislation-476417103.html|title=UPDATE: W.Va. Gov. Justice signs 'parked guns' legislation|last=MetroNews|first=The Associated Press, Bradford Arick, WSAZ News Staff,|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}} He also signed a bill legalizing hunting on Sundays on private land.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wvnews.com/theet/news/free/gov-justice-approves-several-gun-related-bills/article_524f004d-6d0b-5bcc-ae16-52b5713fa3fa.html|title=Gov. Justice approves several gun-related bills|last=JOURNAL|first=Rusty Marks THE STATE|work=WV News|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}} On healthcare, Justice does not support repealing the [[Medicaid expansion]] that resulted from the [[Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act|Affordable Care Act]].{{Cite web|url=http://www.ontheissues.org/Governor/Jim_Justice_Health_Care.htm|title=Jim Justice on Health Care|website=www.ontheissues.org|access-date=2018-11-20}} Regarding [[LGBT]] issues and [[same-sex marriage]], Justice has taken a nuanced position. He did not say whether he supports or opposes same-sex marriage, and, instead, stated that he respects the Supreme Court decision, [[Obergefell v. Hodges|''Obergefell v. Hodges'']], which legalized same-sex marriage nationwide.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wvgazettemail.com/news/politics/justice-weighs-in-on-same-sex-marriage-decision/article_cfc75c77-2bf5-5fe5-83cd-c2a5fdd18638.html|title=Justice weighs in on same-sex marriage decision|last=Gutman|first=David|work=Charleston Gazette-Mail|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}} In 2016, Justice opposed a bill that would have allowed businesses to refuse service to LGBT customers.{{Cite news|url=https://www.wvgazettemail.com/news/politics/jim-justice-opposes-religious-freedom-bill/article_fab770af-c186-5ccf-8fdc-3f8d5bd73cc0.html|title=Jim Justice opposes 'religious freedom' bill|last=Beck|first=Erin|work=Charleston Gazette-Mail|access-date=2018-11-20|language=en}} ==Opinion about global warming== According to the ''[[Charleston Gazette-Mail|Charleston Gazette–Mail]]''[[Charleston Gazette-Mail|,]] Justice has equivocated on the scientific consensus on [[global warming]]. In an interview with the paper, he said: "There's documentation that would give one concern, and I don't think you should ignore that," he said. "At the same time, I think there's an awful lot of research that still should be done. [...] I surely wouldn't sit here and say I am a believer in global warming, but I wouldn't sit here and say that I am not concerned." ==Personal life== [[File:Jim and Cathy Justice.jpg|thumb|Jim and Cathy Justice]] Justice lives in [[Lewisburg, West Virginia]]. He met his wife, Cathy (''[[née]]'' Comer) in high school.{{cite web |url=http://www.governor.wv.gov/about/Pages/default.aspx|title=About Jim|website=www.governor.wv.gov|accessdate=August 4, 2017}} They have two children, Jay and Jill. He stands at 6 feet and 7 inches.{{cite web |url=http://www.successfulmeetings.com/Strategy/Meeting-Strategies/James-C--Justice-II,-West-Virginia-s-Gentle-Giant/|title=James C. Justice II, West Virginia's Gentle Giant: Successful Meetings|website=www.successfulmeetings.com|accessdate=May 14, 2017}} Justice is a lifelong fan of the [[New Orleans Saints]] of the [[National Football League]] (NFL), and spent $30 million to develop a training facility for the team to use in 2014 at [[The Greenbrier]]. He hosts the [[Greenbrier Classic]], a [[PGA Tour]] event, at The Greenbrier annually. ===Youth sports=== Since 1992 Justice has been President of Beckley Little League. His participation has helped the program expand to over 1,000 children playing on 80 teams. Having lived in Lewisburg since 2001, he has been the girls basketball coach at [[Greenbrier East High School]] since 2003, having won the state championship in 2012. In 2011, he also became the head coach for the boys basketball teams, a position from which he stepped down in September 2017.{{cite web|url=http://www.wvva.com/story/36370290/2017/09/Thursday/gov-justice-will-no-longer-coach-high-school-boys-basketball|title=Gov. Justice will no longer coach high school boys basketball|first=Paul|last=Hess|accessdate=April 5, 2018}} He was the only coach at the AAA level ([[West Virginia Secondary School Activities Commission|the state's]] largest classification) who coached both the girls and boys basketball teams. Justice stated that though he will place his business interests in a [[blind trust]] upon becoming governor, he will still coach basketball while serving.{{cite web |url=https://apnews.com/db837818bed746cea1bd53ea2839204d|title=West Virginia gov-elect plans to keep coaching basketball |accessdate=May 14, 2017}} In discussing the coaching position, Justice said, "There are three things I know that I can do, and that's shoot a shotgun, make a deal and coach basketball. I'm excited about it." He has been director of the Mountain State Coal Classic since 1995. The basketball classic has enjoyed tremendous success awarding hundreds of thousands in scholarships and direct support to participating schools. ==Electoral history== {{Election box begin no change | {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2018}} {{Use British English|date=January 2018}} {{Coord|57|8|00|N|2|9|30|W|region:GB_source:enwiki-osgb36(NJ905047)_type:edu|display=title}} {{Infobox company |name = The Macaulay Land Use Research Institute |logo = Themacaulaylanduseresearchinstitutelogo.gif |founded = 1987 |type = Registered Charity |predecessor = Hill Farming Research Organisation (HFRO)
Macaulay Institute for Soil Research (MISR) |successor = [[James Hutton Institute|The James Hutton Institute]] |location_city = [[Aberdeen]] |location_country = [[Scotland]] |homepage = {{URL|www.macaulay.ac.uk}} |key_people = Richard Aspinall |defunct = {{End date|df=yes|2011|03|31}} |fate = Merged |subsid = Macaulay Scientific Consulting Ltd. }} {{More citations needed|date=December 2009}} The '''Macaulay Institute''', formally the '''Macaulay Land Use Research Institute''' and sometimes referred to simply as '''The Macaulay''' is a research institute based at [[Aberdeen]] in [[Scotland]], which is now part of the [[James Hutton Institute]]. Its work covers aspects such as [[landscape]], [[soil conservation|soil]] and [[water conservation]] and [[climate change]]. ==History== The '''Macaulay Institute for Soil Research''' was founded in 1930. A benefaction of £10,000 from one of Canada's Scottish sons, [[Thomas Bassett Macaulay]], of the [[Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada]] was used to purchase 50 acres and buildings at Craigiebuckler in Aberdeen.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=crVAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=uqUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5781%2C2594642 |title=Institute transfer snag |first=Thomas |last=McConnell |work=[[The Glasgow Herald]] |date=11 April 1986 |page=7 |accessdate=15 July 2016}} Macaulay's aim was to improve the productivity of Scottish agriculture. Thomas Bassett Macaulay was a descendant of [[Macaulay family of Lewis]], who were centred on the [[Hebridean]] island of [[Isle of Lewis|Lewis]]. He was true to his Hebridean roots throughout his life, often giving large donations to Lewis, which funded various projects including a new library and a new wing at Lewis hospital. The new Macaulay Institute opened on a site near Bucksburn in April 1987.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=wPs9AAAAIBAJ&sjid=M0kMAAAAIBAJ&pg=5133%2C552905 |title=West College chief given new post |work=The Glasgow Herald |date=2 December 1986 |page=26 |accessdate=16 July 2016}} It was formed by the merger of the Macaulay Institute for Soil Research and the Hill Farm Research Organisation. The proposed merger was announced in December 1985 with the government anticipating that it would result in cost savings.{{cite news |url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=abdAAAAAIBAJ&sjid=xqUMAAAAIBAJ&pg=4551%2C2778929 |title=Research to undergo radical changes |work=The Glasgow Herald |date=13 December 1985 |page=2 |accessdate=15 July 2016}} It was established to carry out research in support of the agricultural industry, taking account of the interaction between the industry and other land users, and set in the context of the environmental objectives of the [[UK Government]] and the [[European Union]]. In April 2011, the Macaulay Institute merged with [[Scottish Crop Research Institute|SCRI (Scottish Crop Research Institute)]] in Dundee to form the [[James Hutton Institute]]. The [[chief executive]] of the new institute is Professor Iain Gordon.{{cite web|url=http://www.macaulay.ac.uk/newinstitute/ |title=New Institute, SCRI Macaulay merger |accessdate=29 October 2010 |last= |first= |coauthors= |year=2009 |work= |publisher=The Macaulay Land Use Research Institute}} ==Research== It is an international centre for research and consultancy on the environmental and social consequences of rural land uses. Interdisciplinary research across the environmental and social sciences aims to support the protection of natural resources, the creation of integrated [[land use]] systems, and the development of sustainable rural communities. With an annual income from research and consultancy of over £11million, the Macaulay Institute is the largest interdisciplinary research organisation of its kind in [[Europe]].{{Citation needed|date=December 2009}} It is one of the main research providers to the [[Scottish Government]] and currently about 75% of the Macaulay's income is related to commissioned research programmes, principally on "Land Use and Rural Stewardship". The 300 staff and postgraduate students are drawn from over 25 countries, and conduct research in Scotland, across Europe and internationally, with a wide range of partner organisations. Their goal is that the research they undertake provides evidence that will help shape future environmental and rural-development policy both in Scotland and internationally. The Macaulay Land Use Research Institute was a [[Charitable organization|registered charity]] since 1931.{{cite web |url=http://www.oscr.org.uk//charities/search-scottish-charity-register/charity-details?charitynumber=SC011922 |title=Scottish charity SC011922 |publisher=Scottish Charity Register |accessdate=15 July 2016}} Commercial services are delivered through Macaulay Scientific Consulting Ltd, its subsidiary consultancy company.[https://web.archive.org/web/20110517204153/http://www.macaulayscientific.com/ Macaulay Scientific Consulting Ltd] The mineral [[Macaulayite]] is named after the Institute.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/scotland/north_east/8400025.stm|title=Nasa tests Aberdeenshire find for life on Mars clues|work=[[BBC News]]|date=8 December 2009|accessdate=8 December 2009}} ==Notable Directors== *[[Donald McArthur]] [[FRSE]] (1948-1958) *[[Robert Lyell Mitchell]] [[FRSE]] (1968-1975) ==Affiliations== The Macaulay Institute is a member of the [[Aberdeen Research Consortium]] which also includes: *[[University of Aberdeen]] *[[FRS Marine Laboratory]], Aberdeen *[[Rowett Research Institute]] *[[Robert Gordon University]] *[[Scottish Agricultural College]] ==Current work== [[LADSS]] and [[AGRIGRID]] are examples of projects that are being undertaken at the Institute. ==See also== * [[AGRIGRID]] * [[LADSS]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.macaulay.ac.uk/ Macaulay Institute Official Site] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110517204153/http://www.macaulayscientific.com/ Macaulay Scientific Consulting Ltd] *[http://www.hutton.ac.uk/ James Hutton Institute] [[Category:Agriculture in Scotland]] [[Category:Environment of Scotland]] [[Category:Research institutes in Scotland]] [[Category:Economy Directorates]] [[Category:Public bodies of the Scottish Government]] {{Infobox person | name = Manuel Fal Conde | image = Manuel Fal Conde.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = Fal Conde in Toledo, 1936 | birth_name = Manuel Fal Conde | birth_date = 10 August 1894 | birth_place = [[Higuera de la Sierra]] | death_date = 20 May 1975 (aged 80) | death_place = [[Seville]] | body_discovered = | death_cause = | resting_place = | resting_place_coordinates = <!-- {{coord|LAT|LONG|display=inline,title}} --> | residence = | nationality = [[Spain|Spanish]] | citizenship = | other_names = | known_for = Political leadership | education = | alma_mater = | employer = | notable works = | occupation = Lawyer | years_active = | home_town = | salary = | networth = | height = | weight = | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | party = [[Carlism]] | opponents = | boards = | spouse = | partner = | children = | parents = | relations = | callsign = | awards = | signature = | signature_alt = | website = | footnotes = | box_width = | misc = }}
'''Manuel Fal Conde, 1st Duke of Quintillo''' (1894–1975) was a Spanish Catholic activist and a [[Carlist]] politician. He is recognized as a leading figure in the history of Carlism, serving as its political leader for over 20 years (1934–1955) and heading the movement during one of its most turbulent periods. Initially he led the belligerent faction pressing anti-Republican insurgency; during the [[Spanish Civil War]] he joined the [[Nationalist faction (Spanish Civil War)|Nationalists]]; later on he championed anti-Francoist strategy.
==Family and youth== [[File:SierraDeAracena-P1040876.JPG|thumbnail|left|[[Sierra de Aracena]], [[Huelva province]]]] Manuel Lorenzo José Fal Conde descended from a petty [[bourgeoisie]] family originating from [[Asturias]];<ref>[Ana Marín Fidaldo, Manuel M. Burgueño], ''In memoriam. Manuel J. Fal Conde (1894-1975)'', Sevilla 1978, p. 19</ref> it is not clear when the family settled in [[Higuera de la Sierra]], a small town in the [[Andalusia]]n [[province of Huelva]]. Although many of his ancestors were connected with medicine,<ref>Manuel Fal Vázquez (born 1783), José Fal Vázquez (b. 1788), Manuel Fal Reyes (b. 1818), Juan Fal Reyes (b. 1817), Juan Fal Sánchez (b. 1849), Rafael Lancha Fal (b. 1885), Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 19</ref> his father, Domingo Fal Sánchez (1857-1926),<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 23</ref> was referred to as "agricultor y industrial", who owned a small workshop producing cork utilities<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 19</ref> and served as [[alcalde]] of Higuera between 1900 and 1905;<ref>''Alcaldes que rigieron el ayuntamiento de Higuera de la Sierra'', [in:] ''Inquietudes y vivencias de un sexagenario'' blog 25.10.13, available [http://inquietudesyvivencias.blogspot.com/2013/10/alcaldes-que-rigieron-el-ayuntamiento.html here]</ref> also later on Domingo Fal exercised influence on Higuera's life.<ref>e.g. in 1918 he launched Cabalgata de Reyes, the second oldest cabalgata in Spain, ''Higuera de la Sierra espera unas 35.000 visitas a su Cabalgata de Reyes en su 96 aniversario'', [in:] ''lainformacion.com'' service 03.01.14, available [http://noticias.lainformacion.com/estilo-de-vida-y-tiempo-libre/turismo/higuera-de-la-sierra-espera-unas-35-000-visitas-a-su-cabalgata-de-reyes-en-su-96-aniversario_IwkJgzO260fUUiWNc9N5Q6/ here]</ref> He married a local girl, María Josefa Conde;<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 19</ref> the couple lived in a building housing also the workshop. They had 4 children, Manuel was the youngest and his mother died 13 days after giving birth.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, pp. 19-20</ref> The widowed sister of Domingo helped to look after the children, brought up in fervently Catholic ambience.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 19</ref>
Manuel commenced his education in the [[Extremadura]]n town of [[Villafranca de los Barros]]. He entered the local [[Jesuit]] college<ref>founded in 1893, see ''Historia'' [in:] ''Colegio San José'' service, available [http://www.sanjosecolegio.com/index.php?id=10&zona=quienes&marca=enlace_25 here]</ref> and joined his two older brothers already being educated there.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 19</ref> The Jesuit education proved crucial in Manuel's formative years. It was Gabino Márquez, the Villafranca scholar of biblical studies, papal teaching and pedagogy,<ref>compare ''abebooks'' service available [http://www.abebooks.com/book-search/author/gabino-marquez-p/ here]</ref> who paid particular attention to the student, who he considered promising.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 20</ref> Following bachillerato obtained in 1911<ref>with excellent marks, Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 20</ref> the young Fal entered the Jesuit [[novitiate]], but he changed his mind some time afterwards, and considered studying medicine.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 20</ref> His father dissuaded him as his older brother, Domingo, was already pursuing that path;<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 20. For his work as a doctor Domíngo was later recognized by the Higuera community by the naming of a major street after him</ref> eventually Manuel commenced law studies in [[Seville]].<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 20</ref> [[File:Sevila19.JPG|thumbnail|160px|[[University of Seville]]]] At [[University of Seville|Universidad Hispalense]] Fal was drawn to a circle of Manuel Sanchez de Castro,<ref>Leandro Alvarez Rey, ''La derecha en la II República: Sevilla, 1931-1936'', Sevilla 1993, {{ISBN|9788447201525}}, p. 135</ref> a Carlist, catedratic of natural law and moving spirit behind the emergence of militant Catholicism in Seville.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 20. compare José Calvo Gonzalez, ''Restauración tomista y catolicismo militante en la Universidad de Sevilla (1884-1924''), [in:] ''Anuario de filosofia del derecho'' 6 (1989), pp. 377-395</ref> He graduated as licenciado in 1916; following a year in [[Madrid]] he obtained the grade of a doctor.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 21; not correspondent to the current PhD, in the Spanish education system of the time the title enabled to teach in colleges</ref> In 1917 he served as soldado [[:es:Militarismo en España|de cuota]]<ref>in 9. Regimiento de Infanteria of Soria, Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 21</ref> and in 1918 he entered Colegio de Abogados de Sevilla.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 21</ref> Following brief internship Fal opened his own office at calle José Gestoso.<ref>below the apartment occupied by his cousin Rafael Fal, Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 21</ref> In parallel to his law practice Fal commenced also his brief teaching and academic career. He taught history and law and ethics at the Jesuit college of Villasis in Seville.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, pp. 21-22, Alvarez Rey 1993, p. 135</ref> At Universidad Hispalense he worked at department of derecho procesal, at the same time pursuing research in history of Spanish political law.<ref>Alvarez Rey 1993, p. 135, Marín, Burgueño 1978, pp. 21-22</ref> He also briefly managed a car dealership.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 22</ref>
In 1922 Fal married María de los Reyes Macias Aguilar (1904-1975),<ref>''ABC'' 14.07.77, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1977/07/14/069.html here]</ref> a native of nearby [[Sanlúcar la Mayor|Sanlucar]].<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 22</ref> The newlyweds initially settled in Seville at calle Miguel del Cid.<ref>though in 1952, following death of his older brother, Fal inherited the family house in Higuera, he and his wife have always resided in Seville, living at 6 different locations, Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 22</ref> The couple had 7 children,<ref>José María, Mari Pepa, Domingo, Teresa, Alfonso Carlos, Javier and Pilar, see ''ABC'' 29.05.75, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/madrid/abc/1975/05/29/093.html here]</ref> born between 1923 and 1938.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, pp. 22-24, 30, 46-47; 1923 (José María), 1926 (María Pepa), 1928 (Domingo), 1930 (Teresa), 1932 (Alfonso Carlos), 1937 (Javier), 1938 (Pilar)</ref> Some were active as [[Traditionalism (Spain)|Traditionalist]] militants during the [[Francoism|Francoist]] period and afterwards, in the 1970s opposing the socialist bid of [[Carlos Hugo, Duke of Parma|Don Carlos Hugo]]; José Maria, Alfonso and Domingo Fal-Conde Macias<ref>in the 1960s he was leading provincial Sevilla Carlists until deposed by the Hugocarlistas, Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''El Naufragio de las ortodoxias. El carlismo 1962-1977'', Pamplona 1997, {{ISBN|8431315644}}, p. 100, see also Caín Somé Laserna, ''El tradicionalismo sevillano ante la transición hacia la democracia'', [in:] Rafael Quirosa-Cheyrouze Muñoz, Luis Carlos Navarro Pérez, Mónica Fernández Amador (eds.), ''Las organizaciones políticas : Congreso Internacional Historia de la Transición en España'', Almeria 2011, {{ISBN|9788469490761}}, pp. 355-368</ref> were present as supporters of [[Prince Sixtus Henry of Bourbon-Parma|Don Sixto]] during the [[Montejurra massacre|Montejurra incidents]] of 1976.<ref>''ABC'' 19.05.76, available [http://hemeroteca.abcdesevilla.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/1976/05/19/038.html here]</ref> In the 1980s Domingo Fal-Conde Macias served as head of [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista Carlista|Comunión Tradicionalista Carlista]], a new united Carlist organization.<ref>José Carlos Clemente, ''Seis estudios sobre el carlismo'', Madrid 1999, {{ISBN|9788483741528}}, p. 23</ref> Javier became known as [[:es:Flamenco|cantaor]].<ref>''ABC'' 19.04.05, available [http://hemeroteca.abc.es/nav/Navigate.exe/hemeroteca/sevilla/abc.sevilla/2005/04/19/007.html here]</ref>
==Early public career== [[File:Esparanza de triana año 1915.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Semana Santa]], Seville, around 1915]] It is not clear whether there were any Carlist antecedents among the ancestors of Fal; some authors claim there were none,<ref>Josep Carles Clemente, ''Ultima entrevista con Fal Conde'', [in:] ''elcaballerodeltristedestino'' blog 01.04.12, available [http://elcaballerodeltristedestino.blogspot.com/2012/04/la-ultima-entrevista-de-manuel-fal.html here]</ref> while others quote his family as exemplary case of Carlism having been transmitted from generation to generation as sort of a genetic code.<ref>allegedly the ancestral family record of Fal contained "precedentes familiares donde el ideario tradicionalista, furtemente arraigado, se transmitía de generación n generación como si de una especie de herencie genética se tratase", Alvarez Rey 1993, p. 125</ref> It is known that Fal's father was a devout Catholic, but none of the sources consulted provides clear information what exactly his political outlook was. It is possible that Traditionalist views were if not reinforced then implanted in the young Fal during his education. At the turn of the centuries the Jesuits were clearly sympathizing with [[Ramón Nocedal Romea|Ramón Nocedal]] and his [[Integrism (Spain)|Integrist]] vision of religion and Traditionalism; it is likely that his Villafranca years affected Fal accordingly. He admitted juvenile fascination with address delivered to the college audience by [[Manuel Senante Martinez|Manuel Senante]], at that time one of key Integrist politicians.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 20</ref> Militant Catholicism of Manuel Sanchez de Castro is likely to have contributed further on, forming the young Fal as an energetic Catholic activist, possibly along the intransigent and ultra-reactionary Integrist lines.<ref>compare his vision of Spain’s raison d’etre: "Patria española es una realidad historica, cuya unidad indestructibile fur forjada, no tanto por la comunidad de territorio, raza, o de lengua, sino ante todo y esencialmente por la unidad de Fe católica y el destino común de los diversos pueblos que concurren a formarla", quoted after Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, p. 5</ref>
Fal commenced his public assignments already during the academic years in Seville; he joined Asociación Escolar Sevillana and soon grew to be its president; the organization remained a fairly typical student grouping, though politically it tended towards "catolicismo político y social", flavored by Traditionalism in general and by pro-German [[World War I]] stand in particular.<ref>José Calvo Gonzalez, ''Restauración tomista y catolicismo militante en la Universidad de Sevilla (1884-1924)'', [in:] ''Anuario de filosofia del derecho'' 6 (1989), p. 387</ref> Following his return from Madrid he started contributing to local Catholic periodicals.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 21</ref> In the 1920s he excelled, however, in various Catholic organizations, ranging from educational associations to charity groupings to trade unions to penitentiary circles, like Congregación de los Luises, Conferencias de San Vicente de Paulo, various Hermandades de Penitencia, the Jesuit-sponsored Patronato para Obreros, the Franciscan-sponsored Compaña de las Hermanas de la Cruz and a number of others.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, pp. 21, 23</ref> He also launched some initiatives himself, like the 1924-inaugurated Romería de la Peña de la Reina de los Angeles.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, pp. 22-23</ref> Exposure to a variety of structures provided Fal with experience and confirmed his enormous capacity as organizer. [[File:La Esperanza Macarena en 1928.jpg|thumbnail|Semana Santa, Seville, 1928]] It is not clear whether during late [[Restoration (Spain)|Restoration]] or during the [[Miguel Primo de Rivera|Primo de Rivera]] dictatorship Fal was active in the Integrist ranks. When discussing his post-1931 activity, present-day scholars almost unanimously refer to him as to a former Integrist<ref>compare "el integrista Manuel Fal Conde" (Clemente 1999, p. 30), "Manuel Fal Conde (antiguo integrista)" (Julián Sanz Hoya, ''De la resistencia a la reacción: las derechas frente a la Segunda República (Cantabria, 1931-1936)'', Santander 2006, {{ISBN|9788481024203}}, p. 213), "Manuel Fal Conde, que procedía del integrismo" (Gonzalo Redondo, ''Historia de la Iglesia en España, 1931-1939: La Segunda República, 1931-1936'', Madrid 1993, {{ISBN|9788432129841}}, p. 305), "integrista Manuel Fal Conde" (Eduardo Gonzalez-Calleja, ''El ex-rey'', [in:] Javier Moreno Luzón (ed.), ''Alfonso XIII'', Madrid 2003, {{ISBN|9788495379597}}, p. 418), "Manuel Fal-Conde, joven abogado andaluz, procedente del campo integrista" (Román Oyarzun Oyarzun, ''Historia del carlismo'', Madrid 2008, {{ISBN|9788497614481}}, p. 464), "integrista Manuel Fal Conde" (Javier Tusell, Feliciano Montero García, José María Marín Arce, ''Las derechas en la España contemporánea'', Madrid 1997, {{ISBN|9788476585245}}, p. 219), "integristas como Manuel Fal Conde" (Antonio M. Moral Roncal, ''La cuestión religiosa en la Segunda República Española: Iglesia y carlismo'', Madrid 2009, {{ISBN|9788497429054}}, p. 64), "Manuel Fal Conde, abogado integrista de Sevilla" (Juan Iturralde, ''La guerra de Franco, los vascos y la iglesia: Quiénes y con qué fin prepararon la guerra y cómo comenzó'', New York 1978, p. 98)</ref> or even more explicitly as to "antiguo militante del Partido Integrista",<ref>Fernando García Cortázar, ''El tradicionalismo de Fal Conde'', [in:] ''ABC'' 19.05.15, available [http://www.abc.es/cultura/20150519/abci-tradicionalismo-cortazar-historia-ideas-201505161737.html here]</ref> though none provides detailed information on his engagement in any party initiatives of the 1920s.<ref>some sources claim that he joined the Integrists as late as 1930, Robert Vallverdú i Martí, ''El Carlisme Català Durant La Segona República Espanyola 1931-1936'', Barcelona 2008, {{ISBN|9788478260805}}, p. 161f, Jordi Canal, ''El carlismo'', Madrid 2000, {{ISBN|8420639478}}, p. 312</ref> When reporting on Fal's activities in 1930, the Integrist daily ''[[El Siglo Futuro]]'' referred to him as "queridisimo amigo nuestro de Sevilla",<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.10.30, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000477241&page=1 here]</ref> which suggests that he might have indeed co-operated with Integrism in general and the newspaper in particular also earlier on, especially that he displayed a particular knack for journalism: he is known to have contributed to various press titles before 1923,<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 21</ref> launched his own daily later and was correspondent of ''El Siglo Futuro'' in the early 1930s.
==Political beginnings== [[File:Fitxer Proclamació de la República Plaça Sant Jaume. Fotògraf Josep Maria Sagarra, 1931.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] declared, 1931]] Fal, who later confessed to approaching politics as Christian responsibility and a call from God,<ref>Santiago Martínez Sánchez, ''El jacobinismo antirrepublicano del Manuel Fal Conde y del cardenal Segura'', [in:] Manuel Álvarez Tardío (ed.), ''Nuevos estudios sobre la Cultura Política en la II República Española 1931-1936'', Madrid 2012, {{ISBN|9788415454830}}, p. 106; furtherly developed in Ricardo Martínez de Salazar y Bascuñana, ''Manuel J. Fal Conde. La política como servicio de Dios y España'', Cádiz, 1998. By the end of his life he straightforwardly referred to Comunión Tradicionalista as "obra de Dios" and perceived its mission as political evangelization, Caspistegui Gorasurreta 1997, pp. 150-1. Though devout faithful, he nevertheless resisted advances of Catholic visionaries like José Lles Segarra, Moral Roncal 2009, p. 210</ref> was first recorded as engaged in a political enterprise in the spring of 1930. He was among members of Junta Organizadora of Partido Tradicionalista-Integrista, a new post-dictatorial incarnation of Integrism,<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 11.04.30, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000469914&page=1 here]</ref> and emerged as leader of the Seville branch of the party.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 20.10.30, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000477526&page=1 here]; some sources claim that the group was in fact a joint Integrist and [[Jaime, Duke of Madrid|Jaimist]] initiative, preconfiguration of later unification of all Traditionalist branches; according to this account both the Integrist leader Juan Olazabal and the Jaimist one marqués de Villores nominated Fal Jefe Regional of Western Andalusia of their respective organizations, Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 24</ref> In late 1930 he was also busy co-organizing local branches of Juventud Integrista.<ref>''El Siglo Futuro'' 13.10.30, available [http://hemerotecadigital.bne.es/issue.vm?id=0000477241&page=1 here]</ref> Fal witnessed emergence of militantly secular [[Second Spanish Republic|Republic]] with horror;<ref>compare Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''1868 en la memoria carlista de 1931: dos revoluciones anticlericales y un paralelo'', [in:] ''Hispania Sacra'' 59/119 (2007), pp. 337-361</ref> he personally led local Juventud organization trying to protect the Seville churches against [[:es:Quema de conventos de 1931 en España|violence which erupted in May 1931]].<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 25</ref> In June 1931 he ran for [[Cortes Generales|Cortes]] from [[Cadiz]];<ref>some claim that he competed as member of the Right-wing coalition, see Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 25; other sources claim that he presented his bid as Independent Right candidate, Martin Blinkhorn, Carlism and Crisis in Spain 1931-1939, Cambridge 2008, {{ISBN|9780521207294}}, p. 54</ref> the bid proved unsuccessful. According to a homage publication Fal gained enough votes to be voted in, but it was behind-the-stage manipulations which relegated him to non-electable position; embittered, he has never run for the Cortes again.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 25. According to the authors, impartial scrutiny would have given Fal 15,000 votes. According to official results, the last elected candidate in the Cadíz district gathered 34,000 votes, compare the official Cortes service, available [http://www.congreso.es/portal/page/portal/Congreso/Congreso/SDocum/ArchCon/SDHistoDipu/SDBuscHisDip?_piref73_1340033_73_1340032_1340032.next_page=/wc/enviarCgiBuscadorHistorico here]</ref> Instead, he focused on a newly acquired daily, ''El Observador'', re-launched as an ultraconservative Catholic title in Seville,<ref>more details in Alfonso Braojos Garrido, ''Tradicionalismo y antimasonería en la Sevilla de la II República. El semanario "El Observador" (1931-1933)'', [in:] José Antonio Ferrer Benimeli (ed.), ''Masonería, política y sociedad'', vol. 1, Madrid 1989, {{ISBN|8440449402}}, pp. 381-404</ref> apart from contributing to other local periodicals.<ref>like the Integrist ''La Union'', Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 26</ref>
In early 1932 the Integrists re-united with Carlism in [[:es:Comunión Tradicionalista|Comunión Tradicionalista]]. Fal was entrusted the West-Andalusian jefatura<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 24</ref> and together with provincial leaders<ref>José María Alvear (Cordoba), Ramón Contreras (Granada), Fernando Contreras (Jáen) and Ricardo Huelin (Málaga), Moral Roncal 2009, p. 79</ref> achieved remarkable success implanting Traditionalism where it was hardly popular.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 74; some scholars write about "auténtica eclosión tradicionalista" in Western Andalusia, all thanks to proselytism and efficiency of Fal, Canal 2000, p. 313; detailed analysis of his strategy in Moral Roncal 2012 and Leandro Alvarez Rey, ''El carlismo en Andalusia durante la II República (1931-1936)'', [in:] Alfonso Braojos Garrido, Leandro Alvarez Rey, Francisco Espinoza Maestre (eds.), ''Sevilla 36: sublevación fascista y represión'', Brenes 1990, {{ISBN|9788486335663}}, pp. 17-79</ref> Characteristic feature of his leadership was – even in comparison to other Carlist leaders - unveiled hostility towards the Republic. Fal remained enthusiastic about co-operation with [[Sanjurjo]];<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 28-9</ref> Andalusia was where the coup was most welcomed by local Carlists.<ref>some of them killed in the fighting which ensued, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 91</ref> In the aftermath Fal was arrested for 3 months,<ref>longer incarceration was experienced only by 2 leaders of Andalusian requeté, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 92, Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 29</ref> which did not discourage him from sounding other military on leading a potential Carlist rising.<ref>like Varela, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 97; the two met in prison, Canal 2000, p. 300</ref> Also his ''El Observador'' kept making references to violence.<ref>Fal noted that the Catholic citizenry must defend society "even with its blood" against unjust and usurping power, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 104; in July 1933 he stated bluntly that "power is violence" and called to organize resistance adequate to the violence experienced, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 103</ref> Two other specific features of Andalusian Carlism were impact on Catholic youth<ref>Fal proved to be very skilful when organising Semana Santa in Seville in 1932; as a lawyer he did his utmost to defy the constitutional ban on all public displays or religiosity, Moral Roncal 2009, p. 64; he turned out to be staunch defender of Segura and enemy of Herrera Oria and Tedeschini, accused of appeasement and cowardice, Moral Roncal 2009, p. especially the chapter ''"Contra el imperio de los personalismos": críticas carlistas contra Tedeschini, Herrera Oria y Vidal'', pp. 165-176. Compare also "lealtad, valentía: Senante, Fal Conde, ''El Siglo Futuro''. Los protagonistas de las "cobardias y defecciones" quedarían (con frecuencia, aunque no siempre) implícatos en su [Segura’s] pluma. No es necesario cavilar en exceso para intuir, que se referia al triunvirato Herrera-Tedeschini-Vidal y Barraquer", Santiago Martínez Sánchez, ''El Cardenal Pedro Segura y Sáenz (1880-1957)'', [PhD thesis at Universidad de Navarra], Pamplona 2002, p. 225</ref> and initiatives targeting the urban working-class. In many Andalusian districts Carlism emerged as an exclusively youth movement, which in the spring of 1933 pushed Fal to create a federation of local Juventud circles.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 116, Moral Roncal 2009, p. 85</ref> Acute social problems in turn induced Fal to set up fairly successful Workers Section in early 1933.<ref>named Agrupación Gremial Tradicionalista, Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 30, also Blinkhorn 2008, p. 117, Moral Roncal 2009, p. 85</ref> [[File:Quintillo 1934.jpg|thumb|Quintillo,1934]] Fal gained nationwide attention following the [[Zumarraga, Spain|Zumarraga]] act;<ref>in June 1933 the Carlists organized nationwide celebrations to the memory of Zumalacarregui, staged in a Gipuzkoan town of Zumarraga. Attendants, mostly from the North of Spain, were amazed by arrival of a cavalcade of buses carrying a massive Andalusian contingent, headed by Fal, Eduardo Gonzales Calleja, ''Contrarrevolucionarios'', Madrid 2011, {{ISBN|9788420664552}}, p. 194</ref> in recognition of his excellent organization skills in November 1933 [[Alfonso Carlos, Duke of San Jaime|Alfonso Carlos]] nominated Fal Jefe Regional for all Andalusia,<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 32; for Fal as Carlist regional leader see Antonio Manuel Moral Roncal, ''Manuel Fal Conde y el carlismo andaluz'', [in:] José Leonardo Ruiz Sánchez (ed.), ''La confrontación católico-laicista en Andalucía durante la crisis de entreguerras'', Sevilla 2012, {{ISBN|978-8447214198}}, pp. 169-188</ref> but the most impressive coup was yet to come: in April 1934 regional Carlism organized a massive gathering at Quintillo estate near Seville. This demonstration of local prowess climaxed in parade of 650 uniformed and well-trained [[Requetés]], which made a stunning impact on guests from other regions.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, pp. 32-3</ref> When national leadership of [[Tomás Domínguez Arévalo|Conde Rodezno]] was called into question due to rapprochement with the [[Alfonsism|Alfonsists]] and his gradualist strategy,<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 137, Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 33</ref> Fal became one of top contenders for the job.<ref>his candidature launched by Lamamie, Contreras and Senante</ref> Alfonso Carlos, himself sympathetic to Integrism and personally familiar with Fal since late Restoration, seemed well-disposed. In May 1934, despite his relatively young age<ref>people assuming Carlist political leadership were usually far more advanced in age: Nocedal was 58 (in 1879), Cerralbo 45 (1890), Barrio 55 (1899), Feliu 66 (1909), [[Cesáreo Sanz Escartín|Sanz Escartin]] 74 (1918), Comín 61 (1919) and Rodezno 50 (1932), though there were exceptions: Larramendi and Villores were only 38 (respectively in 1919 and in 1921)</ref> and unenthusiastic welcome from Carlist stronghold, [[Navarre]], Fal was nominated Secretary General of the Communión.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 138. Canal 2000, pp. 312-3, gives two reasons for Fal’s elevation: his relatively young age and successes in Andalusia</ref> ''El Siglo Futuro'' hailed him as "Sevillian [[Zumalacarregui]]"<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 138, Canal 2000, p. 314</ref> and Carlist youth welcomed him as the man who "brought [[Montejurra]] to Andalusia".<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 140; favourably disposed contemporaries claimed that he turned the city from "Sevilla la Roja" to "Sevilla de las Boinas Rojas", Moral Roncal 2009, p. 85</ref>
==''Jefe''== [[File:Míting del del Cercle Tradicionalista.jpeg|thumb|left|Carlist meeting, 1930s]] Fal embarked on massive reorganization of Carlist structures.<ref>the most thorough organisational change since remodeling commanded by marqués de Cerralbo in the 1890s</ref> He created 5 central Delegaciones;<ref>co-ordinating Youth, Press, Propaganda, Requeté and Finance activities, headed respectively by Arellano, Gonzalez Quevedo, Lamamié, Zamanillo and Sangarrén, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 207, Vallverdú 2008, p. 163</ref> Council of Culture<ref>headed by Pradera, it was set up to diffuse ideology and unite Carlists of different origins, Blinkhorn 2008, pp. 207-8</ref> and Grand Council.<ref>it was created to bring regional jefaturas closer to command centre, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 208</ref> Launch of official Carlist gazette enhanced communication.<ref>named ''Boletín de Orientación Tradicionalista''; it removed perennial problem of dependence on good will of editorial staff running Carlist dailies; the key ones at that time were ''El Siglo Futuro'' (Madrid), ''El Pensamiento Navarro'' (Pamplona), ''El Correo Catalan'' (Barcelona) and ''La Union'' (Sevilla). For detailed discussion see José Fermín Garralda Arizcun, ''"El Boletín Carlista de Orientación Tradicionalista" y la strategia política del tradicionalismo de 1934 a 1936,'' [in:] Alfonso Bullón de Mendoza, Luis Togores (eds.), ''Revisión de la Guerra Civil Española'', Madrid 2002, {{ISBN|8497390008}}, pp. 436-444</ref> Most importantly, he detached affiliated organizations from local circulos and joined them in nationwide, parallel, centrally commanded structures. The first remodeled were Requeté<ref>detailed discussion in Julio Aróstegui, ''Combatientes Requetés en la Guerra Civil española, 1936-1939'', Madrid 2013, {{ISBN|9788499709758}}, esp. chapter ''Manuel Fal Conde y la milicia para la insurrección'', pp. 79-84; see also Gonzales Calleja 2011, pp. 198-200, 259-265, Eduardo G. Calleja, Julio Aróstegui, ''La tradición recuperada: el Requeté Carlista y la insurrección'', [in:] ''Historia Contemporanea'' 11 (1994), pp. 30-31. Fal contributed to Requeté buildup in his trademark way, compiling ''Requete Prayerbook''; Pablo Larraz Andía, Víctor Sierra-Sesumaga (eds.), ''Requetés. De las trincheras al olvidio'', Madrid 2011, {{ISBN|9788499700465}}, p. 126; on the cover it bore a phrase "Ante Dios nunca serás héroe anónimo" (before God you are never an anonymous hero), intended to counter the atheist symbol of an unknown soldier, Jeremy MacClancy, ''The Decline of Carlism'', Reno 2000, {{ISBN|9780874173444}}, p. 20</ref> and Juventud Tradicionalista,<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 208-9</ref> with [[:es:Agrupación Escolar Tradicionalista|AET]] and Margaritas (Carlist feminine organization) somewhat less successful.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 212</ref> New affiliated formations were created: urban proletariat was lured to Agrupación Gremial, a Carlist red cross organization emerged as Socorro Blanco and a grouping for younger boys was established as Pelayos.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 211</ref> Internal taxation was introduced.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 214; he created Tesoro de la Tradicion, sort of the Carlist ministry of finance, Vallverdu 2008, p. 164</ref> Carlist periodicals were co-ordinated within modern propaganda machinery,<ref>one scholar has coined the term "modernización reaccionaria", "reactionary modernity", to describe the Fal’s skills in expoiting modern means to pursue his reactionary policy, see Francisco Javier Caspistegui Gorasurreta, ''Paradójicos reaccionarios: la modernidad contra la República de la Comunión Tradicionalista'', [in:] ''El Argonauta Espanol'' 9 (2012), available [http://argonauta.revues.org/1409 here]</ref> brought under more discipline in return for financial help.<ref>which i.e. transformed ''El Siglo Futuro'' from a 19th-century daily into a fully modern newspaper with photographs, graphics, complex layout and new sections, Vallverdú 2008, p. 275; in 1935 Carlism controlled 9 dailies, 19 other periodicals, Josep Carles Clemente, ''Los días fugaces. El carlismo, de las guerras civiles a la transición'', Cuenca 2013, {{ISBN|978-8495414243}}, p. 37. Detailed discussion in Cristina Barrero Gordillo, ''El carlismo y su red de prensa en la Segunda Republica'', Bilbao 2004, {{ISBN|9788497390378}} and Eduardo González Calleja, ''La prensa carlista y falangista durante la Segunda República y la Guerra Civil (1931-1937)'', [in:] ''El Argonauta Espanol'' 9 (2012)</ref>
The change meant vast improvement in terms of steerability,<ref>Requeté transformed from local groupings, capable at best of protecting local churches, into a nationwide paramilitary structure capable of achieving tactical military objectives. No other party possessed a comparable "shirt organization", with Falangist, Anarchist, Socialist or Communist militias formatted chiefly as urban hit-squads specialising in limited street violence like sabotage, arson or assassination</ref> provided critical mass and enhanced homogeneity,<ref>Canal 2000, p. 314</ref> though also enforced discipline and laid command of all structures in hands of Fal and his entourage, removing dependence on local juntas and especially on the [[Southern Basque Country|Vasco-Navarros]].<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 220</ref> The latter complained about "fascistization" of the Comunión,<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, pp. 220-222</ref> especially that Fal's trusted collaborators were appointed to key positions.<ref>others were offered prestigious but not really influential roles; that was the case of conde Rodezno, former political leader. He was not given jefatura of any of the newly created sections, but was offered a seat in the Council of Culture instead, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 208</ref> Nevertheless, remodeled Comunión was fully able to bear the weight of rapidly expanding ranks; instead of inefficient isolated circulos where zeal of new converts was evaporating, new structures channeled and reinforced enthusiasm.<ref>for numerical overview of Carlist structures in 1936 see Vallverdú 2008, pp. 248–260</ref> Organization question aside, the change started even to affect the way of life.<ref>apart from reading Carlist newspapers and frequenting Carlist libraries, Carlists were asked to buy Carlist products, spend vacations in Carlist hotels and even play football in Carlist football league, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 211; Fal co-founded Asociación Deportiva Tradicionalista, Moral Roncal 2009, p. 121</ref> Comunión began to expand into unlikely areas both geographically and socially; structures were emerging in such regions as Extremadura or the [[Canary Islands|Canaries]], while following the example of Western Andalusia, representatives of urban proletariat started to appear in local bodies also elsewhere.<ref>structures of the Comunión were incomparably more heterogeneous socially than those of Renovación, filled often with local aristocrats; some scholars call them, applying their own social cliches and preferences, "more democratic", see Blinkhorn 2008, p. 213</ref>
Unlike the Northerners who conceived Traditionalism as rooted in family and regional values,<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, pp. 153-4</ref> Fal was focused on structures. As alliances were likely to get them dominated by other groupings, victorious campaign – maybe unfeasible as exclusively Carlist affair - should be launched and controlled by Carlists.<ref>a British scholar writing in the 1970s, perfectly familiar with history of Carlist marginalization within Francoist structures, nevertheless hails Rodezno’s strategy as "pragmatic" and lambasts Fal’s vision as "sheer wishful thinking", Blinkhorn 2008, p. 154</ref> In line with this vision, under Fal Carlism steered clear of alliances,<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, pp. 135-6</ref> its strategy dubbed "isolationism" or "exclusiveness".<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 229</ref> Though he felt compelled to join [[Renovación Española]] in National Bloc (the Spanish Right-wing political alliance of the 1930s) late 1934, he made sure the access was as non-committal as possible.<ref>Vallverdú 2008, pp. 188-194, Moral Roncal 2009, p. 127-134</ref> In 1935 he grew increasingly skeptical<ref>Canal 2008, p. 318</ref> and later that year let Rodezno mix with the Alfonsinos on the private business basis<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 215</ref> before definitely abandoning the alliance in the spring of 1936.<ref>Canal 2000, p. 318</ref> From the onset highly suspicious about [[Spanish Confederation of Autonomous Right-wing Groups|CEDA]]<ref>already in 1933 Fal expressed a view, later growing to a dogma, that members of different parties better stick to their own organizations, Blinkhorn 2008, pp. 203-4, Witnessing the emergence of CEDA he was skeptical, not only because of its accidentalism and infection of liberalism, but also as it was born out of the ungodly Republican regime, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 102. In late 1933, when CEDA opted for a coalition with Lerroux, Fal, recently promoted to Delegate for all Andalusia, concluded that Gil Robles had cut himself off from his former allies and that was no way to defend religion in Spain, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 125. In early 1934 ''El Observador'' was waging a regular anti-CEDA campaign, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 130</ref> he was more than happy to see it decompose in 1935-6.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 229</ref> [[File:Flag of Cross of Burgundy.svg|thumbnail|Carlist standard]] Another shift in Carlist strategy under Fal was [[Electoral Carlism (Second Republic)|de-emphasizing of politics]] and focusing on organizational buildup, with special attention paid to paramilitary. His vision was already set on violent overthrow of the Republic; starting 1935 openly belligerent language became increasingly common at Carlist rallies, with references to sacrifice, blood, arms, violence and power.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 219</ref> Permitting taking part in 1936 elections, Fal did not pay much attention to the campaign.<ref>Alfonso Carlos addressed Fal in a letter, suggesting that he fields his candidature as well; Fal refused, Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 34</ref> Though Rodeznistas viewed him as a uninspiring, colorless, mediocre bureaucrat,<ref>especially compared to charismatic figures of other Right-wing leaders like Calvo Sotelo or José Antonio, or even compared to eloquent and gregarious Rodezno; Blinkhorn 2008, p. 215. The so-called cruzadistas accused Fal and his "Integrist camarilla" of taking part in conspiracy, aiming at transferring dynastic rights to the Alfonsinos, though scholars dismiss this charges as idiosyncratic. In fact, Fal was also anxious about looming problem of succession, but preferred not to press Alfonso Carlos and wait for him to make a decision, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 216</ref> Fal gained recognition bordering devotion among Requeté and the youth.<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 215</ref> Also Alfonso Carlos seemed perfectly satisfied;<ref>Fal accepted Alfonso Carlos’ decision to set up a regency with no objections. Though many considered Don Javier – a hardly known foreigner – a laughable figure as a prospective claimant, and preferred fusionist talks with the Alfonsinos instead, it was not the case of Fal, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 230</ref> in December 1935 he raised Fal from Secretary General to Jefe Delegado.<ref>Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 34</ref>
==Insurgency and unification== [[File:El Siglo Futuro Alfonso Carlos y Javier.png|thumb|160px|left|[[Alfonso Carlos, Duke of San Jaime|Alfonso Carlos]] and [[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Don Javier]], April 1936]] Convinced that in the battle against democracy Carlists must strike first,<ref>especially after the [[Popular Front (Spain)|Popular Front]] victory in [[Spanish general election, 1936|February 1936 elections]], Blinkhorn 2008, p. 206</ref> Fal threw himself into wartime preparations;<ref>spending more time in San-Jean-de-Luz with Don Javier than in Spain, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 237, Marín, Burgueño 1978, p. 35. Some sources claim he was exiled in France, Mercedes Peñalba Sotorrío, ''Entre la boina roja y la camisa azul'', Estella 2013, {{ISBN|9788423533657}}, p. 16, Stanley G. Payne, ''Falange: a History of Spanish Fascism'', vol. 22, Stanford 1961, {{ISBN|9780804700580}}, pp. 109-110, also Jacek Bartyzel, ''Manuel (José) Fal Conde'', [in:] ''legitymizm.org'' service, available [http://www.legitymizm.org/spw-manuel-fal-conde here]. He headed the Junta Suprema Militar, consisting of general Muslera, teniente coronel Baselga, teniente coronel Rada, capitan Sanjurjo (son of the exiled general) and local military inspectors, Juan Carlos Peñas Bernaldo de Quirós, ''El Carlismo, la República y la Guerra Civil (1936-1937). De la conspiración a la unificación'', Madrid 1996, {{ISBN|9788487863523}}, pp. 18-21</ref> his initial plan was abandoned in April 1936.<ref>it envisioned two focos of Requeté insurgency in Western Spain as means to lure governmental troops, while Madrid conspirators disguised as Guardia Civil were to take control of key offices and Requeté arriving from the North would guarantee success as reinforcements. The plan was abandoned when security discovered false Guardia Civil uniforms. It was based on assumption that the army would remain passive; though talks were held with Sanjurjo, no accord was struck; Blinkhorn 2008, pp. 240-2, Peñas Bernaldo 1996, p. 23</ref> He envisaged a purely Carlist insurrection<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 238</ref> with conditional assistance of the army.<ref>which might be helpful if not vital, given the military do not push conditions compromising Carlist principles, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 226</ref> Fal placed his bets on Sanjurjo, who agreed to lead the rising.<ref>either staged as exclusively Carlist enterprise or as a joint Carlist-military project; transitional government would be a stopgap solution leading to establishment of a Traditionalist monarchy, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 243. Sanjurjo and Fal met as early as in March 1936 in Lisbon, Peñas Bernaldo 1996, p. 22</ref> Talks with [[Emilio Mola|Mola]] proved unsuccessful. The general<ref>most of the conspiring generals viewed insurgency as means to change the government, prevent revolution and ensure order, not as means to re-establish the monarchy, let alone a Traditionalist one, César Alcalá, ''D. Mauricio de Sivatte. Una biografía política (1901-1980)'', Barcelona 2001, {{ISBN|8493109797}}, p. 29</ref> refused to accept Fal's conditions,<ref>during the talks Fal remained entirely intransigent, which drove Mola to desperation. He later admitted having been close to shooting himself, "este hombre [Fal] estuvo a punto de conseguir que yo me pegara un tiro", Maximiliano Garcia Venero, ''Historia de la unificacion'', Madrid 1970, p. 76</ref> which aimed at toppling the Republic and installing Traditionalist monarchy.<ref>he demanded derogation of Republican legislature, dissolution of all parties (including the supportive ones), provisional dictatorship with temporary directorate heavily controlled by the Carlists, future corporatist state, and usage of monarchist standard; detailed review of the talks in Peñas Bernaldo 1996, pp. 31-35, Peñalba Sotorrío 2013, pp. 18-21, Aróstegui 2013, pp. 93-128, Gonzales Calleja 2011, pp. 370-388</ref> However, Mola opened parallel negotiations with the Navarrese. Led by Rodezno, the latter bypassed Fal and were keen to commit local Requeté to a joint insurgency with almost no strings attached.<ref>most detailed account in Tomás Echeverría, ''Cómo se preparó el alzamiento: el general Mola y los carlistas'', Madrid 1985, {{ISBN|8439850123}}; see also Blinkhorn 2008, pp. 246-8, Peñas Bernaldo 1996, pp. 35-37. Key Falcondistas are listed as follows: José Luis Zamanillo, José Zuazola, José Martinez Berasáin (sic!), Juan María Roma, Pedro Roma, Mauricio Sivatte, Juan Lavaquial, José Brú, Luis Zuazola and Agustín Tellería. Key Rodeznistas listed are: conde Rodezno, Victor Pradera, Fernando Contreras, José María Oriol, Juan Olazábal, Domingo Tejera, Javier Martínez de Morentin, Luis Arellano, Marcelino Ulibarri, Gaitán de Ayalá, José María Valiente (sic!) and José María Arauz de Robles, Peñalba Sotorrío 2013, p. 18. Some authors add also the Baleztena brothers, though others indicate that their position was highly ambiguous, see Manuel Martorell Pérez, ''La continuidad ideológica del carlismo tras la Guerra Civil'' [PhD thesis in Historia Contemporanea, Universidad Nacional de Educación a Distancia], Valencia 2009, p. 121</ref> Though at that point Fal considered dismissing the entire Navarrese junta,<ref>Blinkhorn 2008, p. 249</ref> he decided not to risk open confrontation; Rodezno and his entourage outmaneuvered him and elicited hesitant approval from the royal envoy, [[Prince Xavier of Bourbon-Parma|Don Javier]].<ref>Don Javier later referred to the stance adopted by the Navarros as "una traicíon a nuestros principios y a nuestras gentes, cuya sangre habemos sacrificado inutimente", Peñas Bernaldo 1996, pp. 39-40. There was no formal pact between the military and the Carlists; Mola and Fal agreed to act on basis of the letter, sent by Sanjurjo on July 11. Its contents allow usage of monarchist standard provided army units related use none, apolitical government with civilians, abolishing of all political parties (including these supporting the coup), dismantling Republican regime and introducing a new state. There was no explicit committal to monarchy, let alone Traditionalist one, and no guarantee of Carlist role in either military command or provisional government. Blinkhorn 2008, pp. 247-250</ref>
Upon the [[Spanish coup of July 1936|outbreak of hostilities]]<ref>on July 19 he was flown from Sant-Jean-de-Luz to Pamplona, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 121, where he spent a day. During the night he travelled by car to Burgos, Peñas Bernaldo 1996, p. 215, others say he stayed in Pamplona until July 25, Martorell Pérez 2009, p. 121</ref> Fal headed the new Carlist wartime executive, Junta Nacional Carlista de Guerra,<ref>full squad in Ricardo Ollaquindia, ''La Oficina de Prensa y Propaganda Carlista de Pamplona al comienzo de la guerra de 1936'', [in:] ''Príncipe de Viana'' 56 (1995), p. 486. See also Peñas Bernaldo 1996, p. 218, Peñalba Sotorrío 2013, p. 28. Fal divided his time between office work, talking to foreign correspondents (compare ''Fal Conde y el requete juzgados por el extranjero Cronicas de prensa'', a book published in Burgos in 1937, and Antonio César Moreno Cantano, ''El carlismo y la propaganda exterior durante la Guerra Civil española'' [unpublished paper delivered to Congreso La Guerra Civil Española 1936 - 1939, 2006]) and especially visiting Carlist troops on the front-lines, Larraz, Sierra-Sesumaga 2011, p. 212, Aróstegui 2013, pp. 357, 436, 713, 729</ref> and had to acknowledge that instead of being equal partner, Carlism was getting reduced to a junior role.<ref>as late as in September Fal saw the rising as an alliance of equals between the military and the Carlists; he found room for the Falange only as a junior partner, whose assistance was somewhat condescendingly welcomed, Blinkhorn 2008, p. 265.
